PETITION.TITLE: Marriage
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Marriage

To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: We the undersigned citizens of Australia concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown, convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened.
Humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
1. reject any moves towards divorce by post
2. restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or marriage
3. protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
4. ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
5. encourage counselling towards reconciliation
6. restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
(i) intolerable behaviour;
(ii) desertion for two years;
(iii) separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation .
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Sir John Carrick (from 11 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination Against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President, and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23(1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State'. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23(1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the Nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10(c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Sir John Carrick (from 10 citizens), Collard (from 18 citizens), Jessop (from 120 citizens) and Watson (from 191 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace Klaipeda, Lithuania was the only church permitted (by the Soviet authorities) to be built in post-war Lithuania.
That the church was built by the Catholic parishoners from their own resources and with support from overseas Christians.
That upon completion of the church building in 1960, the church was not allowed to be consecrated and, in 1961 was resumed by the State for purposes other than religious.

That this resumption of the church and the subsequent persecution and arrests of the local clergy and other christians is contrary to the spirit and the letter of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and International Covenent on Human Rights.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled request the Australian Government to communicate most strongly to the Government of the USSR the sympathy of the petitioners for the plight of the Lithuanian Christians and ask that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the Catholics of Klaipeda for the practice of their religion without interference.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I merely wish to indicate to the Senate that this is an arrangement which has been made with the Opposition.
—Order! There is too much audible conversation in the chamber.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. We would like to hear the Opposition Leader but we cannot. Something is wrong with the microphone, I think .
—I have just drawn the attention of honourable senators to the level of noise in the chamber. I call Senator Chaney.

—The blessed silence which has descended I am sure will aid the microphone mightily. I wish to indicate to the Senate that the Opposition agreed to these revised sitting hours on the basis that next week was likely to be the final week of sitting. Many changes and concessions have been made during that period to ensure that the Government has time to conclude its business. However, I want to advise the Senate of what has been discussed privately, namely, that the Opposition would have preferred not to continue sitting for a continuous five-week period. I had some discussions with the Government and with the Australian Democrats about that matter. A continuous five-week period of sitting is very wearing on the Government, not less than the Opposition. In general we would prefer to have a pattern of sittings which did not involve such continuous periods of sitting. It was the view of the Australian Democrats in those discussions that other arrangements would probably be made even more convenient if we broke the sittings and then resumed. Since it was clear that the Opposition would not have a majority if it sought to ensure that we had a week up and then resumed sitting, it seemed better to go along with the proposal and not to waste a lot of parliamentary time. Because the matter may be an issue in the Budget session, which will be a more normal session in that there will not be an election which will interfere with the pattern of sitting and make the Government's job more difficult, I publicly indicate that the view of the Opposition will be against prolonged periods of sitting of the sort that we have had to have on this occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the view of the Opposition that we should, if possible, have both Tuesday and Wednesday mornings free for party and shadow Cabinet meetings in the traditional way. I mention that matter because in the negotiations-quite informal negotiations at times-which took place around the rearrangement of sitting hours during the last parliament, concessions were made to the then Opposition's view that it required the Tuesday and Wednesday mornings to meet its responsibilities to Caucus and to the shadow Ministry or shadow Cabinet, whatever it was termed. At that time the Government acceded to the request of representatives of the Opposition that we should permit that pattern.

I have little doubt that after the experience of these revised sitting hours it will be necessary for us to have some discussions about what this pattern has meant to the operations of both the Government and the Opposition and what pattern the Government will suggest to the Parliament for the Budget session. I wish to indicate that Opposition senators are firmly of the view that we would like to avoid these prolonged period of sittings and we would like those mornings I have mentioned to be free. Of course, we are ready, willing and able to sit whenever the Government has business and we do not seek to avoid our responsibilities in that respect. But there are features of the present sitting hours which are difficult. As I said earlier I think the Government will have found those difficulties impinging on its operations.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

There was general agreement at the National Economic Summit that an economic planning advisory council (EPAC) should be established to continue the process of co-operation and consultation begun at the Summit Conference.

The purpose of this Bill is to put this commitment to co-operation and consultation into effect. Through EPAC the Government will have available to it, on a continuing basis, independent advice from State governments, industry, unions and community groups which will be invaluable to the process of economic policy formulation. However, this information flow will not be just one way. The public release of a large volume of government information prior to the National Economic Summit is evidence of the fact that the Government is firmly committed to knowledge sharing. The Government is convinced that such knowledge sharing plays an integral part in establishing a common perception among various community groups regarding the causes of, and possible solutions to, Australia's economic difficulties.

The Bill before the Senate defines the functions of the council and invests it with sufficiently wide powers to enable it to execute its functions. Provisions are made for the council to express its views freely and to have its own independent secretariat. It is important that EPAC be constituted as a statutory body in order to provide the council with the status, permanence and stability it needs to do its job effectively. It is also important to ensure that EPAC is as independent as possible of any department of government, and statutory status is necessary to achieve this.

The functions of the council are defined in clause 6 of the Bill. In essence, the council's role will be to act as a vehicle for community participation in the development of government economic policy. In particular, it is intended that the council will:
Draw together the views of community representatives on prospective economic conditions and appropriate economic policies;
Identify feasible and desirable goals and targets for the economy as a whole;
Provide perspectives on the medium-and longerterm economic outlook; and
Develop policies to help realise the maximum growth potentialities of the economy and assist in the achievement of sustained economic growth.

These functions will allow the council a very wide charter. In addition to acting as a vehicle for knowledge sharing and policy consultation, EPAC will enlarge our knowledge base. In part, this will be through its basic research activities which will be directed at fundamental problems facing the economy.

As well, it is intended that EPAC will, after it has found its feet, undertake what we have called indicative planning-that is, it will advise on feasible and desirable economic goals and on policies to realise the economy's maximum growth potentialities. The Government considers that it is of considerable value for the nation to try to assess the longer term trends ahead and to seek to influence these trends in a desirable direction.

The council will have seventeen members, including three Commonwealth Ministers and three State government representatives. For this purpose the Northern Territory will be treated on similar terms as the State governments. In addition , one member will be selected in consultation with local government organisations, three in consultation with business, one in consultation with rural industry, four in consultation with trade unions, one in consultation with welfare organisations, and one in consultation with consumer and community groups.

The State government representatives will be nominated by their respective governments. The representation of the States will be arranged on a rotating basis, with rotations every two years. For non-government members, it is the Government's intention that they will, after an initial phasing-in arrangement, serve for four years. The latter will be appointed by the Government after consultation with relevant organisations as set out in the Bill. The non- government members will be selected on the basis of those who are best able to contribute to the work of the council rather than as nominees of organisations.

To discharge its important functions, the council is to be provided with appropriate powers, listed in clauses 7, 8 and 19 and 22 to 24 of the Bill. The council will be able to conduct inquiries and collect information on any aspect of its functions. Clause 7 contains provisions in regard to the publishing of reports. While the clause provides that the Treasurer may refrain from publishing a report or may publish a report with deletions if the Treasurer considers that to do so is necessary to protect the public interest, it is the Government's intention that this power be exercised only if there are overwhelming reasons in the national interest for doing so. The Government remains committed to knowledge sharing with all members of the community.

The council will be able to consult widely with Commonwealth and State bodies and with commercial, industrial, consumer, welfare and other organisations. The council will have powers to engage consultations to conduct studies for it and to arrange with the Commonwealth and State authorities for officers of those authorities to be available to assist the council. The council will also be able to form committees of council members and others, who will conduct investigations on behalf of the council and will report their findings and recommendations to the council. These powers should enable the council to meet its responsibilities adequately.

The legislation gives the council the necessary degree of independence so that its advice can be provided to government freely and without unwarranted influence. Clause 6 of the Bill provides that the council, in deciding which matters it should consider, shall consult with, but shall not be bound by the views of, the Commonwealth Government. The Bill also provides that the Commonwealth members will not vote when the council is deciding on the advice to be given to the Commonwealth Government in a policy report. These provisions will make sure that EPAC's advice is truly at arm's length from government.
Provision is also made for the recording of minority opinions although it is the Government's expectation that, as far as possible, the council will endeavour to find a consensus in its opinions.

Another important area where independence is ensured is in the staffing of EPAC . It is intended that EPAC will be served by professional staff in an independent secretariat. The staffing requirements will be a matter for negotiation with the council when it has been established. The staff are to be employed under the Public Service Act, but clause 22 of the Bill provides specifically that staff members shall perform their functions and duties in accordance with the directions of the council.

The budgetary costs associated with the establishment and running of EPAC, which will mainly reflect the costs of staffing and maintaining the secretariat, will be met in full by the Commonwealth Government.

The foregoing represent the more important purposes of the Bill. There are, in addition, the usual provisions of a Bill of this nature concerning the appointment, terms of office, payment of expenses of council members, and acting members and related matters. The council will meet as necessary to perform its functions. A council member will be required to disclose any interest he may have in any matter under consideration by the council where such an interest would conflict with the proper performance of his functions. Unless the council determines otherwise, such an interest will debar the council member involved from taking part in any decision on the matter in question and from being present at any discussions on that matter.

The Government believes that there is an overwhelming case for establishing an effective economic policy advisory body in Australia as an independent and permanent statutory authority. Nothing less will properly safeguard the status, permanence and stability of EPAC. This Bill provides the necessary safeguards. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill, as outlined by the Treasurer in his Economic Statement, is the initial step in giving effect to our election commitment to take immediate action to create worthwhile employment opportunities, especially for the record number of Australians now unemployed.

The Bill establishes the Community Employment Program with the intention of generating a level of activity in 1983-84 consistent with our objective to provide in a full year, through this program, up to 70,000 full time jobs for an average duration of six months.

In particular, the Community Employment Program will be aimed at those most disadvantaged among the ranks of the unemployed who will be least likely to be assisted by employment growth generated by the general economic recovery which will result from this Government's policies.

The Treasurer's Economic Statement made very clear that Australia's current economic problems are without recent precedent, and that the seriousness of the economic situation imposes very real constraints on the Government. Notwithstanding these difficulties, we were elected with a commitment to create jobs and we are determined to fulfil that commitment.

The need for such action is desirable at a time when Australia has the worst unemployment since the Great Depression. Seven years of the policies of the previous Government have led to an increase in unemployment of almost half a million with the rate of unemployment in April standing at 10.2 per cent or almost three quarters of a million people. Over this period the average duration of unemployment has risen from around 3 months to more than 7 months at the current time.

The social and economic consequences of this explosion in unemployment have been immense and need no elaboration to any concerned member of the Senate. These consequences, however, were virtually ignored by the previous Government. The Fraser Government was elected on a promise to provide jobs for all those wanting work. After more than 7 years its abysmal failure to fulfil this promise is painfully evident.

As the dimensions of its failure became more apparent, the Fraser Government steadfastly refused to accept responsibility for the jobs crisis, but instead sought to shift the blame. Its two most popular scapegoats were wages growth and the international recession. This Government recognises the crucial importance of wage restraint in current economic circumstances, but it is the responsibility of the national government to provide the environment and the leadership to attain appropriate wage outcomes, as this Government has done. The Fraser Government failed utterly in this regard.

The Hawke Government recognises the difficulties posed for domestic economic management by current international circumstances, but it is the responsibility of the national government to meet the international challenge head-on, to implement domestic policies which will foster growth in activity and employment, notwithstanding adverse external influences.

We are adopting positive policies to overcome the legacies left by the previous Government. Part of these policies is our commitment to job creation measures directly aimed at increasing employment opportunities in both the public and private sectors of the economy. Such policies were steadfastly rejected particularly in regard to the public sector by those occupying the other side of the Senate except for the one-year program to sugar coat the Wage Pause. But the need and justification for such policies in the current circumstances cannot be disputed. Most Western governments operate specific employment creation schemes as an integral ingredient of policies to reduce or contain unemployment. Even such a conservative government as the Thatcher Government in the United Kingdom has seen the need to operate specific job programs.
Similarly in Australia political conservatives have at times recognised the value and impact of such programs, as is illustrated by the following quotation:

''In summary I would like to emphasise that by remaining aloof and closing our eyes to job creation schemes, Australia is at variance with accepted practice in most other Western countries. Certainly overseas experience appears to indicate that such programs are worthwhile. Furthermore their merit is even more underlined by the likely continuation of high levels of unemployment in Australia. Most likely there is room for some mixture of private sector wage subsidy schemes and public sector project employment. It would seem that detailed planning, a slow build-up and a large measure of local involvement would ensure a good chance of successful implementation''.

This ringing endorsement of job creation programs came from none other than the Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, in a letter to the former Prime Minister in June last year. Certainly this Government agrees with the Queensland Premier on this issue. Our commitment to job generation has also been endorsed strongly by all groups at the recent National Economic Summit Conference.

This Government will adopt a twofold approach to directly assisting the unemployed through action, first to create jobs and, second, to provide the unemployed with the training needed to fill the jobs which will be created through a sustained economic recovery.

The Community Employment Program along with our housing package are first steps in the process. This Program will involve the Commonwealth Government in constructive partnership with the States, local government and community groups to provide worthwhile and productive jobs in both the public and private sector, on projects of social and economic benefit to the community, for those unemployed Australians hardest hit by the recession in the labour market.

It should be painfully evident to honourable senators that there is a vast amount of such worthwhile and productive work, of social and economic benefit, which needs to be done in Australia at the State, local and community levels and that there are record numbers of unemployed Australians, men and women, who can, and want to, do that work. Our Program will provide the framework and financing to bring forward from all areas within the community projects which will provide such work.

As I have already said, our objective is to generate a level of activity under this Program in 1983-84 consistent with supporting in a full year up to 70,000 full time jobs for an average duration of six months. Up to twice the number of jobs can be expected to be created indirectly by the increased demand for goods and services and the higher incomes resulting from implementing the Program. As a basis for achieving this objective, the Commonwealth Government intends to allocate $300m to the Community Employment Program in 1983-84. Of that amount $ 50m will be set aside for job creation programs through Commonwealth departments and authorities.

The remainder, including the Jobs on Local Roads initiative, under which it is proposed to allocate $70 million to enable local governments to construct and maintain local roads, will be allocated to projects sponsored by State and local governments and community organisations. A sum of $20 milion of this amount will be for project activity involving water supply improvement programs in country towns.

In addition to the allocations to the Community Employment Program the Government will continue to meet commitments under the Wage Pause Program set up by the previous Government. This will add a further $100 million to job creation measures in 1983-84.
Despite reservations about the adequacy of this Program in fully meeting our job creation objectives. It is our view that pre-existing agreements under this Wage Pause Program should be honoured.

Consistent with our election commitment, the Commonwealth under the Community Employment Program will provide the bulk of funds to worthwhile projects to pay for wage and other costs. The Commonwealth will, however, be seeking on a State basis, a contribution of 30 per cent of total costs from project sponsors. This will allow all sectors to make a contribution towards overcoming our unemployment legacy and will mean the creation of a greater number of jobs.

The Commonwealth, though, will remain flexible on this matter. We will be prepared to accept greater contributions towards meeting up to 49 per cent of the cost of projects where such funds are available. On the other hand, we will be prepared to provide up to full funding where a desirable project is in danger of not being able to proceed without such Commonwealth funding.

Funds appropriated under this Program will be allocated among the States and Territories on the basis of population, with the exception of funds allocated to Commonwealth departments and authorities and 40 per cent of the funds allocated to road programs. This 40 per cent portion of road funds will be distributed on the basis of a formula under the Commonwealth Roads Grants Act. Apart from this allocation, priority will be given when approving projects to areas experiencing especially severe unemployment problems.

The Commonwealth will direct and oversight the Program, through the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations but the States and the Northern Territory will be responsible for the administration of the Program within their boundaries, although not of course for those projects conducted by Commonwealth departments and instrumentalities. The Minister will be having early discussions with the States to reach agreement on these administrative arrangements so that the Program can be implemented from July 1983. The Minister is confident that the States will approach these discussions with the urgency and commitment to help the unemployed which this Government has demonstrated by initiating this Program.

Committees comprising Commonwealth and State officials, local government, community organisations and interested groups will be established in each State and Territory to consider projects for approval. They will consult widely in the community as to what type of projects are needed and they will give assistance, where necessary, to interested groups in developing projects. Final project approval will remain with the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations or his nominee.
To be eligible for approval, projects would have to conform to the following guidelines:
projects must be labour intensive, offering work for at least three months and a maximum of one year in the first instance at appropriate minimum award rates;
projects must involve high Australian content; non-Australian content would be limited to 20 per cent of all projects in a State or Territory;
projects will need to involve activities leading to productive output and permanent jobs, or provide services of permanent public and community value;
projects will have to provide worthwhile work experience and/or training opportunities to enable participants to enter the normal workforce; and
projects must also be additional to those planned and would not otherwise have been funded under normal budgetary conditions.

Those eligible for participation must be Commonwealth Employment Service registrants who have been out of work for at least three months, with priority then being given to those who have been unemployed for at least nine months, those who have never worked,-particularly the very disadvantaged of the labour market, such as Aborigines-and those for other reasons in need of immediate employment.
Equal access should be provided for females under the Program, which in some instances may necessitate special measures to ensure that women receive an equal share of the jobs created.
Finally, vacancies for projects funded under the program must be lodged with the Commonwealth Employment Service.

To ensure that the Program makes the most efficient use of resources to meet our objectives, there will, after an initial period of operation, be a joint Commonwealth and State Evaluation conducted by the Bureau of Labour Market Research in conjunction with the States concerned.

These guidelines will be the basis of a more effective and equitable job creation package than that provided by the Wage Pause Program. Like the Wage Pause Program, the Community Employment Program will contain provision for equal access to work by men and women alike and ensure that Aboriginal Australians and other particularly disadvantaged groups are catered for. However, the Community Employment Program, through its giving of priority to those out of work for long periods, and its insistence on adherence to the guidelines, in contrast to what has been the happening under the Wage Pause Program, will be more tightly targeted to those most disadvantaged in the labour market. In addition, the Program's administration will be streamlined and more effective and greater provision will be made for direct involvement of local government and community groups.

The Community Employment Program does not represent the end of our job creation activities. Our election program foreshadowed the introduction of a Private Sector Assistance Program to provide training and employment opportunities in the private sector. We intend to proceed with this Program during 1983-84. As part of the process of introduction of the scheme we will be conducting a broad review of all existing training and assistance programs to ensure that they fully meet the Hawke Government's objectives in this area.

The overall result will be, however, a substantial increase in the Government's commitments to employment and training activities. As the Treasurer has indicated total expenditure in 1983-84 in this area will be $733m-an increase of 110% on the funds provided on these crucial programs during 1982-83.

This figure is clear evidence of the Government's commitment to provide greater job opportunities for all Australians. The Community Employment Program is the first step towards fulfilling that commitment. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill provides for an amendment to the Wheat Marketing Act 1979 to give effect to decisions taken by the Government in the context of its expenditure review.

The effect of the amendment will be to terminate from 1 July 1983 the scheme whereby the Australian Wheat Board is reimbursed for the additional costs involved in borrowing from the domestic capital market compared with the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank. The scheme was introduced to compensate the Board for the Government's decision to compel it to borrow from the higher cost domestic market.
The Bill therefore provides that from 1 July 1983 there will be no liability for the Commonwealth to make any payments under the scheme.

In consideration of the termination of the scheme, the Government will seek the approval of Loan Council to permit the Board to borrow overseas in 1983-84 and subsequent years subject to the following conditions. The Board would be free to borrow 50 per cent of its prospective net borrowing requirements overseas but would require the agreement of the Treasurer and myself to borrow more than 50 per cent from overseas sources. The criteria for our approval in the latter case will take into account both the prospective monetary situation on the one hand and the prospective borrowing requirements and borrowing costs of the Wheat Board on the other. Within the annual limit the Board would be free to determine the currencies, timing, size and term of individual borrowings subject to it giving the Government prior notification of the size and timing of borrowings.
The Bill therefore also provides for the Board's powers in relation to borrowing and the issue of securities, to be exercisable both within and outside Australia.

These new arrangements should enable the Board to borrow from lower cost markets such that there should be no increase in the cost of borrowing to the Board from the termination of the interest subsidy. Not only are current interest rates generally lower overseas but as wheat is often traded in foreign currencies the Board would be able to hedge the risks of currency fluctuations by borrowing in the same currencies in which it makes sales. I am sure that the Board and wheat growers would welcome the increase in commercial freedom of the Board.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 25 May 1983.
Proposed new Part VIIA.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Proposed new clause 77A, definition of 'complaint', paragraph (a), leave out 'unjust or unfair', insert 'inaccurate, unfair or biased'.
(2) Proposed new clause 77A, definition of 'complaint', paragraph (b), at end of paragraph, add '(whether or not the matter so obtained was included in the program)'.
(3) Proposed new clause 77A, definition of 'complaint', at end of definition, add the following new paragraph:
'(d) that the program was otherwise offensive'.
(4) Proposed new clause 77A, definition of 'person affected', leave out the definition.
(5) Proposed new clause 77D, sub-clause (1), leave out 'affected', insert ' making the complaint'.
(6) Proposed new clause 77D, sub-clauses (2) and (3), leave out the sub-clauses , insert the following new sub-clause:
'(2) The complaint may be made by an individual, or by a body of persons, whether incorporated or not.'.
(7) Proposed new clause 77E, leave out the proposed clause.
(8) Proposed new clause 77F, sub-clause (1), leave out 'Subject to section 77E, '.
(9) Proposed new clause 77F, sub-clause (4), paragraph (c), leave out 'the person affected or'.

The purpose of these amendments is to incorporate in the Opposition's amendment the principles that I outlined during the second reading debate. In my view, at least some of them ought to be accepted if the point of view that was expressed by Senator Martin last night is valid. I consider that the matters which Senator Martin outlined to the Committee last night are valid. The complaints of people under the circumstances outlined by the honourable senator should receive proper attention by the Australian Broadcasting Commission. The allegation was that the matter raised in a Four Corners program was unfair to the complainant. The allegation also was that the matter was an error of fact. It could be said that the community affairs officer would be required to deal with errors of fact under the current legislation.

I take the point that has been made by the Government that people ought to have the right to feel that their complaints are being adequately dealt with by an independent tribunal. As I understand it, that was the attitude of the Australian Democrats last year. Of course, that has been detailed to the Committee by Senator Baume in moving his proposition. It is my view that that ought to apply as well because, over the years, the ABC has tended to become bureaucratic and a law unto itself. My amendment to the proposition would ensure that the complaint was about matters that are considered by the complainant to be 'inaccurate, unfair or biased'. Clearly, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Board has a duty to ensure that its programs are accurate and impartial.

Clause 8 on page 6 of the Bill relates to the duties of the Board. The Government, in detailing the guidelines for complaints, has picked up only the accuracy part of the duties of the Board. It has not picked up the impartial part of the duties. In fact, on the one hand, clause 8 refers to the duties of the Board which require the Board to ensure that information is accurate and impartial. On the other hand, the Government, in the same piece of legislation, when it comes to testing the Board about whether it is carrying out those functions, will apply only one test, and that is the test of accuracy. There is another matter which is quite distinct altogether and that is the invasion of property. What I am trying to pick up and what I believe the Opposition really is trying to pick up is the question of impartiality. Therefore, I am proposing to amend the Opposition's amendment so as to include the words 'inaccurate, unfair or biased'.

The second amendment is to proposed new clause 77A, which relates to the definition of 'complaint'. I feel that the Opposition's amendment does not pick up what is now in the Government's Bill. Clearly, if there is an invasion of privacy the complaint should relate to actions taken by the ABC regardless of ' whether or not the matter so obtained was included in the program'. I seek to make that amendment to the Opposition's amendment. I hope the Opposition will agree with that as well. My third amendment is also to proposed new clause 77A. It seeks to add a paragraph to the definition of 'complaint'. My amendment is that the proposed new clause should include the words:
(d) that the program was otherwise offensive.

If the Opposition's amendments are not carried I will also be proposing that amendment to the Government's Bill. My fourth amendment is complementary to the fifth amendment. It is, of course, also complementary to the sixth. The amendments propose that 'the complaint may be made by an individual, or by a body of persons, whether incorporated or not'. The other three propositions flow from the statements that I made in the second reading debate or which I believe I have made elsewhere. Rather than delay the Committee, I commend those propositions to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that Senator Harradine's amendments fall into two groups which are really quite separate. The purpose of the first group is to cover the definition of 'complaint' and the second group is to alter the question of who shall have standing. Senator Harradine might correct me if I am wrong, but I think that the second group of amendments seeks to widen quite markedly the group of people who might make a complaint. Is my understanding correct?
—Yes.

—As a matter of principle, we had chosen to stay as close as we could to the British model so that the point we were making and the comparison we were drawing with what the Australian Democrats proposed last year remained perfectly valid. We are not happy to move away from the British model to the extent of altering who should have standing. A number of Senator Harradine's amendments-I think amendments Nos 2 through 9-actually bear upon the question of who can make a complaint and the fact that people can make complaints about programs in which they may not have been involved. We would not be disposed to agree with those amendments. I come back to Senator Harradine's first amendment in which he is concerned about the definition of 'complaint'. I think the honourable senator makes a point there which has a considerable amount of substance. He wants to add the words 'inaccurate' and 'bias'. He wants to make a slight rearrangement to the words there. I can see no reason why that would not be acceptable. It seems to me perfectly appropriate that those words should be included in that way. I indicate that the Opposition agrees to the first of Senator Harradine's amendments. I wonder whether we are incorrect in thinking that the remainder really form a block of amendments.
—No, they do not.

—The honourable senator might care to separate the groupings for us. I will yield to him again in a moment. If he can indicate which of those amendments actually refer to giving a wider capacity for standing for a complaint, I can then indicate the Opposition's view.
—My amendments Nos 1 to 3 relate to what constitutes a complaint. Amendments Nos 4 to 9 effectively relate to the locus standi. That is it in simple terms.

—The Opposition thinks that the first amendment is one with which it can agree. We find that the second and third amendments may be a bit too difficult or too broad. The honourable senator is quite correct; they relate to the type of complaint. The view we have taken is that unless compelling arguments were advanced we would not support amendments Nos 2 and 3.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The compelling argument is simply this: If the Government agrees to place something in the Bill, why not pick it up? My amendment No. 2 simply proposes an amendment to the Opposition's new clause 77A. The definition of 'complaint' is contained in clause 77B.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's amendment provides that:
'complaint', in relation to a program means a complaint as to any one or more of the following matters:
(b) that an unwarranted intrusion into the privacy of a person took place in the course of obtaining matter for inclusion in the program;

All I am suggesting is that we add the words 'whether or not the matter so obtained was included in the program'. As I understand it, that is contained in the Government's proposition. My proposition is that if there has been an invasion of privacy a complaint against the actions of the Australian Broadcasting Commission is proper whether or not the matters have been referred to in a television or radio program. It is clear that there is either an invasion of privacy or there is not. For example, there could well be an invasion of privacy in the collection of material. Whether that material is used on a program is immaterial; an invasion of privacy has taken place. As I understand the Government's legislation, community affairs officers would be required to deal with that sort of invasion of privacy. Perhaps the Minister will enlighten me.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clause 82 (1) (b).
—That is right. I thank Senator Chipp. That is quite clear. Clause 82 (1) (b) states:

SPEECH.PARA: that an invasion of privacy has occurred in, or in connection with the preparation of, a program, announcement or other matter broadcast or televised by the Corporation.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will accept your amendment No. 2.

—That must have been a compelling argument. I am now compelled to put the other argument to see whether we can get acceptance of my third amendment. Clearly, I accept that persons have the right to complain to the ABC about program standards where they do not have a 'sufficient interest', in the narrow definition of that phrase. Where they do not have that sufficient interest this amendment provides them with the opportunity to make a complaint. If there are excessive numbers of complaints about a particular matter, excessive in that it is unduly burdensome on the complaints tribunal to answer all the complaints individually, it would do so, presumably, by way of some sort of broadcast. As to a program that is otherwise offensive, I believe that if we have a complaints tribunal as has been suggested by the Opposition, or if community affairs officers receive complaints, the public will expect that that tribunal or those persons will receive complaints. I do not think that the public will see the niceties of the situation described by Senator Button. I do not think it will say that complaints have to go through the complaints tribunal or the community affairs officers. Why can these people not receive the complaints that I mentioned?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am impressed to some extent by some of the arguments put forward by Senator Harradine. But, as Senator Button explained, to insert these amendments into legislation at this time, particularly those conditions concerning standards, and to broaden the scope of the activities of the tribunal, as the Opposition would want to call it, or the community affairs officers as stated in the legislation, would in the Government's mind-and I suspect it is right-cause such a welter of complaints and material at the outset as to make the system unworkable. The Government might be wrong but at least we have an undertaking from it that this matter will be reviewed at an early opportunity once the corporation is set up and is working.

SPEECH.PARA: I say with great respect and without giving offence that the argument on amendments to the Opposition's amendment is rather academic at this stage. It is a fascinating debate, and I am interested in all that is being said because the Government and the Democrats will not accept the Opposition's amendment. Debate on the Opposition's amendment is a good debate going to waste. I would prefer the very sensible comments of Senator Harradine to be directed to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill proper. I think we could save time. The reason why the Democrats will not accept the amendment, as I said before and will say again -Senator Peter Baume, Senator Harradine and Senator Sir John Carrick were quite right last night in saying this-is that the Democrats would prefer a complaints commissioner, an independent body. There is no question about that. With great respect-and I do not think those honourable senators meant any mischief by those remarks-all of them omitted the vital part of the Democrats' proposition, that is, that that complaints commissioner should not be appointed by the Government but should be appointed and approved by both Houses of the Parliament. There is a world of difference. Senator Sir John Carrick, with great respect for his years of experience, mildly and in a good manner rebuked us by saying that if a judge is appointed everything will be all right. That argument contends that a judge is beyond reproach and beyond suspicion and is totally objective--

TALK.START.PARA: —He believes that.

—I am sure he does. I respect him for his views, but I hope he respects me for mine when I say that I absolutely disagree with that view. I do not think there is anything sacred about judges. I could point to a few--
—Or ombudsmen?
—Or ombudsmen, indeed.
—Governments appoint ombudsmen for exactly this purpose .

—The fact that there has been a practice in some areas does not mean to say that we have to compound those practices with the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Of course governments make these appointments. I would prefer, and the Democrats would prefer, for those kinds of appointments to be approved by both Houses of Parliament. But the Opposition clearly, right from the outset, said that it would not accept that part of the Democrats' proposition. Opposition senators are entitled to do that. Having done that, the Democrats have to address themselves to the question of which of the two worlds we would prefer-an independent complaints commissioner who is capable of being appointed by a government or the present system in which at least we have filters, checks and balances built into the system. The Government has accepted Democrat amendments for the community affairs offices to be recommended by the advisory councils. At least we have a checks and balances system in regard to pure stooges being directly appointed by the Government. Therefore, I must say that we will oppose the Opposition's amendment and Senator Harradine's amendments to the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a couple of points, and I shall do so quite objectively. Senator Chipp said that there may be no merit in a debate on issues in which it is clear that some amendments will not be carried. I put to him and to the Committee that this debate goes well beyond what will happen initially as a result of this Bill. Great philosophical questions must be asked and attempted to be answered in this journey. It is not good enough, for example, to use the argument which Senator Chipp used. I have not heard the Government use it, but Senator Chipp, and I respect what he says, argues that the Government says that if one took the course advocated by Senator Harradine there would be too many complaints to handle. If that is the question to be directed, it is entirely the wrong end of the telescope. The real question is not whether there would be too may complaints but whether there is a sufficiency mechanism to allow valid complaints, however many, to be dealt with. We are not looking at the question of whether a bureaucracy would be bogged down . We are looking at a citizenry which has the right to make complaints. That is a primary situation.
—The only situation.

—The only situation. It is inherent in what Senator Harradine is saying, although as Senator Baume says, the Opposition will stick primarily to its amendments because they are as close to the British Broadcasting Corporation situation as possible and very much what the Australian Democrats advocate.
—Come on, state our position clearly. I plead with you. Do it fairly.
—I would be very happy to do that.
—The difference is acknowledged.
—He doesn't acknowledge it.
—What am I not acknowledging?
—That there is a fundamental difference between what the Democrats put and what you're saying.

—As I understand it, the only difference is how the chairman of a totally independent commission, divorced entirely from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, shall be appointed: As I understand it, what the Democrats are doing today is putting aside that principle entirely and supporting with some amendments the concept of a complaints officer in the Corporation, responsible to it for his salary, his term of appointment and conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: I direct myself to that aspect. How can such a person do that job? What will be the level of his salary? Shall he have officers senior to him in the Broadcasting Corporation? Will he be junior, perhaps considerably junior, to the Managing Director? How can there be any objectivity? With the greatest respect, I suggest that the device of using an advisory council to recommend his appointment is simply an incestuous device. Who appoints the advisory council? The test should surely have been heavily upon us. In recent weeks we have seen, arising out of a contretemps in the Senate, all sorts of allegations of pressure and duress on the Australian Broadcasting Commission, all sorts of revelations that complaints had been made privately. Indeed, there had to be a digging and a delving to bring out the nature of those complaints and a judgment made as to whether certain people were attempting to use duress, whether they had done things properly, whether there was a right for management to handle the disciplining of officers or whether a commission should do all these fundamental things.

One thing became abundantly clear, that is, that in no way at all could a complaints commission function properly if it were incestuous. If the complaints commission were in the Broadcasting Corporation, quite clearly, all the events of the past could happen again. There would be no way in the world of getting away from the bad old days. I have pleaded and made it perfectly clear that the worst of all worlds would be if there were any danger to anybody, a public figure or not, in criticising the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Today if we criticise the ABC, our opposition will say that we are using threats and duress on it.

The element of duress will also arise if letters are sent to a complaints officer who is a member of the staff. What will he do if a Government member sends him a letter? Of course he will say to himself: 'Here is a situation involving a Government member'. The implication of duress will be there. I cannot believe that anybody-Australian Democrats, Independents or others-having gone through the journey of recent weeks could possibly say that whatever device we use, whether it be advisory council recommendations or not, we should have a complaints officer who is subject to the terms and conditions of appointment set by management and who is a member of staff of the very corporation that is the subject of complaint.

I drew a parallel to this situation when I spoke before. In this place we have regarded it as very healthy to expose a variety of corporations, primary industry corporations and others, to scrutiny. We have said that they ought to be the subject of the crucible of exposure. They ought to be examined. They are stronger for it and better protected for it. In what area could this be more important than in the national broadcasting system? How can we do it unless we separate the complaints process from the people against whom the complaints are made.

I have referred to a situation that has occurred in virtually every State in Australia. The citizenry of the States have rejected the idea that the police force can hear appeals by the public against individual policemen and their actions. Nobody really believes that that kind of situation is a good and sensible one. The worst of all worlds is that it does not protect the integrity of the police force. It suggests that it has something to hide. It puts a taint, a defect, on all the people who are concerned, whereas that taint is not deserved.

TALK.START.PARA: —It compromises them.

—Yes. Why do we do this when we have a simple opportunity to rectify the situation? The British have tested a complaints commission and found it to be a sensible thing. It is no good saying to me: ' Senator Carrick has faith in judges'. Senator Chipp does not have that faith. Therefore he must not have faith in any royal commissioner we appoint.
—Some.

—Some. The essence of the structure of our democracy is the separation of the Executive, the Parliament and the judiciary. If we do not believe in both the independence and the integrity of the judiciary we are in a bad way indeed, we are seeing evil under every bed.
—Not everyone.

—There is no way in the world of devising a perfect system. Senator Chipp says: 'Let us have a parliamentary system for doing that'. Are parliamentarians less fallible than judges? Are they more likely to reach an objective conclusion than a judge is? In any judgment the majority would prevail . The Government of the day would make sure that it had the numbers. The very nature of a parliamentary system is the pressure of numbers. We operate under a majority system. How could that be more objective than a person who is selected because, in the public judgment, he or she has both the integrity and sufficient ability to carry out the job. When we look at these arguments we see that they demolish around us. We are dealing with a fundamental. We are dealing with a failure to understand who is the master and who is the servant in this situation .
—The Parliament is the master. That is something you have never understood.

—I have understood it. The reason I am here is that I am the servant of that principle. The Parliament is the servant of the people. Honourable senators should understand that the Parliament is not the master at all; it is the servant of the people.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me state fundamentally what this matter is about. We are setting up a statutory corporation, not as an end in itself, not as a goal, but as a means to an end-a means to serve the whole community and to reflect value judgments, the standards and the moral and ethical judgments of the community. It is no good the Government telling me that it cannot devise these things in law. The Government will do that willingly if it wants to. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation is an instrument which is there to serve and reflect the views of the community. Its very charter says that it is there to reflect the views of the community. As I have said, it is given independence not as an end in itself but as a means of accepting the responsibility of being objective. That is what independence is about. It should not have freedom of licence or take liberties, on the contrary, the test is: Will it live up to the responsibility that it has been given? It is no good saying: 'Look at all those lovely words in the charter '. The public must be able to make a fundamental acid test. The members of the public should be able to say: 'There is your charter. Let us test it'. They should be able to test it as widely as possible. It is nonsense to say: 'If we did this there would be too many inquiries. We cannot handle them'. Again, that is letting the bureaucracy make the judgment and not the people. The only question is the validity of the inquiry-the right of people to have their say.

Fundamentally, we are not looking at a question of someone losing or winning when a vote is taken today. If we decide today to continue with a system that, in the past, produced the very unpleasant circumstances that were triggered off in the exchanges between Senator Button and Professor Leonie Kramer; if we continue with the same system where a leader of a political party of whatever colour and a senior member of a government of whatever colour can suggest that there has been unfairness and suggest-however unfairly perhaps-that there has been duress--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not available to the ordinary citizen.

—This avenue is not open to ordinary people at all. It is like saying: 'Come and see me in my office and I will tell you privately what it is all about'. Honourable senators will remember this interesting situation. We are now looking at a system that will entrench that very situation where a Minister can say: 'Come and see me in my office. I will not tell you here what in fact I have against the Chairman of the ABC but if you come and see me privately I will'. Having had second thoughts the next day we then get the statement: 'I will get around this. I will not say it in here. I will write her a letter and put the onus on the person attacked to decide whether to expose the reasons'. That is the kind of situation that we have. That system will continue unless the Australian Democrats are willing to break the placental tie, unless they are willing to establish a completely independent complaints commission.
—They were last year.
—They were last year. The onus is heavily upon them today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to deal firstly with the question of whether the recipient of complaints should be a member of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation or an independent person. It is a very sad indictment of today's community that people believe most of what they read in and hear on the media. It plays a vital role and has enormous effect and influence upon and within the community generally. It is imperative that there is a proper balance and proper fairness. Very sadly and inevitably people are judged guilty just by the very fact that their names are mentioned or linked with the suggestion of impropriety. I find it very sad that people, by and large in the community do not await the final outcome before concluding that a person is guilty until he can prove himself innocent. We have all seen in recent years how many people have been judged guilty by the media and in no other way.

SPEECH.PARA: It is vitally important that there should be a proper mechanism of a complaints commission that not only properly resolves the questions of complaints but also certainly gives the Australian Broadcasting Commission an incentive to ensure there are as few complaints as possible. It is without question that if there is an employee of the Commission-a person to whom complaints shall flow and who will determine the outcome-inevitably there will be some bias and colouring. There will be public perception of no impartiality or no independence. Of course , there will not be independence because that person will be an employee of the group about whom the complaints are being lodged. He will be part of the establishment, part of the system, part of the comradeship, part of the club and part of the team about which the complaints are being made.

It seems to me a poor analogy to suggest that if a complaint is made against a footballer his coach should sit on the tribunal; to say the least it certainly would not be seen to be the right thing. It is like Caesar's wife. In these situations I am sure it is important that fairness is seen to be fair. The proposition of having the appointment approved by both Houses of Parliament does not have a great deal of merit either because invariably the judgment will be made by one party that the other party is putting up somebody of their colour and persuasion because they can expect the same from the other side. Unfortunately--

TALK.START.PARA: —Both Houses of Parliament.

—Well, there are two parties in both Houses. It is an unfortunate quirk of fate that three parties are represented here for the moment . Invariably one finds that both political parties will be tempted to balance the scales, at least as they see it, by appointing somebody on their side at least if it is only to be taking out--
—So you want to get into the Government.

—Yes. I would rather all the sins be visited on the people who make the appointments. As I said last night, they will be judged by the community. They will be judged in the ballot box by the voters. Nothing can be achieved by having two parties compounding the sin. At least if there is one party they carry all the responsibility.
—We are trying to avoid the sin, not compound it.
—If the honourable senator listens very carefully without interrupting--
—I have been.

—The honourable senator cannot be listening and talking at the same time, unless he has a facility which he has not demonstrated so far. If two political parties are making judgments, inevitably either side will be taking out a bit of insurance and appointing somebody who will be seen to be countering the appointment of the other side. At present the ABC is not intimidated by complaints. My view is that from the modest experience I have had of lodging complaints with the ABC I have received very little satisfaction. I am no Robinson Crusoe about that.
—That is an argument for the Government.

—I do not follow the honourable senator's logic. Perhaps he might save his comments for his own speech. I am sure the great majority of people in the community have a sense of unease about the ABC's treatment of their complaints. In fact, the matter was raised before the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs recently because of a story run I think on Nationwide or Four Corners-I do not recall which-regarding a Perth technical school. I think it arose as a result of a report by some students. The program was televised. The principal of the school was subsequently called upon by the producers of the program to make some observations of his own. Under ministerial direction and instruction, he declined to do so. He told the producers of that direction at the time. However, they insisted that the program would be televised. During the program the point was made that he was indifferent, did not care and had, of his own volition, declined to make any comment. He then complained to the ABC and received no satisfaction whatsoever. He asked for nothing more than a retraction. That was not forthcoming, so he went to Professor Richardson, the Commonwealth Ombudsman. The Ombudsman took up the matter with the ABC. Naturally, it felt completely immune from any sort of criticism. In fact, it was prepared to take the matter to the High Court of Australia in order to challenge the Ombudsman's jurisdiction over the ABC. The Ombudsman's observation was that the ABC treated him, his position and authority with a great deal of contempt. This demonstrates that so long as the ABC is secure in the knowledge that it will be the ultimate arbitrator of complaints lodged against it, no one will receive a fair hearing of complaints. It seems to me that the appointment of an officer ought to be along the lines suggested by the Opposition. To suggest there is something wrong in the Parliament appointing a judge does not seem to be a fair observation. All governments appoint to the positions of ombudsman, royal commissioners and judges, people whom they perceive to be persons of integrity and capacity. Under the proposals put forward in our amendment, they will be able to report to the Parliament. That, in itself, insulates them from any suggestion of bias one way or the other, because their activities are exposed to the community and to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: In general terms I support the amendments numbered (1) to (3) that have been put forward by Senator Harradine. I am pleased that the Opposition accepts them. One of the greatest complaints made against the ABC is not necessarily its inaccuracy-

TALK.START.PARA: —We accept amendments (1) and (2).

—I hope that the Opposition will also accept the third amendment because it seems to have the same thrust as the Opposition's amendment . The greatest complaint made against the ABC on most occasions is that of bias. I am glad that that word, along with the words 'inaccurate and unfair' are contained in Senator Harradine's proposal. It is almost the same wording as we proposed. As Senator Harradine has said in respect of the second matter, there seems to be no material consequence whether information that has been obtained by unwarranted intrusion of privacy is used on a program. I am glad that that point has been accepted also. Proposed paragraph (d) states:

SPEECH.PARA: that the program was otherwise offensive.

I cannot see any objection to that paragraph. I cannot see why paragraph (d) cannot be included also, when definitions are able to be drawn with respect to obscenity and all sorts of other matters. I hope that Senator Peter Baume will reconsider that point unless he can tell me why it should not be included.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I see some merit in some of Senator Harradine's amendments to the Opposition amendment. Of course, as the Government will oppose the Opposition's amendment, I will not comment on them at this stage. I simply say that, in the course of looking at this matter, a number of solutions have been suggested by all parties. The Government was concerned to provide a solution which was relatively simple and relatively low key and which provided a quick remedy for those who are aggrieved by a particular Australian Broadcasting Commission program in the area of untruth, which is the principle area of concern or, in the area of invasion of privacy. For example, Senator Harradine made a very good point in his amendment to the Opposition's amendment in relation to invasion of privacy. I would submit, and I think Senator Harradine would agree, that the proposition in the Bill relating to that is far preferable to the proposition in the Opposition's amendment. I take it that Senator Baume may accept that fact.
—That is amendment (2). We accept amendment (2) moved by Senator Harradine, on the same grounds; that is, that it makes a lot of sense.
—Senator Harradine's proposition is an improvement on the Opposition's amendment, if I might say so, because I think it covers the situation where privacy might be invaded and no program goes to air.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say one or two things again about the general issue in relation to the complaints tribunal. Senator Sir John Carrick, in contributing to this debate, referred to the journey of recent weeks which we have been through. Of course, this legislation is designed to rectify the journey of recent years. I simply make the general point about the complaints procedure that the ABC is now 50 years old. Liberal-National or Liberal-Country Party governments have been in office for, I think 36 of those 50 years of the history of the ABC. Not once in those 36 years has concern been expressed about the necessity for a complaints mechanism in relation to the ABC. In not one of those 36 years, until last year, has any concern been expressed about this matter. I find it extraordinarily strange that Senator Sir John Carrick should suddenly have developed this passionate concern.

On this question we as a government say that certainly there may not be a perfect solution. We do not suggest that the Government solution is a perfect one. We have indicated that, after looking at how the complaints procedure operates, we would be amenable to further suggestions about how it might be developed. But we as a government do not want to create, after all these years of neglect of this issue, an enormous sort of superstructure which would be responsible for supervising, as it were, the ABC in respect of all its activities. That is what would be involved if Senator Harradine's proposition amending the Opposition's proposition about program standards was taken up.

I might illustrate the difficulties we all face in this sort of matter in trying to arrive at a solution by referring to Senator Sir John Carrick's speech . He says that the Opposition's proposition would involve a judicial appointment . That is extraordinary. That is an interesting view from the back bench of the Liberal Party in this chamber. Not once in the House of Representatives was the suggestion made that there should be a judicial appointment to the complaints tribunal which is suggested by the Opposition. Not once did the shadow Minister for Communications in the Senate suggest that it should be a judicial appointment. But Senator Sir John Carrick, in his usual juristic way, invented the idea of a judicial appointment in order to give greater credibility to a proposition which is not really credible and which does not stand in its own right. That is the position of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —By using that analogy, you do not do him justice; you really don't.

—I think I do because that is what he said. He made a lot of play about the fact that when dealing with a totally different matter Britain appointed a retired Lord Chief Justice to a position on the tribunal. Of course, we could do that in Australia. We could appoint Sir Garfield Barwick or Sir John Kerr. They are the only people available in Australia who fall into that illustrious category. One is a retired Chief Justice of New South Wales and the other is a retired Chief Justice of Australia. But that is precisely the sort of thing the Government is trying to avoid. We want the complaints procedure to be simple and practical. I quite agree with some of Senator Sir John Carrick's criticisms in the sense that they were constructive. He suggested that perhaps the mechanism could be improved by creating greater independence for the community affairs officers, although I would draw his attention to the fact that the Bill provides for community affairs officers in the States. It is quite clear that they could be appointed from outside the Corporation, although they would, of course, be on the Corporation's payroll. The Government is merely saying that it wants a complaints procedure to be available for the first time in the history of the ABC in relation to two particular matters, untruth and the invasion of privacy, which we take to be the most important matters with which people are concerned. This procedure will enable a quick remedy.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Martin, in the course of her contribution to this debate, drew an illustration from Queensland. The remedy offered by the Government in this legislation would be the most appropriate remedy one could find. The aggrieved person in the example given by Senator Martin could have gone straight to the ABC and said: 'These things which have been said about me are untrue'. Because of this expeditious procedure which we have suggested, the ABC would be required under the provisions of the legislation to issue on ABC programs a statement saying: 'Yes, what we said about this person was untrue'. There is no better or quicker remedy than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —How expeditious would it be?

—I do not know. It would certainly be more expeditious than this cumbersome structure which the Opposition envisages and which, of course, is quite outside the province of the Australian Broadcasting Commission itself. In our view the suggestion which comes from the Opposition has a fatal flaw in that the appointment to this very sensitive position would be made by government. In spite of all the protestations that have been made from the other side, in a number of ways-in terms of appointments to the Corporation and or removing some sections of the old legislation which militate against the independence of the Corporation-we are trying in this legislation to create an ABC which is more independent of the political process than it has been in the past. It is very sad to us that the Opposition seems reluctant to agree with the desirability of that process. Indeed, the second reading amendment moved by the Opposition was the most classic example of misunderstanding the true nature of this legislation . It is a total misunderstanding to say: 'Let us adjourn it all because Neville Wran has a libel action against the ABC.' While we see some merit in some of Senator Harradine's amendments to the Opposition's amendments, the Government will not accept them for the reasons which have been outlined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address a question to Senator Button. He said that the fatal flaw in the Opposition's amendment is that the complaints commissioner would be appointed by the Government. Does that mean that there would be some lack of objectivity if it were an appointment by the Government? If so, is there not such a fatal flaw in the appointment of a royal commissioner or anybody else by the Government? Since he chose to find some whimsy in saying that Sir Garfield Barwick or Sir John Kerr might not be suitable people, has he noticed a report in this morning's Press that the British people felt that Sir Zelman Cowen, a former Governor-General and also a distinguished lawyer, was the right person to head the British Press Council? This is a body in which the role of ombudsman displaying objectivity is regarded very highly, in which there is something of a parallel to this matter. What is the fatal flaw? Each time that the Government makes an appointment from now on, are we allowed to say: 'There is a fatal flaw in what you have done, you have subjectively intruded a government influence'? If we cannot say this, why not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —The reference to Sir Zelman Cowen being appointed Chairman of the Press Council in Britain illustrates the silliness of the whole argument advanced by Senator Sir John Carrick. I do not wish to make any comment about Sir Zelman Cowen. I think he is widely recognised as a distinguished jurist and a great Australian. There is no question about that. We are trying in this legislation to de-politicise the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. That is what we are talking about, and that is something which Liberal-National Party governments, for 36 out of the last 50 years never did. I do not want to go into the sorts of appointments that the former Government made to the Board of the Australian Broadcasting Commission but I tell honourable senators opposite this: It was agreed by Ministers for Communications in the previous Government that over the last five or six years that Government had done a pretty poor job in this regard. That is precisely why the former Government had to have the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and it is precisely why this legislation is before the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: We want to de-politicise the activities of the Australian Broadcasting Commission in the sense of taking it out of the partisan political process. There can be no more sensitive appointment as it is susceptible to political pressure or the allegation of political pressure-to this organisation than the appointment of a complaints officer, or whatever he might be called, with the powers that are envisaged in this amendment. We say that as part of that process the government of the day should have nothing to do with that appointment. That is the point which I am trying to get over and which I think has eluded Senator Sir John Carrick, for all his experience in politics, and probably still does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask some further questions to clarify this matter. Will the members of the Board of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation be political appointments and therefore by some strange means depoliticise the Board? Will those members who are political appointees appoint the managing director and therefore--
—Have you read the Bill?
—Yes, I have.
—Well, that is an absurd question, with great respect.

—May I ask the question? I do not intervene when Senator Chipp asks questions, many of which I happen to disagree with. I am probing at the fundamentals. What will be the test of objectivity? If, in fact, the appointments to the Board are capable of being influenced, if the Board appoints the general manager, and the general manager has influence over the complaints commissioner, where does objectivity lie?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not live in a perfect world. Senator Chipp asked Senator Sir John Carrick, by way of interjection, whether he had read the Bill. If he had read the Bill he would know the answer to the question. The Government is to appoint the Board. But let me make a qualification, something which Senator Sir John Carrick has never done in government. The qualification is simply that there is a clause in this Bill which deals with the criteria under which members of the Board will be appointed .
