They are important criteria in considering the board of a corporation. The Government will make appointments in accordance with those criteria. This will be the first time that there have been criteria of that kind. Not only will the Government make appointments in accordance with those criteria but also the Opposition will be asked to consider the names suggested by the Government.
—That has never happened before.

—Of course it has never happened before, because the ABC was regarded by Liberal Party governments as a sort of bunyip House of Lords to which people were appointed as a reward for political services to the Liberal Party. But that will not happen in the future, we hope.
—Do you include the Chairman in that description?
—No.
—And Laurie Short, the Deputy Chairman and a few others ?
—No.
—Well, whom do you include when you say that? Whom are you referring to? Now, come on! Whom are you referring to? You said everyone else isn't included.

—Let us not get excited about individuals. Let me just say this: In making appointments the Government will consult with the Opposition, if the Opposition wants to avail itself of that process of consultation, as to whether the people whom the Government proposes to appoint meet those criteria. That process has never happened in the past in Australia. I should have thought that somebody who expresses great concern about the independence and so on of the Australian Broadcasting Commission as Senator Sir John Carrick has, would welcome that process because, as I said, it has never happened before. It is important that we make these sorts of changes. We are trying to introduce into the whole approach to the Australian Broadcasting Commission some of the sophistication, if I might use that expression, which has applied in Britain over many years in connection with the British Broadcasting Corporation. It has to be a slow process. But that is what we are trying to do. There is always consultation between the Government of the day and the Opposition of the day about the--
—They have an independent complaints tribunal.
—That matter has nothing to do with appointments, nothing at all.
—It really has.

—I resent some of these desperate throws. That matter has nothing to do with appointments. It has never happened in Australia that the government of the day consults with the Opposition about appointments to the Board of the ABC. The difficult problem we have is that the conservatives in Britain are relatively cultured and enlightened people, and that is something, sadly, which is not being shown here and that is a problem we have to get over.
—That is quite gratuitous, Senator. It is quite gratuitous and unfair.
—It is quite true, too.
—That is insulting to the Chairman.
—I am not talking about the Chairman; I am talking about Senator Sir John Carrick. That is a problem which we have had in Australia over many years and we are trying to change that sort of approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several points raised by Senator Button I think need a response. It is ridiculous to say one can depoliticise the appointments. One moves them to a different arena for resolution. Senator Button may say that they could be moved out of the hands of one group, but they are still appointments which require choices to be made; they are appointments of authority and power. Let people be under no illusions. We are altering the locus of the conflict from one place to another. We are trying to make sure that the process will be reasonable. Let us not pretend that appointments that were made to the Australian Broadcasting Commission--
—Do you know what you just said? You said it is impossible to depoliticise the appointments. Do you believe that?

—It depends on what one means by the word 'politicise'. Senator Button was talking about depoliticising appointments. It depends on one' s definition of 'political'. I think Senator Chipp understands the point I am trying to make. It is ridiculous to pretend that what has happened over the years has been something for which former governments of my persuasion ought to be criticised. We have had governments of several persuasions. Senator Chipp was a member of a government for a number of years, and he was party to appointments to the board of the ABC.
—Never.
—He was a member of a Cabinet and a Ministry. He carried the same responsibility as I did as a member of a Ministry. Is Senator Button criticising all those past appointments?
—Or those of the Whitlam Government?
—That is the point.
—Or the Chifley Government?
—Or the Scullin Government or any other government, although perhaps the Scullin Government may have gone back more than 50 years.
—Certainly the Whitlam Government.

—The Whitlam Government, certainly. Yes, there is a process of consultation. I noticed in the paper this morning that the names of Opposition representatives have actually been released. Apparently there has been some communication by Mr Peacock as to who they are to be.
—You are one of them.

—That was stated in the paper so I suppose I am. I know only what I read in the paper. I say to Senator Harradine, in relation to this third amendment, that it seems to me that the people who might be picked up under his third amendment on grounds of general offensiveness of programs still have the capacity to complain to the Australian Broadcasting Commission that they always have had. One can always complain. What Senator Harradine is seeking is not that they should be able to complain, because they can make complaints now, but that they should be able to make complaints to this specialist body. We must understand that anyone can make complaints if they think a program is offensive, improper, offends against taste or all these kinds of things. Our concern has been that in the process we are trying to establish we want to draw it rather more narrowly, at least in the beginning.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other point I make in response to Senator Button is that he continues to talk about a quick process. I think every honourable senator who has made written complaints to the ABC will agree on one point: Whatever else the Australian Broadcasting Commission has done, it has never responded quickly; the responses have been very slow. When one compares them one finds that the responses are almost the same every time. If I was at a football game talking to some of my rough mates, I know the words I would use for what the responses say. I could paraphrase them. One thing that has characterised responses from the ABC is that they have not been quick. It is only a pious hope--

TALK.START.PARA: —That has not been my experience.

—You must pack more punch, Senator Chipp, but I am glad to hear that there is someone who can say that he has had rapid responses. There is no guarantee, and no guarantee that I can find from the Bill, that the responses will be quick or made within a prescribed time. There may still be some delay. One of the things that has to come out of any consideration of the complaints procedure is that one gets a rapid response to complaints, a response which actually deals with the particular complaint and does not come back just stating some general principle of programming as has happened far too often in the past. I invite the Committee to give very sympathetic consideration to the Opposition' s amendments. I take it that they do attract a considerable amount of support for what they are trying to achieve. The difference appears to be in the process by which we are seeking to do it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just clarify in my own mind what Senator Button was saying about depoliticisation? I put to him the hypothetical proposition that was put by Senator Sir John Carrick, that is, that the appointment be somebody of a judicial nature. Is he suggesting that the appointment has to be seen not to be political, that is, that it be depoliticised, or is he concerned that the government of the day may find somebody in the judiciary who is likely to or who will be biased towards the government of the day, and so will make judgments and determinations compatible with the views of the government of the day? Or is he just simply saying that he wants to give the impression that the appointments will not be of a political nature? It seems to me that perhaps there ought to be--
—How would you like Mr Justice Staples to be appointed?
—I do not know enough about his judgments to make an in- depth determination.
—You have made one.

—I do not think that is the point right now. If Senator Chipp is serious about taking on board the argument I will prepare a list for him. But if he is just testing my argument, that is a different matter. I ask: Is it more important in that consideration to ensure that complaints about the ABC are dealt with and treated in a fashion that ensures that the ABC is impartial, that the complaints commissioner--
—Mr Justice Frederico would be another good one.
—Just because he does not like women in pants appearing in his court does not make him a bad judge, does it?

SPEECH.PARA: Is it better that the community affairs officers be appointed by the Managing Director who will, notwithstanding the best endeavours of his own integrity, be inclined by human nature to want complaints made against his corporation not to have merit and to have no foundation? Surely the best of both worlds is to have somebody who is quite removed from any influence, bias or any temptation of considerations other than the facts before him by way of the complaints.

Having more than one political party make determinations about these sorts of matters does not add a great deal to the argument. As I said earlier, if two political parties make the determination I am sure that the Australian Labor Party will take the view from the outset that the Opposition would be looking at somebody of our political persuasion and we might be tempted to the view that the Government might be looking to somebody of its persuasion. So I do not know that there is a great deal to be achieved by getting together and simply saying: 'Listen, all bets are off. We are all unbiased and we all have very clear consciences about our determination'. I do not know that that achieves a great deal. I ask Senator Button what he means by depoliticisation of the appointment. Is he concerned that the Government of the day will find that a judge, or somebody of that standing, is going to be biased, or is it a question of the perception of the public? Is that better, as I say, than an appointment by the Managing Director of somebody over whom he has absolute and total control?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I always listen with fascination to Senator Crichton-Browne's speeches, not so much when he asks questions but when he embarks on philosophical discourses. It is not my burden to argue the question of whether a judge should be appointed. Indeed it is not even the honourable senator's burden, as an Opposition senator, because he has not suggested that. We do not believe that the complaints tribunal procedure of the Australian Broadcasting Commission warrants the appointment of a judge. I do not want to get into that argument. As I made the point earlier, we have lived for 50 years with the ABC being without any complaints procedure at all. We want to introduce a mechanism which we believe is simple and fair. As I have said, if there are any suggestions which might improve the ABC in the next year or so the Government will certainly look at them very favourably.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator asked me what I meant by depoliticisation of the ABC. What I said was that the thrust of this Bill is, as much as possible, designed to take the ABC away from its traditional unhappy lot of being, in a sense, a political football. Insofar as the Bill is structured as a whole, that is the way it leads.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean in truth or in perception?

—In truth. We will not be appointing anybody to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation on the basis of loyal service to the Australian Labor Party. We would regard it as wrong if we, as a government, appointed anybody to the sensitive position of the complaints tribunal. We concede, as I conceded, earlier, that the mechanism for appointment in the proposal might not be perfect but we think it is better than that the Government should do it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering nine amendments which have been moved by Senator Harradine to Senator Peter Baume's proposed new Part VIIA. Senator Harradine had leave to introduce them together. I propose, in view of the debate , to put them in three groups-amendments (1) and (2) together; amendment (3); and finally amendments (4) to (9).

INTERJECT.PARA: Amendments (1) and (2) agreed to.
Amendment (3) negatived.
Amendments (4) to (9) negatived.
Question put:
That proposed new Part VIIA (Senator Peter Baume's amendment), as amended, be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 78 to 81-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 82. (Community Affairs Officers).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 52, clause 82, lines 1 to 8, leave out sub-clause (3), substitute the following sub-clause:
(3) The Managing Director shall-
(a) on the recommendation of-
(i) the Advisory Council established in relation to the State or Territory concerned; or
(ii) if no such Advisory Council has been established-the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Advisory Council,

appoint, in each State, in the Northern Territory and in the Australian Capital Territory, a person or persons, to be known as Community Affairs Officers, to consider complaints mentioned in sub-section (1); and

(b) on the recommendation of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Advisory Council, appoint an officer of the Corporation, to be known as the Principal Community Affairs Officer, whose duties will consist of or include the co- ordination of the activities of the Community Affairs Officers.'.
This enables the Advisory Council to recommend the Community Affairs Officers to the General Manager and to ensure that he shall accept their advice. Clause 82 ( 3) states:
The Managing Director shall-
not 'may', on the recommendation of the Advisory Council-
(a) appoint, in each State . . . Community Affairs Officers . . .

It takes away the discretion of the Managing Director and puts the choice of these important people virtually in the hands of the Advisory Council. I have spoken about this at some length during the second reading debate and previously during the Committee stage. I will not speak at any length now.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Victoria-Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications) (11.46)-The Committee has already passed two amendments which are consequential, as it were, upon this amendment. The Government indicated at that stage that it supports this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 51, Clause 82, sub-clause (1), after paragraph (b), lines 33 to 35, insert the following new paragraphs:
'(c) that a program was inaccurate, unfair or biased;
(d) that a program was otherwise offensive'.
(2) Page 51, clause 82, sub-clause (2), lines 38 to 43, leave out the sub- clause.
(3) Page 52, clause 82, sub-clause (4), lines 9 to 12, after the sub-clause, insert the following new sub-clauses:

'(4A) When the Principal Community Affairs Officer has considered a report under sub-section (4), he shall notify the complainant or, if there is more than one complainant, each of the complainants, of his decision and of the reasons for the decision in relation to the complaint.

'(4B) Sub-section (4A) does not require the Principal Community Affairs Officer to notify each of the complainants if he is of the opinion that, having regard to the number of complainants, it would be unduly burdensome to do so.'
(4) Page 51, clause 82, sub-clause (1), paragraph (b), lines 33 to 36, at end of paragraph, add the following words:
'(whether or not the invasion of privacy complained of was contained in the actual broadcast or televising of the program, announcement or other matter)'.

The general consensus-I believe all honourable senators agree-is that complaints should be made about unfair or biased programs. This amendment might fail by the inclusion of paragraph (d) which states: 'that a program was otherwise offensive'. It may well be that some honourable senator may seek to amend my amendment by leaving out paragraph (d) so that at least we will be left with half the cake.

I address my remarks to paragraph (c) which states: 'that a program was inaccurate, unfair or biased'. The word 'inaccurate' is contained in the Government's Bill at present; so there is no problem about that word. The words 'unfair or biased' ought to be inserted in the Bill because clause 8 of the Bill , which is entitled 'Duties of the Board', states:
(c) To ensure that the gathering and presentation by the Corporation of news and information is accurate and impartial according to recognised standards of objective journalism-

Those two tests are to be applied by the Board. The Government has seen fit to enable complaints to be made to the Community Affairs Officer on one test-that is, the test of inaccuracy-but it has not enabled the Community Affairs Officer to deal with complaints relating to the other tests of unfairness or bias. The Government may say that it is open for anybody to complain to the Commission about unfairness or bias. But I believe that unless all viewers and listeners have equal opportunity the result will be elitism. I believe that the Government 's legislation is an elitist piece of legislation. Senator Button or myself can phone the Chairman of the ABC and complain about unfairness or bias. But do honourable senators believe that the ordinary citizen-not that I suppose we are extraordinary-and the rank and file would get through to the Chairman. Of course they would not. In fact it is elitist to prevent other citizens from making complaints to the Community Affairs Officer. I hope that if honourable senators have a problem with paragraph (d) they will at least salvage paragraph (c).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. Senator Harradine 's first amendment contains two questions. He suggested we may wish to move a further amendment if we had any difficulties. Mr Chairman, it may be more appropriate to seek your ruling, in accordance with Standing Orders, so that the two questions can be divided for the consideration of the Committee; we can consider proposed paragraph (c) and proposed paragraph (d) as separate questions . We propose to support proposed paragraph (c) but not to support proposed paragraph (d).

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I am prepared to put the two questions separately. I will do so now.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put:
That proposed new paragraph (c) (Senator Harradine's amendment) be inserted.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Consideration interrupted.
Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, follows the question I asked him yesterday. Can the Leader of the Government now tell me, as he was unable to do yesterday, whether the Prime Minister gave a post-election undertaking not to alter taxation of lump sum superannuation payments? If so, how does the Government justify the mini-Budget decision to lift the rate from 5 per cent to 30 per cent?

—The answer to the first part of the question, I am sorry, is no. I think the second part of the question misrepresents the position somewhat in that any increase in taxation in respect of superannuation lump sums is prospective and no person who has an entitlement as at the date of the economic statement will have that entitlement interfered with at all.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of that answer, how does the Leader of the Government explain that the union movement and the national media interpreted private and public comments by Mr Hawke as meaning that there would be no change to the superannuation arrangements? Specifically, has he seen the remarks of the Australian Council of Trade Unions Secretary, Mr Bill Kelty, in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald that when he and other union leaders left Mr Hawke last month they believed that lump sum provisions would not be changed?

—It is not my function to interpret remarks made by people outside the Government and I do not intend to do so. There has been a lot of misrepresentation in the media of the facts in relation to the proposed tax on superannuation lump sums. I do not propose to make any interpretation of the remarks made by Mr Kelty and others. As I informed the Senate yesterday, the Government will be meeting with the ACTU next week and these matters, amongst others, will be discussed.

—I direct my question to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications. Has any evidence been forwarded to the Minister's Department with regard to employees illegally assisting starting price bookmakers? When will the Minister be in a position to respond to allegations made in the Connor report to the Victorian State Government?

—I am unaware of any information having been forwarded to the Minister for Comunications in relation to the allegations made in the report of the Connor inquiry dealing with SP bookmaking and the alleged role of Telecom Australia in relation to that matter. I will make inquiries and will advise the honourable senator as soon as possible if there have been any such complaints.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INCOME TAX REBATE ON HEALTH INSURANCE

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It follows the question I raised with him yesterday. Is he now aware of the context of the Government's pre-election undertaking not to remove the health insurance tax rebate until after the introduction of Medicare? What will be the cost to Australian families of the breaking of this promise?

—One learns from experience in this position. I have learnt from the experience of four years watching the former Government in operation. I have not yet obtained the information for which Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle asked me but I will try to expedite the obtaining of that information.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. It refers to the special assistance scheme for community welfare agencies in financial difficulties. Can the Minister explain why so few welfare agencies have been granted funding under this scheme since its inception in 1974? Does this scheme have any future? If so, what role will it play in the overall funding structure for community welfare agencies?

—From memory, this special assistance scheme was introduced in 1974 to assist agencies that were in difficulty with one-off payments. I believe that since that time only about 50 agencies have been assisted. After 1977 the application of this scheme was so narrow that very few agencies qualified under it. Very few have been assisted in recent times. The new guidelines were introduced in 1980 or 1981. It is my intention to use this scheme to assist agencies on the basis of those guidelines. However, I will get for Senator Elstob further details of the exact operations of the scheme since it was introduced. The Government will certainly investigate whether this is the appropriate method to use to assist agencies which, as he knows and as other honourable senators know, are frequently in greater difficulties in these difficult times.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism aware that at present there are some four separate competing offices in London, each promoting individual Australian States and Territories as tourist destinations? Is the Minister aware of the expressed wish of the Australian tourist industry that the Commonwealth Government co-ordinate marketing of Australian tourism overseas out of one office per country, with the individual States and Territories each having representation in each office as they desire? What steps has the Government taken to persuade the States and Territories to forgo their individual tourist promotions overseas and join the Commonwealth in one major advertising push to sell Australia as a holiday destination rather than a collection of competing States, as was undertaken by the Minister in his address to the National Economic Summit Conference? Will the Minister be raising this issue at the annual meeting of Federal and State tourism Ministers tomorrow?

—The question was so detailed and took up such fine points of policy regarding the promotion of Australian tourism overseas that I am not in a position to answer it. I will refer the matter to Mr Brown immediately so that an answer can be forthcoming. I would say, though, that the policy for a co- ordinated approach to the promotion of Australian tourism overseas implied by the honourable senator's question sounds eminently sensible to me. I will make sure that Mr Brown gives the matter urgent and thorough consideration.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Health outline this Government's proposals for supporting worker health centres which provide such important awareness of worker health hazards? Can the Minister comment in particular on the Government's plans to have the hazardous material asbestos banned from use where alternatives exist and, where asbestos must be used, to have the process guaranteed to ensure worker safety?

—My colleague the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, is in the process of drawing up a comprehensive program for workers' health education, and preventive and occupational health in particular. As Senator Reynolds, and particularly Senator Crowley, will know, this has been a preoccupation of the Minister and the Australian Labor Party's health and welfare committee for some years. The full outline of the program will be announced when it is completed. The Government is aware, as previous governments were aware, of the dangers of asbestosis and the resulting diseases which come from the inhalation of asbestos . I noted recently that some buildings owned and occupied by the Department of Social Security have recently needed modification because asbestos was used as an insulation material and as a lagging material around hot water pipes, et cetera. The Government is conscious of the dangers of asbestos. State building regulations in this day and age usually ban the use of asbestos and require its removal in dangerous situations. As to the involvement of the Commonwealth Department of Health in this area, I will seek full information from the Minister for Health and forward it to the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HOME MORTGAGE INTEREST PAYMENTS: TAX REBATE

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the memory of the Leader of the Government in the Senate been refreshed to the extent that he can now recall the Government's election commitment to continue the existing tax concession on mortgage interest payments ?
—No, not yet. I will try next week.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. How does this position square with the Australian Labor Party's election housing leaflet which stated that the Government would provide mortgage relief for those in difficulty and retain tax rebates for home loan interest payments?
—I suggest, with respect, that it is for Senator Watson to work out how, as he puts it, it squares with something I have already indicated I do not recall.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs been drawn to the remarks by Professor Leonie Kramer reported in the Australian of 14 May concerning the decision of the Australian Education Council to discontinue the national student evaluation program? Was this decision supported by all State Ministers of Education? What were the reasons for discontinuing the national student evaluation program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the second part of the honourable senator's question is yes. I am pleased to have this opportunity to explain to the Senate the decision taken by the Australian Education Council. The Australian Education Council sought an evaluation of the national assessment research project which was being undertaken. That evaluation was an independent evaluation by Professor Power. I think the evaluation was actually undertaken during the time my predecessor, Senator Baume, was still the Commonwealth Minister at the AEC. The result of the evaluation showed that the research project was simply not giving reliable information about educational standards. The methodology was dubious and the results were not such that any government, State or Federal, could base sensible education policies upon them. Thus the decision was taken that this research project into national standards would not be continued. That decision was supported by all Ministers at the AEC meeting, with the exception of the Northern Territory Minister.

ANSWER.PARA: For Professor Leonie Kramer or other advocates of reactionary education policies to interpret this decision, as she has done, according to media reports , as a decision that means that the AEC is not concerned with standards in schools throughout Australia, is quite wrong and quite mischievous. The AEC's decision was expressed in terms of wishing not to continue with a useless project, but the AEC confirmed its concern about educational standards. There is no opposition by any Minister within the AEC to the idea of a national survey of educational standards. There is a concern that any such evaluation produce reliable data on which educational policies designed to raise standards of all schools in Australia can be pursued. In terms of educational values the overwhelming concern at the AEC meeting was that all children should have access to a high standard of education and that the standards of education should be improved in a number of ways. So, to characterise the decision, as has been done according to media reports by Professor Kramer, as a decision that showed that the AEC was not interested in educational standards is entirely wrong and misleading.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the recent statements made by the Prime Minister in an interview with Mr Peter Costigan reported in the Melbourne Herald last Saturday and on the Mike Walsh Show, I think, on Monday of this week to the effect that the Prime Minister would have broken the law had he given Mr Combe the information contained in the report of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation which was received and considered by the security committee of Cabinet. I ask: Did the Attorney-General advise the Prime Minister that he would break the law if he took this action? If so, what was the basis of such advice? If the Attorney-General did not so advise the Prime Minister, will he inform the Senate who did advise the Prime Minister to this effect, and what was the basis for it? Does the Prime Minister's view mean that the law was broken at the conference which took place on Wednesday, 11 May 1983, between the Attorney-General, Mr Combe and the Director-General of ASIO?

—Senator Durack well knows that it is not the practice in this place under Standing Orders either to ask for or to give legal opinions. As such, on that ground alone it would be inappropriate for me to comment on the question as to whether a breach of the law was committed in any of the circumstances referred to by the honourable senator. I add to that, however, that in order to give a complete reply, even if I were minded to do so, to that request for a legal opinion it would be necessary to place on the public record more facts in relation to this whole matter than the Government is presently prepared to do. Indeed, in that respect the Government is simply continuing to observe the stricture which has been constantly urged upon it by members of the Opposition in relation to security matters. I add further that these matters and all other associated matters of contention in relation to the Combe affair are, of course, within the ambit of the Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence Agencies to be set running next week under Mr Justice Hope. It is perfectly open to Mr Justice Hope, under his very wide terms of reference, to deal with these matters, as indeed all the others that are in issue in relation to this affair. If Senator Durack or anyone else on the Opposition benches is unhappy with the answers they have so far received to their public questions, they have a forum in which to pursue these matters further.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Attorney- General obviously, to put it charitably, misunderstood the question. I was not asking for a legal opinion. I am asking the Attorney-General whether he advised the Prime Minister in relation to the statements the Prime Minister has now made and, if he did not, does he know whether anybody else did. I am asking him about a fact.
—To the extent that the honourable senator seeks answers to questions of fact, I have nothing to add to my previous answer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES B52 FLIGHTS OVER AUSTRALIA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Defence to a statement made by the Minister for Defence and reported in the Daily News on 2 May, relating to United States B52 flights over Australia. He was reported as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: As with other low-level training flights, these B52s will be unarmed and carry no bombs.

I ask the Minister: Has the United States Defense Department altered its policy of refusing to confirm or deny that United States military ships or aircraft are carrying nuclear weapons at any time? If not, can the Minister inform us how he knows the weapons status of United States military aircraft while in Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation is that the new Government has not modified in any way the arrangements previously in force which permit United States B52s to conduct low-level navigation flights over northern Australia and surveillance operations from Australia over the Indian Ocean. These flights, we are assured and accept are unarmed and carry no bombs. The agreement of the Australian Government would need to be obtained for the B52s to carry out any other category of operations from or over Australia. As I understand it, no such agreement has been either sought or obtained. There is no present intention, on behalf of the present Government, to review the detailed arrangements under which these aircraft are allowed to operate in Australia. As with our other co- operative arrangements with the United States, the broad issues will be considered in the context of the Government's review of the ANZUS alliance.

—Has the Attorney-General seen an article in the Canberra Times on Sunday last in which Mr Jack Waterford asserted that, under the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act, the Cabinet security committee which received and considered the ASIO report affecting Mr Combe was obliged to inform him of the adverse assessment contained in it unless the Attorney-General certified otherwise? Did the Attorney-General at the relevant time give any consideration to the question whether Mr Combe had a legal right to be informed of the ASIO report affecting him? If so, what conclusion did he come to on the question. If not, why not?

—I did, of course, give consideration to what obligations were upon me or the Government under the ASIO Act or indeed what avenues were open to Mr Combe or other people affected by the course of recent events. I am not prepared, for the reasons I indicated previously in my answer to Senator Durack, to indicate what legal conclusion I came to or what advice I gave other members of the Government in the context of that matter or in relation to any other matter. As to questions of both legal opinion and fact, I repeat that these are matters that are all being dealt with and able to be dealt with by Mr Justice Hope. If any member of the Opposition, whether Senator Durack, Senator Collard or anybody else, is dissatisfied with the way in which these matters are being dealt with presently by the Government, he has his redress in that forum.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has seen a report in today's Sydney Morning Herald headlined 'Macphee attacks Howard' wherein in part it is reported:

QUESTION.PARA: The Opposition spokesman on employment, Mr Macphee, has launched a major criticism of the wages policy of the shadow Treasurer, Mr Howard, in a document calling on the Opposition to support centralised wage fixation.
The report continues:

In his paper Mr Macphee criticises by implication the Fraser Government's role in destruction of wage indexation in 1981. He says that the industry-by-industry approach (which was backed by Mr Howard) was ''doomed to fail miserably and to aggravate the economy, especially as it followed a period of what unions regarded as wage restraint.''

Is it not true that no party can claim economic credibility while it is in disarray on wages policy? Will the Government now invite the Opposition to cease its carping and defeatist criticism of the National Economic Summit Conference and, in the spirit of bringing Australia together, welcome Mr Macphee's comments as a positive step towards endorsement of the Summit communique in which all summiteers expressed support for centralised wage fixation?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chaney

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to Standing Order 98 which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . Questions may be put to Ministers of the Crown relating to public affairs; . . . or other public matter connected with the business on the Notice Paper, of which such Senators may have charge.
I suggest that the question is not related to any matter of business or any public matter of which this Minister has charge.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point of order. I invite the Leader of the Government in the Senate to answer the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the reason why the point of order was raised, Mr President. Yes, I have had my attention drawn to the article in the Sydney Morning Herald. Not only have I had my attention drawn to it but, of course, I did not need to have my attention drawn to the smouldering issue within the Opposition as to whether it should have a wages policy. Everybody in this country has been quite aware of the Opposition's difficulties for some time. We, as a government, are particularly aware of the Opposition's difficulties because we are suffering from them. The absence of a wages policy for the last two years has caused enormous--
—Senator Button has got his memory back.

—I remember the former Government very well. I do not easily forget those last seven years. The fact is that the present Government is suffering because the Fraser Government did not have a wages policy. It went from one ad hoc decision to another in relation to wages. The seeds of the present wage fixation difficulties, about which Opposition senators now ask questions, were laid in 1981 by the Fraser Government. Mr Peacock, the present Leader of the Opposition-for how long I do not know-recognised this in his speech during the Budget debate in 1981 when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Since the abandonment of wage indexation, there is no real wages policy.

That is what the present Leader of the Opposition said when talking about the policies of the former Government. Mr Peacock thought that the transition from a centralised to a decentralised wage fixation system should be planned and orderly. As we know, it was neither of those things.

Following the collapse of wage indexation, in the six months ended December 1981, under the Fraser Government, we saw the highest levels of industrial disputes in the post-war period. That was followed by the wages pause, the need to be seen to be doing something, a series of ad hoc decision-making, divisive policies and no policy at all for the end of the wage freeze enunciated by the former Government.

Of course the Liberal Party, in contrast to the Government, still has no wages policy. Over many years the only person in the Liberal Party who has had an appropriate appreciation of the difficulties of industrial relations policies has been, of course, Mr Macphee who was responsible for criticising the Deputy Leader of the Opposition about his absence of wages policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that the Leader of the Government table the paper from which he has been quoting.
—Absolutely.

—My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, refers to the matters raised by Senator Primmer during the adjournment debate last night against a series of officers in the Department of Foreign Affairs. From the Minister's reply in the adjournment debate it is clear that he does agree that serious and unsubstantiated allegations, totally destructive of several professional careers, have been made under privilege. To protect the civil liberties of those who have been named in this fashion, will the Attorney- General ensure that the matters raised by Senator Primmer are finally and expeditiously dealt with and cleared up? Will he ensure that Senator Primmer and other members of his party are made aware of the avenues open to them to pursue matters of concern without indulging in unsubstantiated character assassination under cover of privilege?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In dealing with this matter last night during the adjournment debate I did not say that Senator Primmer's allegations were unsubstantiated. I did say that they were so far unsubstantiated by the various inquiries that had been held by the Australian Federal Police and, in particular , the Department of Finance, as well as the internal inquiries in the Foreign Affairs Department.

QUESTION.PARA: Inquiries are still on foot by the Public Service Board and the Commonwealth Ombudsman in relation to matters arising out of Senator Primmer's allegations. Until those inquiries have reached their final conclusion I do not think it would be appropriate to accept the description that Senator MacGibbon has offered.

However, I accept that there may well be a case for reviewing the extent to which it is proper, under cover of privilege, to engage in the rather wide- ranging series of allegations that have been put on the record on a number of occasions by Senator Primmer, albeit, as I said last night, with a fierce sense of conviction, honesty and sincerity of purpose by Senator Primmer as to the rightness of the information in front of him. I make that point very clear.

As to the larger questions about the use of parliamentary privilege to raise matters of public importance of this kind, which may indeed have the incidental effect of harming the reputations of individuals, I simply say that these are matters which are being squarely addressed by the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege which has been reconstituted since the election and which is due to report shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Resources and Energy been drawn to the report in the Adelaide News of 20 May that preparations are under way to move the controversial Australian Mineral Development Laboratories, AMDEL , out of the densely populated Thebarton area of Adelaide to Technology Park at the Levels? Has the South Australian Government and/or the Thebarton Council approached the Commonwealth seeking financial assistance to relocate AMDEL from Thebarton, where residents have protested against the possibility of radiation contamination from uranium processing? What stage has been reached in dealing with this matter?

—The answer to the first part of Senator Maguire's question is yes, my attention has been drawn to the Adelaide News report of 20 May. My attention had been drawn to this issue on a number of previous occasions by a number of South Australian Government supporters and in particular the honourable member for Hindmarsh, Mr Scott. On the question of possible contamination, the factual position is somewhat in dispute. Regardless of that, a strong case has been made by Mr Scott and others for transferring this facility to a different site. I might add that there were at least three approaches to the previous Government by both the present South Australian Government and the Liberal Government which it replaced last year on this matter, dating back to at least September 1982. No substantive reply was received to any of those approaches by either the present or the previous South Australian Government. I have told Mr Scott and others that the request for Commonwealth financial assistance will be considered in the Budget processes. I repeat that assurance. But Mr Scott is well aware, as I am sure Senator Maguire is well aware, that this Government faces enormous fiscal problems in the coming financial year because of the very large and, prior to the election, concealed deficit which it inherited from its irresponsible predecessor.
—Does the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs believe that the freedom to send one's children to an independent school is bought at too high a price for the rest of society?

—I think the Government's attitude to independent schools has been made very clear. Certainly during the election campaign this aspect of our policy was given a great deal of exposure. I simply reiterate that the Government is not opposed to independent schools in principle. The Government acknowledges its responsibility to support such schools on the basis of need.
—What is your view?
—My view is the view of the Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Senator Ryan has said that her view is the view of the Government. How then does she explain her written statement in the Sydney Morning Herald of 10 October 1981? It states:

QUESTION.PARA: The freedom to send one's children to an independent school is bought at too high a price for the rest of society.
Does she really expect that she can say different things in different places to different audiences and still be regarded as credible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the Senate is edified by the capacity of the honourable senator to undertake research into newspaper files. I am trying to recall the occasion on which I said those words. I thought they had a ring of familiarity actually when the honourable senator asked his question the first time. It is the kind of flourishing phrase that I like to think is typical of some of my written work. In recalling the situation in 1981, it was probably the case that the balance between a needs based approach to non-government schools and ensuring adequate funding so that the primary responsibility of government towards public schooling could be fulfilled was going the wrong way. It is certainly my view that after seven years of the Fraser Government the balance between the Federal Government's responsibility towards maintaining public schooling-available to all children from any socio-economic, race or religious background-of the highest possible standard should be maintained. Certainly, it was the case that during seven years of the Fraser Administration the capacity of public schooling to provide education of the highest possible standard to all children was undermined. At the same time, there was a very generous funding of schools which were already providing schooling in the private sector at a very high standard.

ANSWER.PARA: Under those circumstances, I believe that the price of individual choice is too high; that is, it is too high a price if a school chosen by individual parents is funded at a level which erodes the Government's capacity to fulfil its primary obligation to public schooling. Those honourable senators who have listened to what I have been saying and have not engaged in their usual practice of mindless interjections will realise that there is no discrepancy between the remark ferreted out by Senator Baume and the Government's policy, which it is my responsibility to implement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Defence inform the Senate whether the Government is planning to provide any assistance to victims of the present floods in northern New South Wales?

—I am able to inform the Senate as to a variety of measures that have been taken by the Commonwealth Government in this respect, involving a spectacular demonstration of the co-operation that is possible between the military and civilian arms of government in this country. The Natural Disasters Organisation received a request for Defence Force assistance from the New South Wales State Emergency Services at 9.34 a.m. yesterday, 25 May. The Minister for Defence approved the provision of a helicopter and at 10 a.m. yesterday the Joint Military Operations Staff at Defence headquarters was advised of this approval. A Royal Australian Air Force Iroquois from No. 5 Squadron at Fairbairn was prepared for a five-day deployment and long range operations, fitted with auxiliary fuel tanks and was airborne at 2 p.m. yesterday en route to Walgett. During its ferry flight I regret to say that it suffered fuel supply problems and was forced to return to Canberra late last night. But following repairs, the helicopter was dispatched and arrived at Walgett at 11.20 this morning. An additional Royal Australian Navy helicopter to provide flood relief operations in the Walgett-Bourke area was dispatched from Nowra at 8.15 this morning. Again , it was forced to divert to Canberra because of bad weather. But it departed an hour or so ago and is due to arrive at Walgett early this afternoon.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Did Mr Hawke during the election campaign promise that a Labor Government would reduce unemployment by 2 per cent over its three years in office? I know that the Minister is perhaps subject to political amnesia on this subject. In contrast, did Mr Keating state at the National Economic Summit Conference that under either scenario A or scenario C, the percentage level of unemployment in the three years ahead would remain, at the end of those three years, the same as it is now, and, therefore, there would be a greater total number of people unemployed? Did the recent economic statement by the Government reduce overall government spending by $427m and indicate a sharp reduction in the overall money supply? In view of those actions, is it not apparent that there will be a substantial increase in unemployment in the years immediately ahead, and another broken promise by the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall Mr Hawke saying during the election campaign that if the Fraser Government was re-elected the level of unemployment in Australia would reach one million people by the end of this year. I also recall Mr Hawke saying in the course of the election campaign-in fact, a week before the election- something which the Fraser Government never said on any occasion prior to an election; it always did so afterwards. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: If we get into government and we have the National Economic Summit Conference and the people of Australia find out that Mr Fraser and Mr Howard haven't been telling the truth-that the Budget deficit is very much higher . . . and there is consensus at the Summit that there would have to be some modification of our programs, then obviously we would accede to that.

That is what the Leader of the Opposition said prior to the election. Of course, that problem was identified by way of suspicion by the Leader of the Opposition before the election and was not identified by way of any semblance of honesty on behalf of the previous Government. I have been asked whether Mr Keating said that scenarios A and C as put to the National Economic Summit Conference would result in unemployment remaining much the same. My recollection is that he did, but I will check that with Mr Keating. I believe the question asked about the cut in expenditure announced by the Government in the course of the recent economic statement to be correct. I do not believe the Treasurer foreshadowed a sharp reduction in the money supply, but I will check that for Senator Sir John Carrick and advise him in due course.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SMOKING IN THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that he was reported on commercial radio this morning as advocating the abolition of smoking in the Australian Capital Territory? Is this an accurate reflection of his views or just a smokescreen?

—Yes, it was drawn to my attention that I was reported on a commerical radio station in Canberra this morning as advocating the abolition of smoking in the Australian Capital Territory as a result of my answer to a question asked yesterday. My comment in answer to that was that anyone who interpreted my words yesterday as meaning that I advocated the abolition of smoking in the Capital Territory had been smoking something considerably stronger than cigarettes. What in fact happened yesterday was that Senator Coates, with that clarity of mind and heightened perception which comes to all ex-smokers, had noted while travelling to and from Canberra that there was a considerable amount of cigarette advertising in airports. Being aware that airports were in general under Commonwealth control and advocating the abolition of advertising of cigarettes and other tobacco products, he suggested that I should advise the Minister for Health that this was an appropriate action we could take as an extension of the banning of advertising of these products on radio and television which is already in existence. I conceded yesterday that this was a possibility and said that I would refer the matter to Dr Blewett, the Minister for Health. That is as far as the matter has gone so far. I am certainly not advocating the abolition of smoking, nor do I think we have the power to do so in the Australian Capital Territory or anywhere else.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I refer to what I believe is one of the major health scandals of the decade; that is, that some 120 Brisbane household backyards have been found to have levels of radioactivity from sand mining tailings which exceed the National Health and Medical Research Council safety limits. The Minister would also be aware that less than one per cent of the 200,000 tons of hot sand which were sold have actually been traced. Can the Minister indicate whether the Federal Government will undertake an inquiry into this matter? Since the problem extends beyond the limits of Queensland this matter would seem to fall within the province of the Federal Government in relation to its powers in radioactive areas.

—The matters raised in Senator Macklin's question are obviously of great seriousness and urgency. I am unable to reply to him now but I will make sure that the responsible Minister investigates the matter immediately and gets a reply for Senator Macklin as soon as possible.

—Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware that large numbers of World War II veterans are now approaching retiring age? Can the Minister clarify what the position would be if all veterans over 65 were eligible to receive the Service pension rather than the age pension?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that a substantial number of World War II veterans are approaching what is regarded as the normal retiring age of 65 and a considerable number of them would be eligible for the Service pension. Senator Harradine asked me a somewhat similar question on this matter a couple of weeks ago. As I am informed, a considerable number of ex-servicemen have applied for and have been granted the Service pension. As a result of the economic conditions existing in the country, arising from the seven years of mismanagement of the economy, a number of people out of work are finding themselves unemployable and, therefore, come within the category considered for a Service pension.

ANSWER.PARA: However, in answer to the specific question that was asked of me, following what Senator Harradine put to me a couple of weeks ago, the estimated cost of providing in the next Budget funds for those who become eligible would approximate $25m. The following year it would be some $57m, assuming that it would be approved in the Budget context. These are net figures representing the cost to my Department in pensions and medical benefits, less savings which the Department of Social Security or the Department of Health would otherwise carry. These costs occur as a result of the advantages which accrue to applicants for Service pensions, namely, that the disability pension received by ex-servicemen is completely disregarded in the assessment of Service pensions whereas it is held in full as income in the assessment of age pensions. So, there is an advantage in that respect. Similarly, under the existing legislation, which was largely determined by the previous Government, the provision by my Department of medical treatment is more expensive than that provided by Senator Grimes's Department. So a substantial cost is involved, which clearly has to be taken in the Budget context.

My Department and I are sympathetic to the proposition that veterans should become eligible, but I remind the Senate that the figures in respect of the 1982 -83 deficit show a blow-out of some $3,000m. When one takes that against the projected deficit for 1983-84 of some $6 billion, one sees that the Government is placed in a position in which it is not able to put into effect its policy considerations and apply a compassionate approach to these problems. This is because of the very difficult Budget problems we have arising out of the way in which the previous Government left the economy of this country. While we are sympathetic, I have to advise the Senate that the Government's hands are considerably tied as a result of what we have inherited.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. On the introduction of the Medicare scheme, what will be the effect on repatriation disability pensioners who are in receipt of a 50 per cent or higher disability pension and who are currently entitled to free medical, hospital, dental and pharmaceutical services? Will they pay one per cent extra tax from 1 January 1983 as part of the new Medicare scheme?

—I am currently having discussions with the Minister for Health in respect of the Medicare proposals and the levy. We are determined that there will be no additional cost as far as Service beneficiaries are concerned. The question of whether they will be eligible for the levy requires some specific consideration by the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Health. Those in receipt of substantial incomes will probably be regarded as being eligible for the levy. Those who are in receipt of benefits from my Department will generally be exempt.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. It arises out of raids on homosexual venues in Oxford Street, Paddington, in January and February of this year and the subsequent charging of 15 men with offences under the New South Wales Crimes Act. Does the Attorney-General agree that the New South Wales laws relating to homosexuals are in need of urgent reform, especially in view of the recent tactics of the New South Wales police? I ask whether the Attorney-General recalls his statement during the election campaign when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I shall be consulting with Mr Landa, the New South Wales Attorney-General and my other State counterparts with a view to the uniform implementation of more enlightened homosexual law reform measures, both in the areas of anti- discrimination legislation and also with a view to achieving the decriminalisation of the law, at least to the extent that has already been achieved in South Australia and Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Australian Capital Territory.
—And the Australian Capital Territory. Has the Attorney-General had discussions with Mr Landa? If not, when will he consult with the New South Wales Attorney-General and other Attorneys-General?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do recall making that statement during the election campaign and expressing on a number of occasions the concern that is felt, I think, around Australia at the weakness of the protections given by the law to homosexuals in a number of jurisdications, not simply New South Wales. I have consulted since the election with Mr Landa, the New South Wales Attorney-General , both in writing and-I hope the expression will not be misunderstood-orally on the subject.

ANSWER.PARA: I am waiting for Mr Landa's reaction to the raising of the issue that I have set in train in this way. I hope that it will be possible on a consultative and co-operative basis over a period to get a rational set of uniform laws around Australia protecting the liberties of the individual in this area.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question also is directed to the Attorney-General. It is in three parts, all in relation to the issue of South West Tasmania. The first is in regard to the promises that the Attorney-General made to me on two separate occasions to table aircraft movement messages that were distributed when the spy flights over Tasmania were ordered by him. When will the Attorney table the messages? On 11 May, in an Estimates committee hearing his officer told him that it would take only two days to give him the information but the messages are still not tabled.

QUESTION.PARA: The second part of my question is as follows: Following the Government's action in seeking an immediate injunction from the High Court of Australia to stop all work on the dam, what arrangements does the Attorney suggest should be made to employ those affected by the cessation of work if the Government is successful? My concern, as he would know, is that from next Tuesday hundreds of men could be thrown out of work for a couple of months until the High Court makes its decision on the Commonwealth's challenge to stop permanently the building of the dam.
The third part of my question concerns the answer Senator Evans gave a couple of weeks ago when he said:
No concluded decision has been made.
Has there been a decision-preferably a concluded decision-as to the Government's intention on the Franklin Dam issue once the High Court hands down its decision? The Attorney would remember--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator will ask her question.
—It is because of the Attorney's answer to one question--
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to ask a question and not to make statements at Question Time.
—He answered a question, he will remember, on Nationwide, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . , we'll certainly abide by the High Court's order . . .
And then he said:
. . . it is only a question of then whether we look to other means--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator will ask her question.
—I ask the Attorney-General: Will the Government look at other means if it loses the case in the High Court or will it abide by the High Court' s decision and leave Tasmania in peace?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first question relating to the tabling of papers concerning aircraft movement orders and other such exotica, I repeat my assurance to Senator Walters that I have no intention whatsoever of not tabling the material; it is just that it does not seem to have emerged yet from the bowels of whichever department it happens to be buried in. I did ask Senator Walters, as she may recall, in the aftermath of the Senate Estimates hearing, whether she would mind harassing the members of my office in the following few days in order to secure the papers in question. It appears that her harassment endeavours in that respect have not yet been successful. I undertake now-I hope my staff is listening-to follow up the matter and ensure that before we rise the papers in question are tabled. I apologise to the honourable senator for not having followed up that matter sooner.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of the redeployment of personnel working on the dam site in the event that the High Court grants an interim injunction, I simply say this: The case is scheduled to commence next week in the High Court. It may be a little delayed by virtue of the amount of time that was occupied in this chamber in debating the legislation on which the litigation is partially based, but it will not be for more than a few days, if that is so. The case is expected to run for about six days. At the conclusion of it there will be a formal application by the Commonwealth for an interim injunction in order to ensure that no work proceeds on the dam, not only during the period we are waiting for the immediate High Court decision on the actual validity of the Commonwealth legislation and regulations but also in the course of any subsequent further hearing that may be necessary to establish the facts of the matter, assuming the legislation is valid; that is to say, whether or not the construction of the dam offends the standards set out in the legislation.

The arrangements that would be appropriate to cover the workers who would thus need something else to do are in the process of discussion. The Commonwealth constantly sought to raise this issue with Tasmania. No doubt it will be one of the matters dealt with in the discussions to take place this afternoon between Mr Hawke and Mr Gray. I cannot say anything more about that matter except that we are well aware of the necessity to give an undertaking, as is the normal course in litigation of this kind, that in the event that any damage should occur to the State of Tasmania and to individuals within it as a result of an interim injunction the Commonwealth appreciates that it has a responsibility- certainly in the event that the case is ultimately lost-to ensure that the tab is picked up for such damage. We understand that, and negotiations are proceeding along those lines.

As to the question of what would happen in the event-in the unlikely event, I hasten to add-that the Commonwealth position in the High Court fails, I simply indicate that of course we will, as I have indicated publicly before, abide by any order that may be made by the High Court. There is no question in that respect. As to the possible taking of other action in reliance on other powers or other executive measures, that remains a matter for consideration when that particular hypothetical event occurs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. It is notable that statements made by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations about job development schemes have stressed the Government's requirement for women to be equitably treated by those administering the schemes, unlike the previous Government, under which women were disproportionately disadvantaged in subsidised training programs. What procedures have been adopted within the Commonwealth Public Service to ensure that increasing numbers of women are employed as apprentices and in other training positions?

—Senator Giles raises an important matter. I am able to say that the Public Service Board is making a determined effort to encourage young women to apply for non-traditional employment vacancies, including apprenticeships. As part of its Equal Opportunity in Employment Program for women, the Department of Transport and Construction, for example, conducted an active campaign to recruit females for its 1983 intake of apprentices. The campaign included the setting of targets for female recruitment and the use of the sentence, 'The Department stresses in the interests of equal employment opportunity that applications from young women are encouraged', in all its advertisements. Guidelines on how to increase the number of female applications were also issued to relevant areas of the Department. A total of 153 young women applied for apprenticeships with that Department, including 33 in New South Wales and 57 in Western Australia. Of the 79 apprentices recruited, 10 are women, which exceeds the target set. Queensland and Western Australia also exceeded their targets of one per region by both recruiting two female apprentices. These 10 women were recruited to the trades of fitter and turner, painter, electrical fitter-mechanic, refrigeration mechanic, carpenter, motor mechanic and sign writer. The 1983 intake takes the number of female apprentices employed by the Department from 7 to 17.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it a fact that the new tax on lump sum superannuation payments applies to such payments at death? Does the new tax also apply to the proceeds of the whole of life policies paid at death?
—I am not sure of the precise details on that aspect. I do not recall them. I will refer the question to the Treasurer and get an answer for the honourable senator.

—Earlier in Question Time I was asked a question by Senator Robert Ray in relation to Telecom's involvement in the alleged SP bookmaking operations. I take it that the question arises from a comment in the Age newspaper and the Connor report. The only information I am able to provide the honourable senator with at the moment is that there has been a concerted effort at identifying sources of alleged corruption within Telecom. On 29 July 1982 the Managing Director of Telecom met with the heads of the Department of Administrative Services, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Deputy Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police to discuss this matter. Telecom has since continued to co-operate wherever possible with police authorities. A number of Telecom employees have been charged in Victoria and New South Wales. Telecom has co-operated to the fullest extent possible with police authorities to date. Methods of increasing the efficiency and detection of alleged illegal activity are being rigorously pursued.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in the week, on 24 May, Senator Reynolds asked me a question about 14 governments signing a pledge to the World Disarmament Campaign launched last June by the United Nations General Assembly. She asked why Australia's name was not among those countries so pledging. I have the following answer for her. The World Disarmament Campaign was launched on 7 June 1982 by the General Assembly at the Second Special Session devoted to disarmament. The purposes of the campaign are to inform, educate and generate public understanding and support for the objectives of the United Nations in the field of disarmament through:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the widest possible dissemination of information and unimpeded access for all sectors of the public to a broad range of information and opinion on questions of arms limitation and disarmament, and the dangers relating to aspects of the arms race and war, in particular, nuclear war.

In the concluding document of its second Special Session on Disarmament, the General Assembly invited member states to supplement available United Nations resources with voluntary contributions to carry out the objectives of the campaign on a worldwide basis. A number of governments and non-government organisations have pledged financial contributions to the campaign.

As Senator Reynolds observed, the 14 governments which had already announced contributions took part in a pledging ceremony at United Nations headquarters in New York on 22 February where they signed a document entitled 'Protocol regarding the initiation of the World Disarmament Campaign' thereby making official their pledges to the Campaign. Two other governments, Canada and Norway , have also subsequently announced contributions to the campaign. The previous Australian Government took the view that our financial support for the campaign would be covered by Australia's substantial contribution to the regular United Nations Budget. The question of a voluntary contribution to the campaign by the Australian Government, in addition to Australia's contribution to the regular budget of the United Nations, is under active review.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take this opportunity of speaking on the first reading of the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1982-83 to talk briefly about alcohol, its use and misuse and dangers and to make a couple of suggestions to the Government, one of which I have made on other occasions. Moderate drinking, whether it be of beer, wine or spirits, is not generally harmful to our health. In fact alcohol in moderation is regarded by some authorities as having a distinct therapeutic effect. However, we have to remember that alcohol has a sedative effect; it is not a stimulant. Drinking of alcohol can evolve almost imperceptibly into excessive, damaging consumption. It seems from studies that the earlier a person starts consuming alcohol the more likely it is that he will end up an alcoholic. We must never lose sight of the fact that alcohol is a drug and any drug consumed to excess becomes harmful.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the dangers of alcohol are pretty well known to the community but less well known is how much alcohol one can drink in a day before one damages one's body. I believe it is generally held that the body can tolerate about 75 to 80 grams of absolute alcohol in a 24-hour period. That is the maximum that a normal weight person can tolerate and can be handled by the liver without damage occurring. That means that about 100cc or one-tenth of a litre of alcohol by volume can be handled by the body in the same period. Perhaps it would be beneficial for the Senate if I turned that quantity into more familiar amounts. For example, I will take Swan beer, which has an alcoholic content of 5 per cent by volume. To receive 100cc of alcohol one would have to drink 2 litres of Swan beer a day and anything in excess of that amount for a normal weight person will result in damage. A can of beer is 375 mls so one can drink just over five cans of beer in a day without any damage. I am not saying that a person has to drink it in an hour or anything like that, but spread over a 24-hour period, the liver , in particular, will be able to handle it. Of course, one can drink a little less of a stronger beer and a little more of a lighter beer.

The alcohol range in unfortified wines is somewhere between 10 1/2 per cent to 13 1/2 per cent. For instance, red wine usually has an alcohol content of about 12 1/2 per cent. A person can drink about 800 mls a day or slightly in excess of one bottle. The range of alcohol in spirits is from 30 per cent to 45 per cent volume in volume. If one chooses to take a drink with an alcohol content of 40 per cent, which is about the strength of a lot of whiskeys, in a day one can drink only about 7 to 8 ounces.

I have mentioned those facts to once again draw the attention of the Government to the danger of alcohol in amounts that are materially less than some people habitually drink. Once again I ask that the Government look at requesting the manufacturers of all spirits, wines and beers to include a percentage of alcohol on the label. That is being done in some areas but I do not believe it is general enough. That is the first thing that should be done. Although the Government may say that if we do that some people will choose the strongest drink rather than the weaker, many people will gradually get to know the alcoholic percentages in certain beers and the quantities of those beers that can be safely consumed. Maybe we should also include some warning of the danger of alcohol on the label so that people will realise and remember that they are dealing with a dangerous drug.

Alcohol is so dangerous that if we had a book of 100 pages that was written on the dangers of all the drugs that are available to humans at least 90 of those pages would need to be about alcohol. It is by far the most damaging and dangerous drug available legally or illegally. Of course, heroin is dangerous. It tends to kill people a lot more quickly than does alcohol but alcohol does more damage over a longer period to a lot people.

The second thing that I would like the Government to look at, if it is serious in its aim to reduce the consumption of alcohol, is adjusting the excise paid on beer and making it proportional to the quantity of alcohol in it. These days there are not many manufacturers of beer, and the alcoholic content of the beer batches can be held fairly close from one batch to the next. It would seem to be a fairly simple thing to work out what excise would apply to a particular brand and style of beer. That is a step that I believe the Government should take forthwith. As about 60 per cent of the cost of beer is excise a reduction of excise for lower alcohol beers would obviously result in a sizable reduction in the price of low percentage alcohol. Therefore a lot of people would tend to choose those beers more often and in a lot of cases that would be good for their health.

I know that a lot of the labelling that I have asked for is now being done. I am pleased to see that some action is gradually being taken but all wines, beers and spirits should have the percentage of alcohol printed in easily understood terms on their label. The Government should look very closely at reducing the excise for low alcohol percentage beers. For the benefit of honourable senators I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a fairly simple set of figures showing the percentage of alcohol in certain beers that are available generally in this country.
