TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I congratulate the Commonwealth Parliamentary Library Statistics Group for the excellent job it did in compiling these figures. One of the great myths of politics in the past has been the swings for and against particular parties of candidates in individual seats. Over the last two or three elections, the job done by the Library in putting out these very comprehensive results I think has been appreciated by all of us.

SPEECH.PARA: During the election campaign I was attached to Bob Hawke's staff, virtually as a full time member. The reason for that was that at the time when he attained the leadership of the Australian Labor Party he had no full time staff of his own save the two members of staff that all members of Parliament have. The national campaign committee of the Labor Party appointed me to act as liaison officer with all the State branches of the party, except those in New South Wales and Victoria. This meant that, during the campaign, I visited all States with the exception of Victoria. I was in a unique position to observe the progress of the campaign as it affected individual States and candidates.

A number of interesting facts and figures have arisen from the Labor Party's victory. The Labor Party received its highest vote for the House of Representatives-49.5 per cent-since the election of the Fisher Government in 1914. The Labor Party's two-party preferred vote-53.3 per cent-was the highest vote that the Labor Party has ever achieved. Its majority of 25 seats equals the largest ever majority which occurred in 1943 under John Curtin. We lost the seats of Cook and Riverina in New South Wales and Moreton in Queensland by very small margins. If we had won any of those three seats we would have had a record majority.

At this stage I mention the situation concerning the boundaries between the States of New South Wales and Victoria. I think it is very instructive that in New South Wales the Labor Party only won 24 out of the 43 seats-that is, 24 seats to 19 seats-yet we achieved 50.1 per cent of the primary vote and 54.2 per cent of the two-party preferred vote. In Victoria, where we achieved a 50.5 per cent primary vote, that is only an 0.4 per cent difference, and a 54.5 per cent two-party prefered vote, that is only an 0.3 per cent difference, the party won 23 seats out of the 33 seats. I hope that, in any fair redistribution of the boundaries, these changes will result in the Labor Party winning an additional three seats at least in New South Wales. National Party representation in the national Parliament is the lowest since 1961. I will refer later to that matter.

This is the first time since 1947 that the Labor Party has governed nationally and in four States at the one time. The last 12 months have been the most successful in the party's history, winning the Victorian, the South Australian, the Western Australian and also the Federal elections. In the past, the Labor Party had been able to win at a State level. It has not been able to carry the vote through to a Federal level. But this time we have been able to do it continuously over a period of 12 months. If we look at the gallup poll figures printed in the Bulletin yesterday, we see that those figures indicate that in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia the Labor Party would win a State election in any of those States by quite a handsome margin at the present time.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do they show for Tasmania?

—Senator Peter Rae has asked what the figures showed for Tasmania . The figures do not indicate that the party would be successful at this time in Tasmania and Queensland, even though the party has shown a great improvement in Queensland. I omitted to mention that, in a gallup poll printed in the Bulletin about two or three weeks ago, the figures showed that the Labor Party would also win overwhelmingly in New South Wales despite the fact we have been in power in that State since 1976.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, the Labor Party now has a 25 seat majority in the House of Representatives. Of 125 seats we have 75 seats and the coalition parties have 50 seats. This is an exact reversal of the previous position. It is remarkable that , since the election in 1977, there has been a 10.5 per cent swing to the Labor Party throughout Australia. In Victoria, that swing has been a massive 13.8 per cent with the result that the Liberal Party in Victoria, which was once its stongest State, now holds only seven of the 33 Federal seats. In Western Australia, the swing towards the Labor Party has been a staggering 20.2 per cent since 1977. In 1977, we held one of the 11 seats in Western Australia. We now hold eight of the seats and, in this election, the seat of Forrest went to preferences. If one looks again at the gallup poll printed in the Bulletin yesterday, one sees that it indicates that, if a Federal election were held now, the seat of Forrest would also fall to the Labor Party.

During the election campaign, I went to Western Australia on three different occasions. I must admit that, after the State result, I feared that there would be a backlash and that the Labor Party would not achieve the vote that a lot of people expected at a Federal level. But, in fact, the swing to the Labor Party continued. I put on record the fact that, in the Federal division of Stirling where the Labor candidate, Ron Edwards, defeated a sitting Minister, Mr Ian Viner, I witnessed what I thought was the best technical campaign that I had witnessed being run in the whole of Australia.

The Labor Party now has 13 women in the Federal Parliament. This is a record. We have six women in the House of Representatives whereas the coalition parties have none. We also now have seven women in the Senate. Jeannette McHugh, the honourable member for the seat of Phillip in New South Wales, became the first woman ever to represent New South Wales in the House of Representatives. In my opinion, it is the most difficult metropolitan seat in Australia for a woman to win. The fact that she was able to win a seat such as Phillip indicates to me that there is now no seat in Australia that a woman cannot win.

I am reminded of the excellent maiden speech given by Senator Cook. He pointed out that five of the new Labor members elected in the Western Australian State election were women. In fact, one of those candidates won the seat of Pilbara which again was a seat that people have said a woman could not win. I witnessed at first hand the campaign run by Pam Beggs in the seat of Whitford where she achieved a swing of 15.1 per cent to win it. This seat is within the Federal seat of Stirling. It was a seat at the State level that I did not think would ever be won by the Labor Party, let alone by a woman candidate. Wendy Fatin, who won the seat of Canning, achieved the second biggest swing of any House of Representatives candidate in Australia-9.2 per cent.

Another pleasing aspect of our victory was the support that the Labor Party received in rural and provincial electorates. Victory in these areas shows how successful the Labor Party has been in building up support since the rural debacle we suffered in 1975 and 1977. Overall seven seats were won in the rural provincial areas. These were: Calare, Eden-Monaro and Macarthur in New South Wales, Herbert and Leichhardt in Queensland, Bendigo in Victoria, and the seat of the Northern Territory. We almost won the seat of New England where Laurie Daly, the Labor candidate, went very close to defeating Ian Sinclair. The seats of Cowper, Lyne and Riverina, with New England all rural seats in New South Wales, went to preferences. They can now be regarded as marginal seats.

If any Opposition senators or senators in my own party doubt the impact that the Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, had on the election campaign they have only to look at the result in the seat of Flinders. To win the seat on top of a 4.3 per cent swing which had been achieved in the by-election, the Labor candidate who was virtually selected at the last moment and unknown throughout the electorate, achieved a further swing of 6.7 per cent.

As far as I was concerned, the only disappointing result was that we failed to win the seat of Riverina where we required a swing of less than one per cent. Some Press reporters have stated that the only mistake we made in our campaign was in making a second visit to Tasmania when, in fact, we should have gone instead to the Northern Territory. I believe that the only mistake we made was in not visiting Broken Hill and in taking the Labor Party vote there for granted . The Labor Party vote had declined in the previous two elections and it did so again in March this year. Whilst the Labor Party increased its vote in the vast majority of the rural centres within Riverina, it was not able to win the seat because of the decline in its vote in Broken Hill.

However, I mention at this stage the complete hypocrisy of the National Party. During the election campaign, the Labor Party promised the electors of Riverina that, if it was elected, it would subsidise the Letona cannery to the extent of $1m to ensure that that cannery stayed in business. The sitting National Party member, Mr Hicks, campaigned against us and, of course, we won the election even though we did not win the seat of Riverina. He is now going around that electorate trying to make out that he was responsible for the Letona cannery staying open whereas in fact the National Party campaigned against it. TALK.START.PARA: —These figures indicate that the Labor Party achieved an excellent Senate result in New South Wales and Western Australia where a very high proportion of the people who voted for the Labor Party in the House of Representatives also voted for the Labor Party in the Senate, despite the increased informal vote between the House of Representatives and the Senate. The decline of only 2.7 per cent in New South Wales and Western Australia was the best in Australia. By comparison, the Liberal-National Party vote in New South Wales declined 4.5 per cent between the House of Representatives and the Senate. It was the worst State in Australia for the Opposition in this regard. One remarkable feature of the Senate vote in New South Wales was that in 10 seats the Labor Party's Senate vote was higher than its House of Representatives vote. That is quite remarkable when one takes into account the number of candidates and the increased informal vote.

SPEECH.PARA: In New South Wales seats the Senate vote was higher than in the House of Representatives in the following seats: Bennelong 0.6 per cent, Chifley 6 per cent, Grayndler 1.4 per cent, Gwydir 2.4 per cent, Hume 0.8 per cent, Lyne 0.8 per cent, Newcastle 1.4 per cent, Paterson 3.1 per cent, Reid 0.3 per cent and Riverina 1.2 per cent. In Riverina the Labor vote in the House of Representatives was 48.6 per cent and it was 49.8 per cent for the Senate, an increase of 1.2 per cent. For the House of Representatives the National Party vote was 50.4 per cent. However, the vote for the National Party and the Liberal Party in the Senate was 40.5 per cent, a decline of 9.9 per cent. It is a remarkable figure. It is one that I find very difficult to explain and it will probably need market research to find out why that vote declined by 9.9 per cent .

While discussing the results in the Senate election, I must raise issue with Senator Missen who previously in a debate accused the Labor Party of deliberately defeating Senator Neville Bonner in Queensland. The situation was that the Labor Party's national executive ordered all State branches to issue a Senate ticket that was as simple as possible and to avoid jumping from column to column with its preferences. Previous research in New South Wales showed that this practice was likely to cost an additional 6,000 to 8,000 informal votes every time a column was jumped. While Senator Missen is quite right that the Labor Party should have realised that the preferences could have been crucial to Senator Bonner, we were placed in a situation where, to direct our preferences to Senator Bonner, could have resulted in the narrow defeat of a Labor Party Senate candidate.

The Liberals in New South Wales have come to the same conclusion in the past and now issue a simple ticket like the Labor Party does. It is all right to be smart after the event like Senator Missen was, but the Queensland Branch of the Labor Party could have adopted no other course of action. We had to accept-that is, we in the Labor Party-that an altered how-to-vote card could have cost the Labor Party control of the Senate. Senator Bonner's tragic situation-I spoke to him about it twice when I saw him on visits that I made to Queensland-was brought about by mistakes made by the Liberal Party. It was not possible for the Labor Party to try to make amends for what Senator MacGibbon and others had done to Senator Bonner in the Queensland campaign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak on the peaceful use of uranium for the benefit of mankind and how out of touch with reality the Australian Labor Party's policy is in relation thereto. In fact, I want to point out the danger of isolation arising from that policy in an energy hungry world which will witness uranium rich Australia paternalistically deciding that it is not in the interests of other nations that they should purchase our uranium, a needed natural resource. That policy is, in terms of item 9C of the Labor Party' s uranium policy document, a 'total unequivocal commitment to phase out Australia's involvement in the uranium industry'.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to address the matter so much from the point of view of economic loss to Australia because if mining and export are wrong-that is, unduly dangerous to man-either because they will increase proliferation of nuclear weapons or because uranium is unduly dangerous in its utilisation for peaceful means, I will not support the mining or export whatever the economic advantages. However, if the basis of the Labor Party policy is invalid, as I say it is, it is reasonable to look at economic loss. Economic loss to the Northern Territory was ably put last night by Senator Kilgariff. Let me simply say in relation to South Australia that the decision on 22 March to refuse the granting of mining leases to the joint venturers of the Honeymoon uranium mine was a major economic blow. Since 1979 South Australia has seen its share of national expenditure on mining exploration increase from 5.8 per cent to 11.38 per cent. Now, a 10-year, $11m investment has been emasculated, and, according to the South Australian Chamber of Mines, the vetoing of Honeymoon and Beverley uranium mines will see mineral exploration investment in South Australia fall by about $38m this year.

The matter is worth pursuing because, although the bottom line policy of the Labor Party is clear, it is equally clear that the party is in fact very divided . Hopefully, with continued logical debate, the wisdom of a more realistic revision can be brought home. The practical application of that conflict, in the words of the Melbourne finance editor of the Australian, Don Kirkwood, is that it is 'an unhappy mish-mash'. The Australian uranium industry now comprises three types of uranium. Firstly, there is the uranium from the Ranger and Nabarlek mines which can be exported because contracts were signed before July 1982. The second type of uranium is not able to be exported because it was not under export contracts at July 1982. Consequently, the proposed Koongarra, Jabiluka and Yeelirrie mines will not go ahead. However, the Labor Party in July 1982 discovered a new form of uranium that could find its way on to the world export market-uranium which is mined as a by-product with other minerals as will occur at the Roxby Downs mining operation.

The Labor Party's current policy stands in stark contrast to the uranium policy pursued by the Whitlam Government. The Whitlam Government in fact pursued policies which recognised the enormous economic benefits to Australia of large scale uranium development and fulfilled what it saw to be Australia's clear responsibility as an energy rich nation in meeting the energy needs of other countries. In view of this Government's attitude to uranium mining, it is edifying to recall the opening words of the Whitlam Government's statement on uranium mining, tabled in Parliament on 31 October 1974. It states:

. . . this statement is to outline the Government's program for regional development of uranium resources in the Northern Territory: a program which will return substantial economic benefits to Australia from our supply of this vital energy resource to our overseas trading partners who face such grave difficulties in securing their energy requirements . . .

Moreover, the Labor Party less than a decade ago not only saw its responsibility to provide uranium to needy world markets but also recognised the additional economic benefits to Australia in establishing an indigenous uranium enrichment industry. On 2 June 1975 the present Treasurer and former shadow Minister for Minerals and Energy, Mr Keating, had this to say of the Australian uranium enrichment industry:

Japan is interested in moving into nuclear power and enriched fuel. We are prepared to give the Japanese any amount of fuel that they need, enriched if we can do so. The only thing is that we would like to do the enriching. Instead of just sending yellowcake at bargain basement prices we want to get the profit that comes from enrichment.

A year earlier the Minister for Minerals and Energy, Mr Connor, had indicated that the Federal Government would study the potential of the Port Pirie area in South Australia as a possible site for an Australian-Japanese enrichment plant. Unlike the present Government's hostility to uranium mining and milling, the Dunstan Government which had encouraged the exploration of the Honeymoon site, also pushed aggressively for an enrichment plant in South Australia. Very clearly, the Federal Government and State Labor governments gave active support to the development of the Australian uranium industry during the early 1970s. Like the Fraser Government, the Whitlam Government recognised the interdependence between Australia and other countries and sought to ensure that Australia fulfilled its responsibilities as a nation rich in energy resources to supply those resources to others.

In less than a decade Labor's attitude has dramatically shifted ground. Support for the development of this vital energy resource has now become antipathy. This change of policy has occurred in a world in which demand for cheap and abundant energy supplies has not lessened, but has increased over the past 10 years. The world's population has not stopped growing. The expected 8,000m inhabiting this planet in the year 2000 will be demanding not less, but more energy than the 4, 000m currently. Those countries which have been classified as underdeveloped will not remain content with their position relative to those with greater affluence. They will demand more energy than is now consumed in order to reduce the gaps between themselves and the affluent nations. The options for nations seeking more and more energy resources are, and are likely to remain for the next 20 years, limited. Their choice will lie with petroleum, coal, nuclear fission and renewable resources. Of these options, only those of coal and nuclear energy are known to be capable of meeting the world's demands for energy now and in the predictable future.

Given that present proven and probable oil reserves total about 700 billion barrels, with an estimated 300 billion barrels expected to be discovered by the year 2000, it is unlikely that oil will be exhausted in the new century. Man will also continue to need coal for energy for many years. While still in plentiful supply, the large quantities required for the generation of electricity have impacted on its cost. Furthermore, coal supply is ecologically destructive, highly energy consumptive, dangerous and easily subject to disruption in adverse economic conditions.

Much has also been made of the potential of solar energy and, for some, it has become the panacea for the world's future energy requirements. However, even granted that enormous amounts of money could be invested in this potential energy source, recent research indicates that at best it would provide up to only one-tenth of our energy requirements in due course. At the same time, it is argued that it would represent the greatest drain on the earth's heavy metals and raw materials of any technology yet devised by man.

Given our current technology, however, it appears clearly that the world's demand for electricity will be met by the two cheapest forms of generating technology: Coal fired and nuclear power plants. The cost in cents per kilowatt hour of coal fired and nuclear powered electricity generation is half to two- thirds that of oil. It is interesting to note that the results of two recent surveys, one conducted by the United States Department of Energy and the other by the Atomic Industrial Forum, show electricity from nuclear power plants being cheaper than that from coal fired plants of comparable size and age. This relative cheapness indicates, in theory, what is happening in practice, although so often denied by the Labor Party. There is a growing reliance on nuclear energy.

In July 1982 some 277 nuclear power reactors were operating in 24 countries. The reactors are producing electricity, not bombs, as some of the more emotional anti-nuclear proponents would have us believe. Some 300 nuclear power reactors are also presently under construction. When in service they will help to provide an estimated 9 per cent of total world energy requirements. This compares with only 4 per cent in 1980. In some countries reliance on nuclear energy is very much higher. If I had time, I would detail to the Senate the rapid advance in volume of nuclear power being produced in France, Hungary, Taiwan, the Federal Republic of Germany, Korea and Japan.

It is important to note also that the demand for nuclear energy will, in all probability, increase even further after the year 2000. Research undertaken last year by the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis, an independent research institution based in Vienna, concluded that nuclear energy might meet approximately 40 per cent of the world's total energy needs by the year 2030. Those projections include the provision of nuclear power to meet the demands of developing countries, which over the next few decades will be the fastest growing sector of world demand. While energy consumption in the developed countries is projected to grow by only 2 per cent annually, a growth rate of 5 per cent a year is expected for the developing countries up to and beyond the year 2000. By 1995 developing countries are likely to account for nearly one- third of the world's total energy consumption. Because of the trend towards urbanisation, developing countries will require highly centralised energy supply systems. Clearly, nuclear power will form part of the energy systems of those countries. Currently some 13 nuclear power plants, with a total capacity of 6, 200 megawatts, are operating in seven developing countries. A further 24 nuclear power plants, with a capacity of about 16,000 megawatts, are under construction in those seven countries. It can only be concluded from such observations that nuclear power for electricity generation will not go away.

Is it safe? Contrary to ALP uranium policy which claims to have regard to the present unresolved economic, social, biological, genetic, environmental and technical problems associated with the mining of uranium and the development of nuclear power, the World Health Organisation in a report released last month stressed that nuclear power is a safe, viable and necessary alternative to conventional energy sources. The report pointed out that only about 200 tonnes of uranium fuel was needed to operate one electricity power plant for 12 months, against 2 million tonnes of anthracite coal or nine million barrels of oil. Athough the Labor Party believes that the nuclear power industry stands condemned for the absence of procedures for the storage and disposal of radioactive wastes, the report of the World Health Organisation pointed to the studies of disposal in underground depositories which had been going on for the last two decades. It pointed to the burying of high level radioactive wastes 500 metres to 1,000 metres underground in stable rock formations being generally accepted as a safe disposal method.

Will it lead to nuclear weapon proliferation? To halt uranium mining and export because of dangers of nuclear proliferation presumes a direct link which does not exist. One need only refer to the bible of disarmament-the final document of the first United Nations General Assembly Session on Disarmament, which was re- endorsed last year at the Second Special Session-one of the few things that all nations at the session could agree upon. I refer specifically to clauses 68 and 69 of that final document. Because of the shortage of time, I seek leave to incorporate those clauses in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The clauses read as follows-

68. Non-proliferation measures should not jeopardize the full exercise of the inalienable rights of all States to apply and develop their programmes for the peaceful uses of nuclear energy for economic and social development in conformity with their priorities, interests and needs. All States should also have access to, and be free to acquire technology, equipment and materials for peaceful uses of nuclear energy, taking into account the particular needs of the developing countries. International co-operation in this field should be under agreed and appropriate international safeguards applied through the International Atomic Energy Agency on a non-discriminatory basis in order to prevent effectively proliferation of nuclear weapons.

69. Each country's choices and decisions in the field of the peaceful uses of nuclear energy should be respected without jeopardizing their respective fuel cycle policies or international co-operation, agreements, and contracts for the peaceful use of nuclear energy provided that agreed safeguard measures mentioned above are applied.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of non-proliferation started almost from the day of the discovery of splitting the atom. Production of, or the acquisition of, nuclear weapons is a matter of judgment for a country. It is a matter of trust versus distrust. To date, more than 100 nations, including Australia, have declared that they do not consider that domestic development of nuclear weapons increases that security. They have declared this by ratifying the Non-Proliferation Treaty and have agreed to inspection systems under the control of the International Atomic Energy Agency. Active participation in the supply of uranium for peaceful purposes gave Australia an effective presence in ensuring adherence to the safeguards treaty. However, we now have a policy which has as its rationale that the cessation of uranium exports will, on the whole, stop nuclear weapons or the incentives for their spread. But to consider nuclear weapons one must focus on the underlying causes rather than surface symptoms. Denial of uranium, whether or not it is in an enriched form, will not assure that nuclear explosives will not be developed. It may even be counter-productive. The denial of uranium may even force it to obtain a nuclear capability in order to achieve a military solution to growing energy and food needs. If countries are forced to be independent in such areas as the production of uranium, and even more so in enrichment and reprocessing, without international safeguards, what has been achieved by the policy of energy denial?

SPEECH.PARA: This Government, under its present policy, is stepping back from its important role of ensuring non-proliferation in a world which a World Health Organisation report notes will need to satisfy its increasing and high energy demands through the utilisation of a variety of energy resources, including nuclear power. We cannot afford a government whose policy denies the vital role Australia can play in satisfying the essential energy requirements to the rest of the world.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

I present Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1982-83 which, together with Appropriation Bill (No. 6) 1982-83 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1982-83 which I shall introduce shortly, comprises the normal additional estimates for 1982-83. In these Bills, Parliament is asked to appropriate moneys to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures additional to the appropriations made under Appropriation Acts (Nos 1 and 2) 1982-83, the Appropriation ( Parliamentary Departments) Act 1982-83, and the Appropriation Acts (Nos 3 and 4) 1982-83 which Parliament passed at the recent special sittings to provide funds for certain urgent purposes which could not reasonably await the passage of these additional estimates.

Cost and price increases since the Budget was prepared are principal factors underlying the additional estimates. Firstly, although the Budget figuring contained allowances for prospective wage and salary increases, those amounts were not then appropriated, and funds are now required to meet the costs of awards and determinations made before the introduction of the wages pause in December 1982, and because of other factors such as staff increases. Funding is also needed in respect of commitments approved by the previous government after introduction of the Budget, and some urgent initiatives of the Labor Government since taking up office. I will outline some of the more significant of these requirements later in this speech and in that relating to Appropriation Bill No. 6.

The additional appropriations in the three additional Estimates Bills total $1, 047.8 million. Of this, $640.0 million is sought in Appropriation Bill No. 5, $ 407.4 million in Appropriation Bill No. 6 and $0.3 million in Appropriation ( Parliamentary Departments) Bill No. 2

These amounts are offset by in part by savings in the Appropriations made by Appropriation Acts (Nos 1 and 2) 1982-83 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act 1982-83, resulting partly from the Government's determined efforts to achieve savings in expenditure for ongoing programs wherever possible . These savings, amounting to $168.6 million, are detailed under the relevant appropriation headings in the document, 'Statement of Savings Expected in Annual Appropriations', which has been distributed to senators.

The appropriations now sought, together with those made in Appropriation Acts ( Nos 3 and 4) 1982-83, and after allowing for prospective savings, represent a net increase of $1,286.5 million in expenditures financed from annual appropriations. This increase represents approximately two and a half per cent of aggregate budget outlays for the fiscal year. The Government considers this increase unavoidable in view of the need to maintain essential services, to continue at existing levels programs of the previous Government pending their review (where appropriate) and to fund certain requirements that have had to be met by the Government since the election.

I now outline some of the main areas in respect of which the Government has found it necessary to seek additional provisions in Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1982-83 to meet expenditure for the ordinary annual services of the Government. An estimated $275 million is for wages and salaries, $208 million being for non- defence and $67 million for defence purposes, to meet increases in award rates and other wage and salary costs including costs in respect of increased staff ceilings approved by the previous Government for the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Social Security. The amounts include the wage and salary component of additional funds being provided to statutory authorities funded under one line appropriations.

$17.5 million is included under the Department of Communications for the Australian Broadcasting Commission primarily to meet salary and rent increases and thus to enable the Commission to maintain its domestic services.

Under the Department of Defence, provisions totalling some $129.1 million are to meet price and exchange rate effects on the costs of new and replacement equipment and stores including programs for the FA-18, Orion and F1-11 aircraft, the FFG frigates and trucks for the Army. A further $11.9 million is included under the Department for the repair and overhaul of equipment and stores.

$10.4 million is sought for the Department of Defence support for production assistance in respect of the Nomad aircraft and covers increased subsidy and development costs caused by price increases, production overruns and cancellation costs. A further $4.3 million is sought by way of additional working capital advances to various Government defence factories.

An amount of $10.0 million is sought under the Department of Foreign Affairs for the provision of the special grant to Papua New Guinea announced recently by the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Additional provision of $8.8 million is made for CSIRO, primarily to meet the cost of wage and salary increases.
An additional $5.0 million has been provided for grants under the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act, and a like amount is sought for payments under the Export Expansion Grants Act.
Supplementation has also been sought for a number of welfare related programs funded from annual appropriations, including:
$2.0 million in respect of grants administered by the Social Security Department for community welfare agencies;
$3.3 million for payments in respect of accommodation for migrants and refugees ; and

Support for employment related schemes administered by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, including $3.0 million for special training for aboriginals, $2.0 million in respect of the Commonwealth rebate for apprentice full-time training, $1.5 million for community-based youth support schemes and $1.5 million for youth training.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I suggest that we have a cognate debate on the three Appropriation Bills and the three Supply Bills.
—There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

—(Victoria) (1.46)-In speaking briefly in the cognate debate on these Bills, I indicate that the Opposition will not impede the progress of the Bills. The supplementary Appropriation Bills have been subjected to the scrutiny of the Estimates committees at which the explanations were sought from and given by the officers of the departments and the Ministers. As is usual, the Estimates committee reports are available for the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Supply Bills are the normal Supply Bills for the ordinary annual services of government-capital works and services, payments to the Territories and other services. I simply indicate that the Opposition does not wish to impede in any way the progress of these Bills. In fact, we wish them a speedy passage. A number of honourable senators will be speaking in the cognate second reading debate. But I would assume that at the second reading stage we will dispense fairly quickly with the Bills that will provide the funds required by the Government in the normal way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in the second reading debate on this collection of Appropriation and Supply Bills, I wish to deal with Appropriation Bill (No. 5) and Appropriation Bill (No. 6) and to talk about one point in each of these Bills. The point in Appropriation Bill (No. 5) which I wish to address deals with the Department of Defence vote. It relates to debates that took place in Estimates Committee E with respect to what have become known as the flights over Tasmania. Senator Durack and I spent a considerable amount of time inquiring into the background of these operations. I must say that the evidence we have is incomplete. But viewing the evidence fairly dispassionately, there is a very clear inference that two conclusions arise-firstly, that the flights were unauthorised and, secondly, that they could not be classified as normal training flights.

SPEECH.PARA: Some consequences come from this deduction. Firstly, if the flights were not authorised then they were an unauthorised use of defence assets. Therefore, it follows that there was an unauthorised expenditure of public funds. Secondly, as the flights were not training flights, defence assets were tasked against a properly constituted State government proceeding on its lawful way. I realise that it is terribly important to the Australian Labor Party to have the legality of these flights pass unchallenged for a whole variety of reasons, not the least of which is the use of public funds. One of the propaganda points that is terribly important to the Labor Party is the subterfuge that the flights were normal training flights. Many people around Australia say: 'Why cannot aircraft of the Royal Australian Air Force fly over any part of Australian territory? We are all Australians, aren't we?' Of course, that is fair enough, Air Force aircraft can fly over Australia in the same way as civil aircraft can fly over nearly every part of the country. But if the flights were not properly tasked and it was not a lawful operation, it becomes a different matter entirely.

I would like to amplify the unauthorised nature of the flights. The Director General of Joint Plans and Operations was asked which of the reference documents the Air Force has to cover situations such as this were applied in this case. There are two documents-'Policies and Procedures for Defence Force Assistance to the Civil Community' and 'Defence Force Aid to the Civil Power'. The Air Commodore admitted quite frankly that there was confusion as to which document was used as the source of the authorisation. It followed as a consequence of that that we questioned a particular document. The witness was given the choice of saying which clause in those two documents he thought was the most relevant one. Again, we found that there was quite a degree of ambiguity. This is important because these documents specifically instance the cases in which RAAF aircraft or RAAF assets can be used to aid the civil power or the civil community. One obviously has to have a requirement for this in cases of floods, emergencies and things such as that. So the fundamental point-what justification the Air Force had for tasking these aircraft-could not be established.

Then we got on to the interesting business of finding out how the request was placed with the Air Force. It turned out that the Director of Operations, Group Captain Waterfield, had received a telephone call. A signal was not sent. Nothing was ever put in writing. It was just a verbal call from Mr Glare in the Attorney-General's Department to the director of Operations of the Air Force. On the basis of that telephone call service aircraft were tasked into operations against a State government. I find that to be a rather surprising thing. I accept that the Director of Operations of the Air Force must have some degree of initiative and must be able to use his own judgment because clearly emergency situations arise in which he has to react immediately. But I would expect that the Director of Operations would satisfy himself as to the authority of the person who made the request. In effect, what happened was that the Director of Operations simply received a telephone call from a person whom he did not know and whom he had never met. This person was a civilian who was not associated with the Defence Department at all. The consequence of that was that low level Mirage flight and the flight the day after by the RF111C.

The Air Force is often called upon to provide emergency services. It is doing that today in regard to the floods. The Air Force does that very well and to the great benefit of the community. The Air Force frequently gets involved in the whole field of search and rescue. I have never had recourse to make a personal request to the Air Force but I do know people in Queensland who have. For example, requests are frequently made for helicopter assistance in search and rescue operations. The experience in those circumstances is that the requests are always expeditiously and efficiently dealt with but that RAAF station Amberley always finds out who is making the request and checks out its authorisation very quickly, but quite completely. Apparently this was not done in this case. As one who knows Service officers very well, I muse on the reasons this took place. Group Captain Waterfield, the officer in charge, in evidence recorded on page 154 of the Hansard record of Senate Estimates Committee E, said :
As I said, because of the way the request or the task was passed to me-I emphasise that it was passed to me as a task already approved by the Minister and not a request-I simply arranged the task.

That leads us to consider the place of Mr Glare in this matter. Did he overstate his case? What form of words did Mr Glare put to the Director of Operations? Did he go beyond what reasonably could have been expected of an officer? We do not know the answers. We have no documentation on the matter. The matter probably will not ever be resolved. Did Mr Glare, a zealous officer working for a new Attorney-General telephone the Air Force and say: 'It is all right; no troubles. We have the approval of the Minister for Defence and the A-G. It's right-we're ready to go. We want this immediately before the court case tomorrow'? Was Group Captain Waterfield dazzled by this authority and the authoritative tone in which this was put to him? Did he say: 'Right, that will be no trouble. We will arrange that for you'? Did he-Mr Glare-go back to the Attorney-General and say: 'No troubles, Minister, it is all set. I fixed it for you in a minute and the Air Force will look after it'? We will never know the answer to that but we can reflect on what might have happened.

I will deal with the aspect that the flights were training flights. It is fair to say that we only got hesitant and evasive answers from the two RAAF operational officers who answered these questions. Any people who read the Hansard transcript of the Committee's proceedings can confirm that for themselves. The implication was quite clear there that they were not normal training flights. I quote a reply to a question reported on page 155 of Hansard. Senator Durack asked:
Would it be in any way appropriate to describe that as a re-routed training flight?
Group Captain Waterfield replied:
This is the Mirage flight you are referring to?
Senator Durack answered:
The Mirage flight.
Group Captain Waterfield replied:
No, that Mirage flight was specifically tasked.

It is interesting to read the letter of the Chief of Defence Force Staff. Air Chief Marshal Sir Neville McNamara is a very great soldier who served this country well. On 12 April he wrote to the Chief of the Air Staff. For those honourable senators who do not know, neither the CDFS nor the Chief of the Air Staff was advised that these sorties were on or being planned by the Air Force, which is a matter that alarmed them both. Air Chief Marshal Sir Neville McNamara wrote to the Chief of the Air Staff on 12 April and he selected his words with great precision. I will quote from the first paragraph of his letter. He said:

. . . in particular I am extremely concerned that the matter appears to have been handled as a routine task within your Directorate of Operations and authorization given without your or my knowledge. At the very least this action demonstrates a lack of awareness of the political sensitivities and even deeper consequences of the use of Defence Force assets on an issue such as the Franklin River Dam.

Quite clearly the CDFS in no way and at no time regarded these as routine training flights. Further evidence that was advanced to the Committee showed that at no time were these flights tasked before the dam flights. The flights over the dam were tasked first of all. Then the excuse of training flights or extra tasks was added afterwards to justify them.

I do not wish to take up much more of the time of the Senate in dealing with this matter, but one of the things which concerned me related to security. I do not wish to go through some of the security breaches which may or may not appear in the documentation tabled by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), but I will refer to one which was in the file of the Department of Defence. It is signed by Squadron Leader Kennedy. Paragraph 2 of his letter relates to an inquiry by Mr Glare. Mr Glare inquired into the operational performance of the aircraft and the photographic gear used. Apparently a discussion took place over an open telephone line concerning what was fairly confidential information because the next part of the letter states that the section on photo- reconnaissance capabilities of the RF111C was deleted on grounds of national security. I wonder what sort of security clearance Mr Glare had and what precautions were taken to avoid an intercept on that telephone line. I will not proceed with that matter much further.

We have had quite a degree of censure in this chamber against the Attorney- General, and I think it was quite justified. The point is that I do not think the Attorney realised the enormity of what he did at the time. I do not think we will convince him of that in the short term. Clearly the most culpable person in this whole business, the person who has avoided all public censure, is the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) in another place because he is the person who must assume responsibility for this matter. It is his Department, his action and his authorisation. He cannot evade the responsibility, and I believe he was grossly negligent in this. He is the person who should be brought to charge. He does not appreciate what it is for a serviceman to be tasked against people of his own nation. The greatest act of disloyalty one can ask a serviceman to perform is to operate against the people of his own country. I make a parallel with the medical and dental practitioners. If the Minister for Defence were in one of those professions and acted in the way he did in regard to the spy flights over the dam, he would be up on a charge of criminal negligence.

I turn now to Appropriation Bill (No. 6) which deals with the expenditure of $ 407m. That means that everyone in Australia is contributing roughly $27 under this Appropriation Bill. Some of that money is well spent but we need to be convinced that it is all being well spent. In this Bill there is an appropriation to shore up Trans Australia Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd and the Australian National Line to the extent of $240m-$90m for TAA, $90m for ANL and $ 60m for Qantas. I wish to speak only on the expenditure for TAA. I make the general point that governments simply cannot run commercial enterprises. Where they try to, it costs the taxpayer very dearly-not only in money but also in inconvenience and a whole lot of other things. We are moving into a situation of state monopoly of health services in this country. I shudder to think of the cost of that to the Australian community. It will go through the roof. More than that, we will get a really rotten service because there will be no competition as a result of it.

The ANL is a classical example of commercial mismanagement. Honourable senators will remember that last year we had the farcical business of whether someone from the Merchant Service Guild of Australia or the Seamens Union of Australia would operate a winch on the new coalburning River Boyne for Comalco on the Weipa-Gladstone route. That Gilbert and Sullivan exercise ran for weeks, if not months, and cost all the parties involved tens of millions of dollars. The blame for that can be squarely laid on the managerial incompetence of the Australian National Line. At a future date I will come back to that and go into it in more detail.

I return now to TAA. The first point is that capitalisation of TAA is too low. I do not think anyone on this side of the chamber has any argument about that at all. Without adequate capitalisation life in the commercial world is very difficult. TAA needs to have more capital and I am pleased to see that it has been given more capital, but the fundamental point has to be made that it is a task of management to service the capital it already has, whether in the form of shareholders' funds or raised as borrowings in the market place. TAA simply has not serviced the capital that it has. A classic case was the superannuation inadequacies which TAA has never ever funded. The government of the day has supported TAA and bailed it out on at least two occasions that I can think of. The last time was within the last 12 months when the Government put over $200m- possibly $220m-into its superannuation fund. TAA cannot say that it does not have the resources to cope because Ansett Airlines of Australia operates under the same situation and does provide superannuation funding for its employees.

We are asked for a large sum of money to go to TAA this year. Unfortunately we do not have its annual report yet. We do not know how big a loss it will make. Rumors around the market place are that it will be somewhere between $10m and $ 20m. I hope it is not as high as that, but it might be. The Parliament has a relevant interest in knowing how much money TAA is losing when Parliament has to put money in to shore it up.

We are paying the price at present for the two-airline agreement in this country. Because the two-airline agreement does not provide for commercial competition between the two major carriers-in fact it preserves them, protects them and guarantees that they can stay in business-we have a hopelessly inefficient internal airline system in this country. The consequences of that are many from the travellers point of view. This Parliament has an interest in looking after the interests of the Australian traveller for he is priced out of the market. If one looks at the relevant figures one will find that traffic around Australia has decreased dramatically. The latest figures I have show that there was a 6 per cent drop in the number of passengers travelling through the Brisbane domestic terminal in the last quarter of 1982 and that the number of people travelling by air in Australia as a whole was down by 9.3 per cent in the last quarter of 1981. I do not have a later figure than that. It is simply a fact that it has become too expensive for people to travel by air.

TAA has contributed to this development by operating in an inefficient way and putting up its fares to cope with its inefficient operation. It has been losing money for years and there is no reason why it should have been. It gets mixed up with extravagant operations like Hertz. I do not know how much that Hertz hire car business has cost TAA but it has certainly cost it millions and millions of dollars and it is still not making a profit out of it. There is no reason on earth for an airline company to own a hire car company, least of all when it is bleeding to death on it.

TAA does not seem to show any commonsense in the market-place. It fritters money away on such things as the bone china purchase. It ridiculed Ansett when that airline went into the business of providing bone china. The correct commercial approach was to let Ansett go and pay the commercial penalty of an unwise move. But, after ridiculing Ansett and saying that it would cost Ansett half a million dollars a year to replace breakages alone, the genii on the board of directors of TAA turned around and spent $850,000 buying gold line Wedgwood bone china for TAA. That is an entirely unnecessary charge on the passengers who fly in Australia. It increases the operating cost of the aircraft because it increases the weight that has to be carried. Weight is highly critical on an aircraft. Breakages have to be replaced. It is all unnecessary.

Let us look at the advertising aspect. I made some Press releases in June last year about the need to sell TAA to protect the Australian public. The reaction to that proposal was the 'Our TAA' theme. I suppose that I should be flattered that I influenced the public projection of an airline but the 'Our TAA' theme riles me even more than the way TAA loses money. The final mindless piece of advertising is this two-page spread-God knows how many hundreds of thousands of dollars it is costing-which one has to read to find out what it is all about- whether it is for an airline, a shoe company or something like that. All that TAA lists here is 12 ways in which it has managed to lose money over the last few months. I will be very interested, at the relevant time, to know what that campaign is costing us. I would have thought that the primary concerns of those running an airline were to advertise safety and things like the convenience of its flight schedules and the frequency of flights, to establish on-time departures and arrivals and to fly people in reasonable comfort and, above all, at low cost. But we never see evidence of that in any airline advertising in Australia.

Quite simply, passengers are not interested in luxury meals, free drinks and things like that. They do not travel on aircraft for a hedonistic experience. They travel on aircraft because they want to go, say, from Brisbane to Sydney or from Sydney to Melbourne. All the legs in Australia except for the Western Australian run are about one hour in length. Anyone can sit there without being filled with wine and food. Honourable senators would find that an airline that operated a no frills service would sweep all the others from the board. Air travel is simply a utilitarian service in Australia today.

I return to the theme of 'Our TAA'. As I said earlier, that particularly riles me. If I am a TAA shareholder I want to go to a shareholders' meeting. Furthermore, I wish to move at that meeting to vote the present board of directors out of office. After that, I wish to sell my shareholding. TAA is something that this country can well do without as a government instrumentality. It is a commercial operation that is best handled by private enterprise. Until we get TAA out of government hands, until it can compete equally with Ansett, East-West Airlines Ltd or any other airline which chooses to operate in Australia on an equivalent commercial basis, we cannot get rid of the two- airline agreement. While we have the two-airline agreement, we have this nonsense of two-page advertisements about an airline that has taken the initiative 12 times in the last few months.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.
(Quorum formed).

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have a statement to read on behalf of the President. Honourable senators will recall that both Sir Condor Laucke and Sir Harold Young, the President's predecessors in the office of President, established accommodation advisory committees to review the allocation of accommodation on the Senate side of the building. When this arrangement was first made in 1980, the then Speaker also appointed a committee of members to advise him on the allocation of accommodation on the House of Representatives side of the building. The aim of the Presiding Officers was to achieve the best utilisation of space available for senators and members without diminishing the efficient functioning of the chambers or the services necessary for senators and members to discharge their responsibilities. In addition, it was regarded as a minimum requirement that every senator and member should have a separate room. Accordingly, past Presidents have made offices on the Senate side of the building available on a permissive occupancy basis to members of the House of Representatives to avoid members having to share rooms.

INTERJECT.PARA: Shortly after the election of the present President, he reviewed the reports of the two previous Presidents' accommodation advisory committees. These committees made a number of recommendations designed to improve senators' accommodation. The President also reviewed the response of the previous Speaker to the proposals of those committees. Subsequently he was asked by the Speaker, Dr Jenkins, whether further rooms could be made available on the Senate side to accommodate four members who are currently forced to share offices. He is now able to advise honourable senators that he and Mr Speaker have directed that certain administrative staff of the Joint House Department be moved from Parliament House to the Hotel Kurrajong. They have also directed that the Secretariat to the Joint Committee on the New Parliament House be moved from Parliament House. Both of those proposals were recommendations of the President' s Accommodation Advisory Committee. Once these moves have taken place, one member of the House of Representatives will be accommodated in the office vacated by the new Parliament House Committee secretariat and the other three members will occupy rooms on the Senate side.

In addition to these arrangements, the President has requested Black Rod to prepare detailed proposals to improve the accommodation available to senators in accordance with other recommendations of the previous Presidents' accommodation advisory committees. When these proposals are finalised the President will further review the matter. At this stage the intention is to commence a program of progressive improvements to senators' accommodation in Parliament House early in the winter recess. The President concludes by thanking those senators who served on the President's accommodation advisory committees and, in particular, the sub-committee of Senators Jessop, Coleman, Scott and Chipp which conducted the main investigation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As a member of the original President's Accommodation Advisory Committee and sub-committee, I compliment both the President and the Speaker on adopting two of the recommendations of that committee. As I remember, at least Senator Coleman and Senator Scott were on that Committee with me.
—I was there too.

—I am sorry, Senator Jessop was the distinguished Chairman. It was one of the most efficient committees on which I have ever served. The Committee encountered a singular lack of co-operation from the previous Speaker-I say that advisedly-and from the staff of the House of Representatives who were advising him. Senators, I believe it is fair to say, bent over backwards to assist members of the House of Representatives in their accommodation on this side of the House, but we needed some co-operation from the Speaker and the staff of the House of Representatives which certainly was not forthcoming. Whilst I am very pleased to accept your action and congratulate you, Mr President, I think it is fair to say that if the Speaker and the staff of the House of Representatives were more receptive to change, the comfort and convenience of most honourable senators, particularly those who now are forced to have very small rooms, would be considerably improved. It is my view, notwithstanding the progress that you have made, that further improvements could be made in the facilities available to some honourable senators who now work in cramped conditions.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN-NEW ZEALAND CLOSER ECONOMIC RELATIONS TRADE AGREEMENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Senator Lewis:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Government on finalising this agreement which was negotiated during the term of the previous Government. The history of our relations with New Zealand over a period of years has been reflected in a number of agreements which have developed vigorous trade across the Tasman Sea. Finally in March 1980 there was a meeting of Mr Fraser and Mr Muldoon following which there was a joint communique about developing closer economic relations. From that time until November 1982 Mr Doug Anthony, the then Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources, was involved in extensive negotiations with his New Zealand counterpart until, finally, on 10 November 1982 an agreement between the two governments was signed. This agreement was prepared following that agreement and was signed by Mr Lionel Bowen on behalf of Australia. It came into force on 1 January 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: The aim of this agreement is the gradual and progressive reduction of all remaining trade barriers between our two nations. The reason is that each country is the other country's major export market for manufactured goods- Australia with a population of 15 million and New Zealand with a population of 3 million. Clearly, Mr Anthony and the former Government are to be complimented for trying to develop a free trade arrangement between our two nations, and I wish the two nations success. It is my belief that it is most unfortunate that in 1900 New Zealand did not become a State of the Commonwealth of Australia, or whatever we might have called it. New Zealand is no further away from Canberra than is Western Australia. It is a great pity that we do not have an additional State, New Zealand.

However, I also wish to congratulate Mr Anthony on his consultations with industry representatives, both primary and secondary, about their concerns with his agreement. Primary and secondary industry representatives on both sides of the Tasman have been concerned, and the negotiations and consultations were extensive. I am aware of problems in the horticultural and agricultural field- including potatoes, timber, fish, wine; and in textiles, steel and industry. Those problems have occurred on both sides of the Tasman. I mention, for example , one manufacturer in New Zealand who set up a company there for the purpose of exporting a product to Australia. He was taking advantage of New Zealand's lower wage structure and export incentives in order to export the product to Australia . Of course, that company is now in grave difficulty because Australian manufacturers will be able to set up in competition with him without his having advantages in the form of export incentives.

In particular I have been concerned about potatoes because of the number of potato growers in western Victoria-in the south-west and in the Ballarat area- who have been concerned about their inability to compete with their New Zealand counterparts. New Zealand has a lower wage structure than does Australia. It has a very substantial currency advantage over Australian dollars, and New Zealand manufacturers get export incentives and subsidies worth about 20 per cent, as estimated by Mr Anthony. I believe that over time the currency will balance out these differences, but in the short term there will be difficulties and many adjustments will have to be made. However, that may very well mean that Australian growers, Australian primary producers and Australian secondary industries, ought really to be looking at the opportunities which will arise as a result of this agreement, as well as watching the concerns. Certainly we will watch the agreement with great concern to ensure that people in our areas are not disadvantaged.

I shall mention very quickly other problems. For example, inducements are given to companies to establish in a certain area. Local governments and State governments have been known to build roads for companies, give land, reduce rates and subsidise their borrowings, all as decentralisation incentives. These are not properly known by an examination of the tariff barrier but are clearly of enormous advantage and could create great difficulties. In fact, those incentives certainly create difficulties of completion between Australian States . I also mention the problem of manipulation of competition by giant organisations. I hope that will not run astray as the result of this agreement.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEFENCE FORCE RETIREMENT AND DEATH BENEFITS AUTHORITY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82
Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment on the report of the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Authority primarily because of the impact of the Government's announcement in the economic statement to tax lump sum superannuation payments. My comments will relate in general to lump sum payments. They will relate specifically to service men and women who are eligible for lump sum payments, which are now to be subject to tax. The whole of the system as put forward-I am aware that there are now rapid attempts to alter it-is offensive in every principle. I will demonstrate this first of all in practice and then in principle. Let us suppose that a person, over 30 or 40 years, has contributed to a fund and that fund yields him upon retirement at, say, 60 years of age, the lump sum of $50,000-a small enough capital saving over that time. It would be small enough anyhow because if he invested it at 12 per cent over the years he would then be getting only in the order of $125 a week. That would be a modest enough income on which to survive.

SPEECH.PARA: What is going to happen to such people? Not only will they be robbed of $15,000 -that is 30 per cent-straightaway but, of course, the capacity of their remaining capital to earn income will also be robbed. Their income will be cut to roughly $81 a week. Taking these as rough figures we can see that, on the one hand, $15,000 will be taken away in capital and on the other, $44 a week in round figures will be taken from them.

Let us look at the position of a person who retires at 60 years of age. On ordinary actuarial expectations, he has 17 years of life left to him. The Government is taking away from him not only $15,000 but also that extra $44 a week, which in present dollar terms is something like $39,000. So the Government is managing, under this scheme, to rob people receiving the most modest lump sums-the ordinary trade unionist, the ordinary low wage earner in the public sector-of huge amounts. That is the particularity of the matter. Of course, at the very heart of it is the socialist principle which is so repugnant. The Government is saying: 'We dislike people accruing capital and then using that capital for their own purposes. We will either force them into putting that capital into institutions through buying an annuity and thus destroy the capital and the ability of the people to invest it. Failing that, we will take from them 30 per cent plus the earning capacity of that 30 per cent over the remainder of their life'.

The community of Australia is one of the most egalitarian societies on earth. In Australia there are fewer extremes between the rich and the poor than in most other countries. Most people are of moderate means. The Government's action does not affect just a few people. That must be understood, because the suggestion is that superannuation is for wealthy people. The Opposition does not say that at all. Nearly two million employees contribute actively to superannuation funds. There were 1.82 million of them several years ago. The number would be larger now. The incomes of those people range from small incomes of a few thousand dollars a year right through the scale. Those people are being denied their right to accrue capital. I find that grossly offensive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also speak on the report of the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Authority in order to draw attention to the Government's moves to institute a tax on lump sum superannuation payments . As I pointed out during my brief remarks yesterday on this matter, the fact is that people retiring from the fund covered by this report are, generally speaking, in the most modest of circumstances. Indeed, the report shows that the average lump sum payable on retirement of people from the Defence Force is of the order of $38,000-a very modest sum, I believe all honourable senators would agree. In those circumstances, we are not talking about semi-millionaires or people who collect golden handshakes of the order of $300,000, $400,000 or $500, 000. We are talking about average people in average circumstances who, as a result of their service in the Defence Force and perhaps having been transferred around the country or to other places, have had no time to acquire a home and who because of the terms of their employment as members of the Defence Force, are faced with retirement at a relatively early age. I instanced the case of a major in the Army, who by virtue of his terms of employment is required to retire at the age of 45 or thereabouts. A person in those circumstances needs to work at least another 20 years to make his own way and build up some capital for his retirement. How can he be regarded as being in the same circumstances as somebody who is retiring at the age of 65 years who has his best earning years behind him, finished the education of his children, and built up an asset in his home? I would say that person is in a very different category.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that people in the Defence Force require consideration, as do a number of others. I would like to draw the attention of the Senate to Mr Keating 's remarks last Thursday night. If we look at page 60 of the economic statement which was made last Thursday night we recall that, included in the lump sum superannuation payments to be taxed were the following items: so-called golden handshakes, other severance payments, contractual termination payments, payments for unused sick leave, amounts other than bona fide redundancy payments-whatever that is; it obviously brings in an element of discrimination-and other amounts which are paid in compensation for loss of office or employment. In other words, there is a distinct category of persons-I presume mostly those in small business areas or those in public or private employment-who specifically will be caught by this legislation and who in no way could be deemed to be in a position of retirement. I think that is one of the critical issues raised in this report and which demand an answer from the Government.

One or two other items also require attention. In Question Time today I mentioned the possibility of the Government applying this tax to lump sums payable to widows upon the death of the superannuitant. That has not been denied by this Government. In fact, from answers to questions in the other place by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) indications are that they are to be included. I ask a further question in that regard. Will such a tax, if applied to lump sums paid in that fashion, also apply to whole of life policies which are paid upon the death of the life assured? Will the ordinary proceeds from life insurance also be covered by this legislation? In the terms of the economic statement from the Labor Government it seems they will be. That opens vast questions of the security of--

TALK.START.PARA: —You quote me the section that says that or implies it.
—Page 60 of the economic statement.
—Quote it.

—I just did. The further point that I would like to make seems to be the most overlooked point of all in relation to this matter. Surely the Government would have enough nous to realise it if it introduced a system such as this-a taxation of lump sum payments-with the object of catching those people who have the most significant amount to save in taxes; I refer to those who are on the larger end of the superannuation scale, those who may get a $300,000 or $ 400,000 benefit. The Government is providing the means for those people to enter into, to use Senator Walsh's words, the biggest rort in tax avoidance that has ever been established in this country. The Government is giving a wonderful incentive for people to want to do that. I believe that this Government will rue the day that it has considered this matter because it will have to live with the consequence of enormous tax avoidance that will make the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes look like a game of bingo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reply very briefly. I just want to place on record my contempt for the humbugs in the Opposition who know very well that they should have taken a step along these lines in all the years that they were in government but never at any stage did they have the courage to do it.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82
Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Senator Martin:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for the opportunity to speak again on the report of the Australian Film Commission. In my comments yesterday I congratulated the Australian Film Commission on a very comprehensive report but regretted that once again, as with most reports that come into this place, it is much too late to be relevant to the period that the report refers to. Is it not possible for an instruction to go to all the statutory authorities stating that their report should be presented to the Parliament at least during the Budget session when the period that they relate to is at least more relevant than it is now?

SPEECH.PARA: I am very pleased to notice that the report mentions the audio-visual programs which have been completed and the types of work that are being done for the various government departments, including the Department of Defence, the Department of Transport, the Commonwealth Employment Service and, in particular, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. But one has to question, almost straight away, whether an audio visual program such as Your Skills in Australia, which details in English work opportunities in Australia for intending migrants, is still relevant, given that there have been a number of changes in policy since the period covered by this report, July 1981 to June 1982. Changes made in policy in relation to trade skills, of course, do frequently apply as we all know. Amendments are constantly being made to legislation which could confuse intending migrants. I refer not necessarily to those people in the United Kingdom but those in other countries who have an intention to migrate to this country. They see a film of this nature, which could be available through our stations overseas, and are made aware that their particular skill is required. They may make an application and find that government policy has changed to the extent that those skills are no longer required. As I have said, a lot of these problems could be eased if we received these reports a little earlier.

I have one question relating to the Australian Film Commission. I do not know whether it is in its power to do something about the matter. It was raised with me last October on a Qantas flight when I went to the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference in the Bahamas. I thought that it was exceedingly strange that where the Australian Film Commission gives monetary support or assistance to the making of a film its distribution is normally undertaken by an overseas company. In effect, this means that Qantas-Australia's own airline-does not have available to it immediately the opportunity to screen those films on the flights leaving Australia or even coming to Australia.

I thought it was rather a peculiar circumstance that required, for instance, Mad Max II to be distributed through, I think, Fox International. The Qantas buyer of films has to journey to the United States once every three or four months to be able to initiate a program of films to be shown on Qantas flights. Perhaps that is something that the Australian Film Commission may care to turn its attention to. Such films are Australian made. Most of them are subsidised by Australian taxpayers' money and we do not deny governments their right to do that at all. I congratulate governments-both past and present-on their attitude to the making and subsidisation of Australian films. However, I do question, with the amount of expertise and talent that we have in Australia, whether it is absolutely necessary that we have to use organisations that are primarily located in the United States of America for the distribution of Australian made films on the world market.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON SECURITY AND INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement
Debate resumed from 19 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Senate take note of the statement.
Upon which Senator Chaney had moved by way of amendment:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert:
''the Senate is of the opinion that the terms of reference should be amended by omitting paragraph (c) and substituting the following paragraph:
'(c) further to the inquiry in relation to paragraphs (a) and (b) above:

(i) all the circumstances, including the actions of the Government, surrounding the expulsion from Australia of Mr Valeriy Nikolayevich Ivanov, First Secretary, Embassy of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, and the involvement of Mr Harvey David Mathew Combe in those circumstances; and

(ii) whether or not the Prime Minister, the Special Minister of State or any other Minister or any senior Government adviser disclosed confidential information in any way relating to the decision to expel from Australia Mr Valeriy Nikolayevich Ivanov; and' ''.
And upon which Senator Macklin had moved by way of further amendment:

Proposed sub-paragraph (c) (ii), after 'senior Government advisor', insert 'or the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives and the Leader and Deputy Leader of the National Party in the House of Representatives'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Debate on this matter has taken place in the Senate on two previous occasions; we are now coming back to the matter for the third time. Although that may seem to be a lengthy consideration of the matter, it is certainly one of the greatest importance. As time goes on and as the Government becomes more and more embarrassed and evasive about this whole matter, I believe that the Senate is taking a responsible step in giving this question the utmost scrutiny and consideration.
