The Senate is mainly considering an amendment to the terms of reference for the Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence Agencies, which was the subject of a ministerial statement put down in this place by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) on the motion that the Senate take note of his statement and, in particular, the terms of reference for that Royal Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition made it clear that it welcomed the setting up of this Royal Commission. The judicial audit of the intelligence agencies and, in particular, of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation accords entirely with the policy that the Opposition pursued when in government and with a promise we made in the election campaign that if we were returned to government we would set up a judicial audit of ASIO before the end of this year. We made that statement in August 1981 when the present Director-General of ASIO was appointed by us. At that time we announced that during the occupancy of that office by the present Director-General we would establish a judicial audit of ASIO. I think it is appropriate that such an audit is made from time to time. The last audit was made some years ago by Mr Justice Hope, and it is particularly fortunate that he is prepared to undertake this exercise again as he has a greater knowledge of these matters than anyone else who might have been invited to do the job.

Attention has been focused mainly on the terms of reference of the Royal Commission. Indeed, these terms of reference were very hastily announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), I think before there had been any Cabinet consideration of it or discussion about it. One term of reference arose out of the highly embarrassing circumstances created by the Government relating to the expulsion of Mr Ivanov and the handling by the Government of the relationship between Mr Ivanov and Mr Combe. One of the terms of reference included by the Government for the Royal Commission to review reads:
. . . all the circumstances surrounding the expulsion from Australia of Mr Ivanov-including the actions of the Government-and the involvement of Mr David Combe in those circumstances.

Although it is true that that term of reference includes the words 'including the actions of the Government' the Opposition has taken the view that that phrase is not clear enough and does not cover the very serious and worrying circumstances that have taken place since the decision made by the Government on 21 April to expel Mr Ivanov. A whole series of extraordinary and most worrying events has occurred since then. Therefore, we believe that it should be spelt out in the terms of reference that the Royal Commission should take into account all these matters. Accordingly, the Opposition has moved that the terms of reference should be expanded to include the following provision:

whether or not the Prime Minister, the Special Minister of State or any other Minister or any senior Government advisor disclosed confidential information in any way relating to the decision to expel from Australia Mr Valeriy Nikolayevich Ivanov.

We have done that because we believe that it is important for this Royal Commission to consider these matters and, if the Royal Commission is so minded and believes that it is necessary, to consider whether there has been a disclosure of confidential information by others. Senator Macklin proposes an amendment which will further widen that proposal and include the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives and the Leader and Deputy Leader of the National Party in that House. We certainly have no objection whatsoever to the terms of the Royal Commission being widened to cover fully this situation so that the Royal Commissioner can give the widest consideration to all the matters about which very great concern exists in not only the Opposition but also the Parliament and the community generally.

I do not propose to cover again all the circumstances and the issues which have emerged, which have really been created by the abject failure and mishandling of this matter by the Government, particularly the Prime Minister and the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans). When we were debating this matter last Thursday afternoon Senator Sir John Carrick made a most notable contribution. He raised all the matters that I believe are of deep concern. However, I am speaking in this debate because some further, very strange events have occurred since the debate last Thursday. These events surround some of the Prime Minister's actions over the last week and the non-answers to questions which were addressed today to the Attorney-General by myself and Senator Collard in relation to some of these matters.

Apparently the Government has decided that, having set up this Royal Commission , it will now hide behind the action that is taken. It has determined that it will not take part in any debate or answer any questions in the Parliament about the matter. Indeed, if any motions are directed against the Government the Prime Minister will simply refuse to take part in the debate. He is obviously running away from a problem. He has obviously something to hide. He obviously believes that he will be able, through confidentiality considerations which attach to this matter and must attach at least to some part of the Royal Commission's inquiry, somehow or other to be protected by this method from properly facing the music, the Parliament and the people.

In contrast to the policy that the Prime Minister has followed in this place he has been prepared to be interviewed in the public arena. But he has not been any more forthcoming in that arena than he has been in this place. He has been making some further, extraordinary statements designed to cover up, to obfuscate and to confuse people as much as possible about the role that he has played in this whole sorry and sordid episode. The matters about which I speak were canvassed last weekend by the Prime Minister in an interview with Mr Peter Costigan which was reported in the Melbourne Herald last Saturday. He also went on the Mike Walsh Show, I think it was, on Monday this week. On the Mike Walsh Show he said that he was nothing less than amazed at the gratuitous and insane observations that he should have called Mr Combe in and tipped him off. That is the phrase that the Prime Minister uses. Nobody else has ever suggested that there was a need for Mr Combe to be tipped off or anything of that sort.

What had been suggested, what still is suggested and what the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General still have to face up to and answer, is the very real proposition that, having received a report concerning Mr Combe and these very serious allegations about his conduct, Mr Combe should have been given at least some knowledge of the allegations and some opportunity of answering them. It is not a question of tipping him off at all. But that is the way in which the Prime Minister seeks further to evade the issue. That is not the case that has been made against Mr Combe.

The Prime Minister, in his interview with Mr Costigan, as reported in the Herald, said on several occasions that he would have been breaking the law if he had given Mr Combe any opportunity to answer the allegations that were made against him. But the Prime Minister has not been able to explain why a Prime Minister and an Attorney-General of this country would be breaking the law by giving someone at least some knowledge of allegations that had been made and an opportunity of answering them. That would be a pretty strange state of our law if that was the effect. Not unnaturally, some questions have been addressed to the Prime Minister as to what law he would have been breaking. No answer has officially been made, although apparently his office fed out that it was the Crimes Act.

The matter was again raised in another place yesterday by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Anthony) in a matter of public importance, namely:
The Government's duplicitous handling of the Ivanov/ Combe affair.

The Leader of the Opposition mentioned these matters and others of great concern relating to the question directly involving the Prime Minister. Yet the Prime Minister ran away from that debate. He did not appear; he did not speak in it; and he has not answered or attempted to answer. What law has he broken? What explanation has he for the fact that a number of people knew all about this matter very shortly after the decision was taken on 21 April to expel Mr Ivanov? The decision obviously was made, to some extent, because of the association with Mr Combe; that is at least clear. Large numbers of people seem to have known about that very shortly afterwards. Mr Combe said that the dogs were barking this whole matter before it ever appeared in the Press or any questions were asked in the Parliament. Mr Combe said: 'The dogs were barking it'. They certainly were. They were barking it because of the very obvious lack of security on the part of people who were not authorised to disclose this information to anybody. Obviously there were unauthorised leaks for this situation of the dogs barking it to have occurred.

The Prime Minister or the Attorney-General would have been authorised to give some of the information to Mr Combe. It would have been appropriate to give some information. Mr Combe could then have been given an opportunity of answering it, but they did not do so. The Prime Minister is now falling back on this extraordinary argument that he would have been breaking the law. He is not prepared to face the Parliament; he is not prepared to face the questions that are raised; he is not prepared to answer them. He retreats behind this facade that he has established, namely, the Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence Agencies.

I have found this a curious and disturbing situation. Today I asked the Attorney-General-a man who is playing certainly the second most active role or perhaps the most active role in these series of events since 21 April-whether he advised the Prime Minister that he would have been breaking the law and what would be the basis of any such advice, or whether anybody else advised the Prime Minister that he would have been breaking the law. What did we get from the Attorney-General? Again, he did not answer. He fell back on the Standing Order that he could not give a legal opinion. He was not asked for a legal opinion; he was asked whether he advised the Prime Minister. He would not answer the question. He is obviously highly embarrassed about the situation and about the strange and extraordinary answers and the story which the Prime Minister has been putting forward to Mr Costigan and on the Mike Walsh Show.

The Attorney-General realises what a complete smokescreen this is for the Prime Minister. He is too embarrassed to say whether he gave any such advice. He is certainly too embarrassed to admit that the Prime Minister has sought to evade this question by giving the reason that he would have been breaking the law. There we have it. It is further evidence of the Government's embarrassment, further evidence of attempts to hide, to cover up, to retreat as far as it possibly can behind the barricades that it has created to protect itself from any further examination in this place or by the people of its very strange and disturbing actions from the time when it made the decision to expel Mr Ivanov.

The Special Minister of State, Mr Young, has already admitted that, during a four-hour luncheon he had with a Mr Cameron on the day when it was announced that Mr Ivanov was being expelled, he did breach security by saying, before it was ever announced, that the Government was 'kicking out a Russian'. We do know that there was some breach of security at least to that extent by a Minister. We know from Mr Combe and from others, as Mr Combe has said, that the dogs were barking what we now know to be the facts. We have this attempt now to cover up the situation that is well known. That is why we want a specific term of reference for the Royal Commission that these matters should be fully investigated.

What an extraordinary state of affairs was revealed today when I asked the Attorney-General: If it was a breach of the law for the Prime Minister to tell Mr Combe something about the matters that were alleged against him when the Cabinet took its decision, why did the Attorney-General sit down with Mr Combe and the Director-General of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation even though the Attorney-General and the Prime Minister tried to make out they had given all the facts to Mr Combe? When questioned further and when Mr Combe went on the Sunday program and said what had happened, the Attorney-General had to admit that only selected versions were given to him. Even if only selected versions were given to him, how is it that that was not a breach of the law? Was it a breach of the law? The Attorney-General does not answer the question. He evades the issue the same as the Prime Minister has evaded the issue and has tried to put a smokescreen over it all. It is for those reasons that the Opposition has moved this amendment. We hope that the Senate will give it support.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Macklin's) to Senator Chaney's amendment be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chaney's) as amended, be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 May, on motion by Senator Teague:
That the Senate oppose any aid from Australia to Vietnam so long as Vietnamese military forces are occupying Kampuchea and Laos.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by Senator Teague, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate oppose any aid from Australia to Vietnam so long as Vietnamese military forces are occupying Kampuchea and Laos.

I support this motion on two main grounds. First, I firmly believe that no aid in time of war to any country could be said to be humanitarian aid. The point is that when a country is in a war situation and is an aggressor, as Vietnam is in this instance, any aid which is supposed to be humanitarian is not humanitarian at all but is in support of the aggressor's regime and army. The second point I make in support of the motion is that this Government, in the speech delivered in this chamber on 21 April by His Excellency the Governor-General, said:
My Government will seek to develop close working relations with our neighbours in South-East Asia and the South Pacific to contribute to the stability and security of our region.
My advisers seek to ensure that relations with the member nations of ASEAN are placed on the firmest possible footing through closer and more frequent consultations at the highest level.
He continued:
My Government will maintain its close and wide-ranging relations with Japan, and continue to broaden relations with the People's Republic of China.

The fact is that if Australia gives Vietnam aid at this time, while Vietnam is occupying Kampuchea, it would be totally contrary to the very spirit and ideals of the program as pronounced by this Government in the Governor-General's Speech . It would completely undermine our standing vis-a-vis the countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations. As we all know, ASEAN comprises Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines. It is interesting to note the reaction of the diplomats of ASEAN countries in Canberra to the statement by Mr Hayden regarding one of the latest attacks in the Thai- Kampuchean border conflict. All representatives of ASEAN countries in our capital have strongly protested against the weak statement by Mr Hayden when he was supposedly condemning the Vietnamese attack. The fact is that all ASEAN countries are opposed to any aid being given to Vietnam until the Vietnamese pull their forces out of Kampuchea. It is interesting to note the reactions of the main ASEAN countries. The comments of the permanent head of Thailand's Foreign Ministry, Mr Asa Sarasm, are reported in an article which states:

. . . that resumption of any Australian Government aid to Vietnam would be 'very harmful to our common effort to get Vietnam to agree to a political solution of the Kampuchea question in accordance with resolutions passed by the United Nations and the international conference on Kampuchea'.
. . . Thailand would consider resumption of Australian aid to Vietnam in present conditions as 'a somewhat unfriendly act against the free countries in the region and ASEAN in particular'.
. . . Australian assistance would help reduce the Soviet Union's economic aid burden to Vietnam and allow it to provide more military hardware to Indo-China.
It would also help sustain Vietnam's 'resolve that what it is doing in Kampuchea is the right course and should be pursued.
'In short, Australian aid would help Vietnam continue its military occupation of Kampuchea and remain in Laos (where an estimated 50,000 Vietnamese troops are stationed) indefinitely.'
The Deputy Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Arun Bunupong, is reported to have said to Mr Hayden when he was in Bangkok:
. . . great care would be needed over when and how much aid was extended to Vietnam.
A Press article states:
Mr Arun said Thailand was not opposed to humanitarian aid to anyone, but there must be a definition of such aid.
Even humanitarian aid should be given at the right time . . .
It should not result in anyone being able to divert their own resources for aggressive purposes, leaving the raising of the standard of living of its own people to the rest of the world.

This is a fact. Whenever aid is given on supposedly humanitarian grounds to a country which is engaged in a war, that aid goes not to the people to whom it is supposed to go but to the people who are fighting the war. They are the ones who benefit from the aid. Let us look at the reaction of General Romulo of the Philippines when it was announced that Australia was considering giving aid to Vietnam. He strongly opposed even a possible resumption of Australian aid to Vietnam which, according to him, would give Vietnam another reason to continue with its territorial occupation and aggression in that area. General Romulo said :

We believe that would be fundamentally wrong. Any aid will be interpreted by the Vietnamese as sympathising with their efforts . . . it would undermine ASEAN efforts to continue showing the Vietnamese that they are isolated in the world.
We have to make them think they are world pariahs. That could make them think again about their Kampuchean policy.

The Foreign Minister of Indonesia, Dr Mochtar, is also strongly opposed to the aid. He made it quite clear that ASEAN countries would protest strongly to Australia if Australia resumed aid to Vietnam. In the Governor-General's Speech the Government said that it would maintain its close and wide-ranging relations with Japan and with the People's Republic of China. It is interesting to note what the Chinese Premier said about supposed aid to Vietnam. When Mr Zhao was on the way to New Zealand and Australia he said:
The most important thing now is for the international community to take effective measures to compel Vietnam to withdraw from Kampuchea.

All major Western democracies and countries in our region are against any aid to Vietnam. While our Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, was in Paris, the United States Secretary of State, Mr Shultz, indicated that Washington was unwavering in its support for the Association of South East Asian Nations and the Chinese Government's demands for an unconditional withdrawal of Vietnamese troops from Kampuchea and Laos. Everybody is against aid to the aggressor.

Let us look at the Australian Labor Party socialists' attitude on this matter. We all know the stance of the left wing of the Australian Labor Party on this issue. The official ALP platform commits the Labor Government to resuming aid to Vietnam. The ALP platform also says that a Labor government:
. . . should utilise its relationship with ASEAN to encourage all forms of dialogue between ASEAN countries and Indo-China.

The question is: What will the left wing of the ALP do and how long will it be quiet about aid to Vietnam? It is also interesting to note that under the platform laid down by the ALP national conference last July, the Hawke Government is committed to recognising the rights of the East Timorese to self- determination and independence. It is strange that the ALP and the socialists are so keen on independence for East Timor while they are not interested in independence for Kampuchea. Where are the standards? That is a hypocritical statement. They are interested in the independence of one country only, while they could not care less whether the other country is occupied by an aggressor. It is fascinating to observe that the left wing of the Victorian Branch of the ALP pushed through a resolution while Mr Hayden was actually on a trip to talk to the ASEAN countries. The resolution reinforced the party's policy on the resumption of aid to Vietnam. Where is the Government standing on this point? Who is winning on this crucial question? We all know who are the members of the socialist Left in the ALP and we all know that the majority of them are just very clever academics. Let me read this quotation:

Give an academic the delusion that he may play an historical role and you can turn any decent scholar into a public hazard. As the Russian proverb says: 'to have a fool is bad, but to have a fool with initiative is worse'.

That is what is happening in the socialist Left of the ALP. Mr Hayden on his tour to South East Asia presented his six-point plan regarding the withdrawal of Vietnamese troops from Kampuchea. The reaction to his plan from General Romulo of the Philippines was quite explicit. He said that there was nothing new in that kind of plan and that the only plan acceptable to ASEAN was a United Nations resolution calling for a withdrawal of troops and for Kampuchean self- determination before any resumption of aid. I am suprised that the ALP and the socialist Left in this instance are not in accord with the United Nations resolution. They have their own point of view which is contrary to United Nations resolutions.

Mr Hayden has suggested-I suppose backing down a bit-that any assistance in the future would be small and in the areas of agriculture or teaching programs. However, General Romulo said that even such a small gesture would be interpreted as backing for Vietnam. When Mr Hayden returned from his trip to ASEAN countries he said:
The pitch I got from everywhere in South-East Asia, with great force and clarity, was that we should not resume aid to Vietnam.
The Chinese were totally emphatic that resumption of aid to Vietnam, which is after all only symbolic, would encourage it to persist in its present policies over the occupation of Kampuchea.
The Chinese view was that if Vietnam is serious in its protestations of peace and withdraws from Kampuchea, then China will negotiate its differences, but not before.
The ASEAN view is similar. There must be a withdrawal of Vietnamese troops followed by some form of political settlement.

It will be interesting to find out what 'symbolic aid' means. If it is only symbolic, what value is it to the people who ought to get it? Symbolic aid could be only a dollar. That is symbolic aid. Otherwise, any aid is more than symbolic , it is helping the aggressor in its aggression towards an independent country. Mr Hayden also said that in practical terms any aid, if Australia gives it, is a million miles down the track. How far is one million miles in socialist jargon? I would like to know that. The next phase was when Mr Hayden proposed his peace role in Vietnam. All the major countries-France, Belgium and the United States of America-rejected that proposal because they had already tried it out. The Vietnamese are just not interested in any peace plan at all. They are interested only in expanding their influence in their region. It will be interesting to see in the next month who is the ruler in the ALP Government. Is it the socialist Left or the Cabinet of Prime Minister Hawke? It will be interesting to see who works for the benefit of Australia and Australian interests in this region. Who is to maintain the credibility and standing of our country towards our neighbours? I support the motion and I oppose any aid to Vietnam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the following motion:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate oppose any aid from Australia to Vietnam so long as Vietnamese military forces are occupying Kampuchea and Laos.

The test of any foreign policy in this country ought to be the following: What is the policy most conducive to bringing about the peace, welfare, health and prosperity of the people concerned? Which will give them more safety and preserve them from the ravages of war? I want to test the whole of what I say on that basis. Last year I was privileged to go to Thailand and talk to the Ministers and the Prime Minister of the Thai Government about the situation in Kampuchea. I was privileged, with their aid, to visit the borders of Kampuchea and to see the circumstances there, which were as they are today. What did I see ? I saw on the border of Kampuchea the Thai Government, which is a government of peace, a government with no aggressive tendencies towards those around it, committed to putting several military divisions to have an immediate defence preparedness to stop a series of events.

Why is it necessary for Thailand to preserve its borders against Kampuchea? First of all, of course, there have been sorties and insurgencies by the Vietnamese across the border, creating the need to defend the border. Secondly, refugees have been fleeing across the border into Thailand. Thirdly, there is the need to protect those refugees who live in the camps in Thailand very close to the border. I was privileged to visit those camps. The Australian community should understand that there were then, and I believe there are now, some 192, 000 human beings, including families and young children, living permanently in those camps with no hope at all of moving out of them; they are caught there by the ravages of the Vietnamese war. I saw in those camps the most horrible sights of mutilated people with limbs amputated by land mines and by the explosive capacity of warfare. I saw, of course, the efforts of the United Nations to help in that regard. I went into the enclave with the United Nations people and saw some 42,000 young and old Khmer women and their children collecting their weekly rice and dried fish rations. They were collecting it under fear. While we were there a few hundred yards away some enemy mortar shells fell and killed and mutilated a number of people. There, clearly, was a situation that is intolerable in the human context.

What is not understood-I want to direct my remarks to this-is the very nature of this matter. There is a belief in the community that the circumstances in this area have been created in the last few years. The trouble is that people have never understood that there are two quite different cultures of people in the area of Indo-China. Let me just sketch history. Over most of history there was no Vietnam as it is understood today. The belief that it was only the wickedness of the French wars, the Japanese wars and the recent Vietnamese war that divided Vietnam is a distortion of history. The first thing that must be understood is that what we knew as North Vietnam was for 1,000 years a province of Southern China. Until, I think, 939 it was a province of Southern China totally absorbed in the cultures of China. Its culture was and still remains, in its big wheel Buddhism, a Chinese culture.

In the south in Laos, what we knew as Cambodia and what was South Vietnam, there was an entirely different culture, an Indianised culture which is called small wheel Buddhism. The people themselves have an affinity with culture and understanding. Over the years, the province known an Nam Viet, North Vietnam, was bringing its aggression down to the south and across to Kampuchea. I make the fundamental point that Vietnam has been the hereditary enemy of Kampuchea. The real threat has not been South Vietnam but North Vietnam. That has been the hereditary threat not in years immediately past but, indeed, over hundreds of years. Indeed, in the eighteenth century a double wall was built across Vietnam dividing North and South Vietnam. It was only in the passage of a few years that there was some kind of a concord between North and South Vietnam. We have allowed the unification by force of Vietnam. We have brought about the invasion into Kampuchea of some 200,000 Vietnamese.

There is absolutely no reason for an outside aggressor to go into Kampuchea. It is a small country, a country of sturdy, attractive people. The Cambodians, or Kampucheans, in the last decade have had their population of seven million reduced by at least one million by bloody slaughter from all sides. The Kampucheans have undergone a series of conflicts. There was the Sihanouk regime up until about 1970. The right wing group displaced him, followed by the ugly Pol Pot regime. There has been trouble there. The fact of the matter is that the Vietnamese have moved in under a pretext. They have not just moved a handful of peacekeeping people to handle the six million people but have effected a military occupation, an occupation of some 200,000 people which has caused untold harm and untold hardship. Of course the Vietnamese boast today that they have the third or fourth largest military force in the world. Maybe they have. Of course, they are strongly supported by Russia.

The fact is that now the Russians have been able to come out of their ice ridden port of Vladivostok-'Vladivostok' in Russian means eastern capital, but it is an ice-bound eastern capital-and they have come down to Cam Ranh Bay where they have military defences. It is no pretty report that one reads recently that the Soviets are building huge missile sites facing Asia. The bulk of Asia is non -nuclear. What do we find? We find that the Soviet Union is making provisions that could lead to the virtual doubling of its SS20 medium-range missiles targeted on Asia. The Soviet Union now has 108 of the missiles facing Asia, and, in the judgment of officials and experts, the new sites could accommodate about the same number. Why? What is the purpose? If indeed there are, apart from China , no nuclear powers in Asia, what a paradox it is that some people talk about a nuclear free zone when in fact there is a unilateral training of threat from that quarter.

I want to make the essential points. First of all, Indo-China has not always been united or of the one culture and nor is it fact that a series of sorties by the French, the Japanese or the Americans have distorted that culture. Over history there have been a series of quite distinctive cultures. The North Vietnamese culture is a Chinese type of culture. Indeed, the Indian or Indianisation culture from Laos and Cambodia across South Vietnam is well described in history. For 1,000 years, North Vietnam, or Nam Viet, was a province of southern China. Indeed over most of the past 2,000 years, there was no unity between the two. I make the point again that the one great threat to and enemy of Kampuchea over the years has been Vietnam, and it has been recognised as such.

TALK.START.PARA: —By whom?
—The history books are full of that fact. I will be very happy to give the honourable senator books to read which tell him the situation chapter and verse.

SPEECH.PARA: The only unity of that area has been brought about by military force-the force of arms-by the Japanese, the French, and now of course by the Vietnamese. It is a very ugly thing indeed. I have described the conditions that I saw on the Kampuchean border and in the refugee camps, and the conditions in the feeding lines of the thousands and thousands of Khmer people-sturdy, happy people but all caught in the onslaught of war, and all of them literally threatened because some 200,000 Vietnamese troops are in that country.

The primary task is to get a world consensus to try to force the removal of the Vietnamese from Kampuchea. There can be no solution to the Kampuchean problem until the Vietnamese forces are removed. Then of course there is the problem of getting a compromise and getting unity within Kampuchea. I sympathise with those who say: 'Look, the war is run by warlords; the people are being hurt; you must give food to and support the people'. But history is against doing that. The fact of the matter is that the more aid that is given to Vietnam in a civil way the more that country is free to turn its resources to military purposes. Vietnam is quite capable of feeding and clothing its people. In any case, it is a member of the Comecon-that is, the east European community-and could draw upon that community for resources.

The certainty is that if we gave civil aid to Vietnam we would, however unwillingly and unconsciously, give Vietnam larger potential military muscle. The one thing we want to do is to send a message to the world that we believe the Vietnamese should get out of Kampuchea. It is part of the domino situation. Why would the Vietnamese be there? They have no reason to be there. Therefore, the essential situation is to give it no help, however unwittingly, to aid itself. Honourable senators must recognise that we are talking about countries that have had proud traditions of national identity and culture that have been destroyed. We are talking about people who live in fear of death and disease, a nation which has lost a million people by bloody murder, including civil war, in recent times. This is a horrible thing; it must not be allowed to continue or to escalate. I therefore support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I entered the chamber to do some paper work without interruption, only to hear the remarks of Senator Sir John Carrick.
—Didn't you listen to me?

—No, but I do not doubt that what Senator Lajovic had to say would have been in the same emotive terms as those used by Senator Sir John Carrick. For a person of compassion-I believe Senator Sir John Carrick to have been and still to be a person of compassion-his reading of the situation in Indo -China is quite hard to understand.
—It is historically accurate.

—No, it is not historically accurate. I think the honourable senator reads text books with a particular bias. He has not bothered to get a balanced view of the tragedy of Indo-China, a tragedy which we imposed upon them . By 'we', I mean the Western powers. When we consider the number of times the Indo-Chinese people, in particular the Vietnamese people, have been betrayed, we note that time and again they have been given certain understandings by international communities, and those understandings have been betrayed. When we consider that point we should have sympathy for the position in which the Vietnamese people find themselves. In 40 years, they have been forced into a position of being dependent on one of the major powers because they have been denied by the other major powers the assistance which they needed to recover from the long years of war. I know that Senator Sir John Carrick would not have had the time-none of us here seems to have the time to watch various documentaries that appear from time to time on television-to see the documentary entitled The Ten Thousand Days War which was so vivid in its description of what happened and the misfortune which befell the Indo-Chinese people. Had he seen that documentary, his views today might have been differently expressed.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Vietnamese people needed and what we refused to give them is understanding. We have allowed ourselves to be caught in an unreal animosity that has forced the Vietnamese people to depend upon the support of the Soviet Union because they receive no support from anywhere else. Before they entered Comecon, the trade bloc, they sought to reach some agreement with the countries in their area. They had depended upon a commitment from the United States that they would receive considerable aid after the war to reconstruct, and they did not receive that assistance. They were then left completely dependent upon the Soviet Union; and the Soviet Union has not failed them. Make no mistake, the Vietnamese did endeavour to reach a non-aligned position. They needed it. They depend very much on that sort of support from their neighbours. Their neighbours , the ASEAN countries, have refused that support. Those countries are the ones to which we are turning for advice as to what we should do in giving aid to Vietnam. When one looks at those countries and the regimes which control them, they would be the last countries we would approach for advice as to what we should be doing in regard to the very vexed question of giving aid to Vietnam.

It troubles me that we are not prepared to make a decision to give to Vietnam the small amount of aid that we previously gave it. It was humanitarian aid. If I remember correctly, one expression of that aid was a cattle breeding station in the hills behind Hanoi. It was aid for a very useful and practical purpose. It gave no assistance to any military effort which the Vietnamese might have been engaged in or were forced to engage in. If honourable senators look at the history of Vietnam, if they watch documentaries concerning Vietnam and read of the human experiences in Vietnam, they might recall the complaint of one Vietnamese woman who said: 'The Americans have made beggars of the Vietnamese children'-by Americans I include ourselves-'prostitutes of the Vietnamese women and communists of the Vietnamese men'. It sticks very firmly in my mind that our lack of understanding of the problems which the Vietnamese faced over the 40 or 50 years of struggle, our failure to understand them properly, has perhaps forced them to accept a political solution to their problems to which some of us might not be sympathetic. We must accept a considerable amount of blame. I find it terrifying and unacceptable that we should not be prepared to give aid except with the advice of the United States or the ASEAN countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or France.

—Or for that matter, France, because the record of France in Vietnam or Indo-China does not bear describing. The techniques that the Vietnamese learnt and imposed upon their enemies were forced upon them in a way by some of the French forces in Vietnam. We cannot allow ourselves to go back and consider France's record in that country and the way it imposed oppression on the Vietnamese and Indo-Chinese people as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: I find the motion extraordinary, coming as it does from within the Senate, a House of the Australian Parliament representing the Australian people. I find it extraordinary that we should take such an inhuman approach. The conditions of aid appear to be that no aid shall be given until the Vietnamese withdraw from Kampuchea. Let us look at who is responsible for the situation in Kampuchea at present, and recognise and clearly understand the reason the Vietnamese armies remain in Kampuchea. The integrity of Cambodia was destroyed in the first place by ourselves, by the clandestine and illegal bombing and by the penetration of our forces into that country. Let us also understand that what is occurring in Kampuchea at present is a result of support from one of the most horrific regimes of modern time, that is, the Pol Pot regime. The Pol Pot regime received strong support from the People's Republic of China. Make no mistake, the People' s Republic of China, in its power struggle with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, opposed the spread of Soviet influence into the Indo-China peninsula and was prepared to support one of the most horrific regimes of modern time, the Pol Pot regime, in order to prevent Soviet expansion in that area. As a result, a whole people were sacrificed by the Pol Pot regime. If I recall the situation clearly, the Vietnamese incursion into Kampuchea can be compared to the Tanzanian incursion into Uganda to depose another of the dictators who could be described in the same terms as Pol Pot. There is not the same sort of criticism of the Tanzanian incursion into Uganda as there is of the Vietnamese incursion into Cambodia. It was necessary, in view of what was occurring in Kampuchea for the period of that regime.

I feel strongly about this subject. One ought to understand the Vietnamese position and the advice that Vietnam was receiving at the time of the last push towards Saigon when the Soviet Union was saying to the Vietnamese: 'You would succeed. What will happen to you will be the same as happened at the Tet offensive. You will fail'. The Vietnamese were receiving the same advice from the Chinese, but for a different reason-because the Chinese did not want them to succeed. The Chinese have continued to apply pressure on Vietnam through the forces which supported and represented Pol Pot. In my mind the People's Republic of China stands condemned for supporting and continuing to support a repressive regime in order to maintain its opposition to Soviet expansionism. The Vietnamese people are victims of its continual pressures in the Indo-China peninsula. The Soviets are the other people who are advising that we ought not be giving aid to Vietnam.

I suggest that honourable senators understand and give some sympathy to the Vietnamese people and, in understanding and giving sympathy, do not give support to the proposition before us. We should be giving aid in spite of the advice that we have so far received. We should understand the situation as it exists. We should be encouraging the Vietnamese to withdraw, but in order for them to withdraw we must give support to the existing Government in Kampuchea. My understanding is that at present we refuse to give recognition to that Government. We refuse to give any more than humanitarian aid to Kampuchea. We should be giving far more than that in order to stabilise that Government and to create the conditions which would lead to a Vietnamese withdrawal. The Vietnamese are supporting a federation of the states of Indo-China. Does anyone here object to those people having a federation who, in spite of their different racial backgrounds-

TALK.START.PARA: —If they wish to.

—They do wish to. Let us create conditions by which they could reach that decision themselves. Let us create the pre-conditions, by some understanding of the difficulties which they face. Let us try to free them from dependence on any one of the super-powers. Let them make their decisions and be free to operate without complete dependence which may lead to dominance from a particular power. We can only do that if we give them some encouragement and the scope to look elsewhere for support. We should not continually create barriers and press for motions such as the one we are discussing. That can only prevent them from being anything but dependent on a super-power for their very existence .

SPEECH.PARA: In spite of what the honourable senator has said, at present the Vietnamese live in conditions of great deprivation. The amount of support that they are now receiving from the Soviet Union is far less than what they used to receive. In fact the Vietnamese people are worse off since the war ended than they were before because they are not getting the same flow of aid. That is why they need encouragement and support, not opposition. A high priority ought to be given to aid to Vietnam. I regret to say that there is hesitation on this side as well as direct opposition from the Opposition in this chamber. I find it highly regrettable that there is any hesitation at all. We ought to be giving aid and, because it is limited aid and only token aid, it ought not to be withheld for any reason. We should take the firm step of immediately giving aid to Vietnam in order to encourage other countries to do the same and so reduce Vietnam's reliance upon the Soviet Union, which from time to time comes under substantial criticism in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: -Two years ago the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) and I visited Vietnam and Laos. We were part of a parliamentary delegation visiting China and Japan, and on the way back Mr Morrison, a Minister for Defence in the Whitlam Government, and I decided to go to Vietnam and Laos. I was very interested in Vietnam. In the early days of the Vietnam war I objected to any intervention in that country. It was a civil war and I believed that any intervention by the Western powers would only drive the Vietnamese people further into the arms of Russian-type communism. Had Vietnam been left alone it would have finished up with a socialist system of government, very similar to that of Yugoslavia, and it would have been in a better situation than it is today.

SPEECH.PARA: I found a great deal of poverty in Vietnam. There is very little development in agriculture or civil works. All the emphasis is placed on the defence forces-the army and the air force. It has one of the finest defence forces of any country in the world. There is no doubt about that. It has the finest trained troops and probably more battle-trained troops than any other country. Its military equipment is as good as that of any other nation. The Western world has forced these people into this situation. I think it is a great shame people have to rely so much on their defence forces. They fear the world. The Vietnamese have no love for the Russians; I found that out when I was there. The Vietnamese had several arguments with the Russian authorities. It is my belief that if the Vietnamese people were left alone in peace for a period of 10 years their emphasis on the army would be reduced, as it should be. Countries such as Australia should provide civil aid to help that country but we should not do everything.

We are providing aid to Laos. I inspected four or five pumping stations on the Mekong River. People there are very happy. They are co-operating in the aid projects. We made certain recommendations. Wherever we went, in Laos or Vietnam, we took embassy staff with us and reports were sent back to the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Tony Street. We recommended that the people there should be left alone. If they were, there should be less emphasis on war.

If we and other powers gave Vietnam civil aid, more specialists would be taken out of the defence forces and employed on civilian construction, agriculture, irrigation channels and so on. No country will reduce its military power while it feels, rightly or wrongly that it is under threat. The Vietnamese people feel that they are continually under threat. While they perceive that threat to be there I believe that Vietnam is a danger to our region. Both sides of the political spectrum in Australia should be trying to build bridges and bring peace to this region. It is very necessary to do that. I do not always agree with America. I am not anti-America; I am not anti-anybody. We have a system in this country that is probably unique. We do not overpower a lot of smaller and middle class nations as the United States and Russia do. Australia is in a better position to negotiate and bring about peaceful settlements.

I certainly want to see the Vietnamese out of Kampuchea, and we should try to work towards that end. Any country should have the right to decide what type of government it should have. It is not good to take a love or hate stand. Nothing is absolutely white or black. We should try to build bridges and bring about peaceful negotiations in our region. While there is poverty in any area of the world we cannot have peace-and I am convinced of that. While people feel that they are under threat from a number of nations they will not reduce their military power. Military power is a real danger not only to Vietnam but also to all other countries in that region. The only way to reduce that emphasis in Vietnam is to leave the Vietnamese in peace, get them interested in civil construction and redeploy their technicians away from the army. In 10 years the Vietnamese army would be reduced and it would not be considered a threat by any of the member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations or their neighbours.

We should seriously think about how we give aid. Sensible ways can be found through all this mire. Australia should be playing a leading role in building bridges and reducing poverty. It is in our interest. We are a trading nation, and the quicker ASEAN countries, which after all are in our area, achieve a reasonable standard of living the better it will be for everybody. I do not think a hard line should be taken. When politicians go into this region they should pay visits to many of these countries. At least that would give them some insight into what is going on. When we had talks with the Vietnamese and Laotian governments we took along our embassy people. In that way, nothing is hidden. That is the way it should be done. I believe that we should have some independent thoughts on these matters. We should not follow lines that are laid down by other nations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate oppose any aid from Australia to Vietnam so long as Vietnamese military forces are occupying Kampuchea and Laos.

I was very interested in the comments made by Senator Sir John Carrick. Senator Sir John Carrick is the one person who has considerable experience of South East Asia. Not only has he visited South East Asia in the last few years to see for himself the problems that presently exist, but also he has known the people since World War II when he was a prisoner of war there. With his experience, I would be quite prepared to accept the viewpoint that he has put forward in the Senate today.

Honourable senators opposite have commented that the people of Vietnam are a complete unit, that they fear the world and their neighbours and that aid should be given to them. Those honourable senators have failed to look inside Vietnam. If they had done so, they would have seen that this militaristic Government oppressed its people in the first place. Hundreds of thousands of Vietnamese have been forced out of Vietnam because of their Government's attitude to them. We know full well that very many people in Vietnam do not have work and they have difficulties in getting supplies and rations. As I have said we know that hundreds of thousands of people have been forced out. Many tens of thousands of Vietnamese boat people have been lost. The boats have been either wrecked or taken by pirates. Many boat people have come to Australia. In fact, there are many tens of thousands of Vietnamese refugees in Australia now. If we spent some time with them, perhaps we would learn more about the situation and find out the reasons why they have had to leave their homeland and their families. Honourable senators would find that they have been forced out by these oppressors-the Vietnamese Government.

I believe there is sympathy for the people of Vietnam and for what they are going through now. But surely there is only one way in which this matter can be rectified to bring peace to South East Asia. The Vietnamese Government, not with its defence forces as has been suggested but with its forces that have attacked Kampuchea and Laos and brought misery to a very large number of refugee camps, should retire to within its borders, cease its militaristic action, and stop attacking the refugee camps over its borders. If the Vietnamese Government took this action there would be quite a rush by countries within South East Asia to give aid to these unfortunate people. I refer to the little people of Vietnam, the people who are being oppressed and held down by their Government.

One of the problems of course is that Vietnam, in accepting the aid of Comecon, the East European organisation, has allowed-as I think Senator Georges said-the Soviet tentacles to come into South East Asia in the same way as we have seen these tentacles going into Afghanistan. Perhaps our senses have been blunted by the horrific stories that appear weekly in the Press-that tens of thousands of people in Afghanistan are killed by these Soviet forces. I used the word ' blunted' but I should have said that we are appalled and horrified. Although we have seen so much, we do not really appreciate the misery in that country.

It has been said-this has not been refuted-that something like $3m a day in military aid goes into Vietnam day after day and week after week. Naturally, when one sees that amount of aid going into Vietnam one is assured that it must have one of the best attack forces in the region. Naturally, as a result, the countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations are fearful of the situation. It is also very clear that these ASEAN countries-Australia is a part of that family-are concerned with the attitude of the present Government. Who would not be? They look upon Australia as a country of stability, a country that is showing all the signs of wanting to assist, to be a part of the South East Asian family and to be more and more a part of the region. Suddenly we say that we are considering giving aid to a country that those ASEAN countries can look upon only as an enemy because of its continuing attack on one of its unfortunate neighbours.

I hope-it is quite obvious that the ASEAN countries hope-that the Australian Government will not pursue this course upon which it has embarked. China has opposed Australian aid. The Chinese Premier has told both Mr Hayden and Mr Hawke , on their recent visits, of this strong Chinese opposition. If the Government seeks to resume the aid surely this downgrades ASEAN's importance in Australia's foreign policy priorities. One can conceive the problems the Labor Government now has because of left wing pressures. Obviously, the left wing has sympathy for the Vietnamese Government and the action that Government is taking. If there is any doubt about the dangers of the Vietnamese invasion, we have only to look at its destabilising influence in this part of the world. It is most intersting to note, when we start considering how this Vietnamese fester, sore or boil is causing so much concern in this region because of its destabilising influence, the statement of the former Labor spokesman on foreign affairs, Mr Lionel Bowen, on 11 September 1982. He said:
The Australian Labor Party takes the view that generally the presence of armed forces in a country, other than one's own, heightens international tension.

That is a very true statement. One can only hope that in time to come the Federal Government will recognise the truth of what Mr Bowen has said and ensure that, at present, no aid will be given to Vietnam. If aid is given to Vietnam it will encourage the Vietnamese people. It will take off the pressure in so very many ways. It will allow them to divert money to military purposes from areas to which aid has been given.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on!

—Of course it will. All the direction of effort within Vietnam goes towards its military build up and military support for its attack on these countries. So any aid that we give now will be only a foundation for further efforts in its militaristic attitudes towards its neighbours. I hope that the Labor Government will get the message not just from this motion, but also from the people of Australia who are extremely concerned and from attitudes of its friends in the ASEAN countries. Perhaps the Government will do much better to give aid where it is more needed in the Third World which does not compromise Australia's defence and foreign policy objectives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never heard so much hypocrisy in my life or seen so many honourable senators with such short memories. Do honourable senators opposite remember the five million people who were murdered by Pol Pot? Do they remember those days?
—I am remembering the people being murdered now.

—Yes. The honourable senator has a short memory for the five million who were murdered then. The previous Government knew months before what was going on in Kampuchea but never lifted a finger to assist the people. The Vietnamese were in Kampuchea. I am not quarrelling about their motives, but the fact is that they went into Kampuchea and they stopped murder. It is no good saying we will not give aid to Vietnam because it will continue to have forces in Kampuchea. That again is hypocrisy by Opposition members. If ever a nation was forced into the Comecon camp, the Vietnamese nation was. They were squeezed out of the Asian Development Bank, the World Bank and any other forms of assistance by Australia and America which was owed to the Vietnamese. Nevertheless, they stopped another five million people from being murdered on top of the five million already murdered in Kampuchea. We are talking about stopping aid to Vietnam in the hope that the Vietnamese will withdraw their troops. Who will then be put in? Do members of the Opposition want Pol Pot back? Do they want to be allies with the Association of South East Asian Nations which believes Pol Pot should return? I sincerely hope the Vietnamese do not pull out of Kampuchea until such time as there is a proper plebiscite by the people to choose for themselves who they want, and it certainly should not be Pol Pot.

SPEECH.PARA: The memories of the Opposition members are short; they have convenient memories . We are talking about aid to assist the Vietnamese troops to continue in Kampuchea. What is the difference between aid and trade when it comes to assisting a country? The previous Government continued to trade with the Russians while bleating about Afghanistan. Is that not assisting them to carry on there? Instead of crocodile tears running down Opposition senators' faces about what has happened to Afghanistan while they are trading with the Russians, they are complaining about a bit of humanitarian aid to the Vietnamese people because of what is going on in Kampuchea. But they conveniently forget what went on in Kampuchea. To draw a red herring--

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody is forgetting. Why do you say that?

—Because of honourable senators' attitude. It is only the left wingers, according to the previous speakers. I think that is rather insulting to a lot of people who will not associate with the left wing, but they are just humanitarians who realise the situation, who are crying for a plebiscite to take place. They would like the Vietnamese troops to come out but they certainly do not want Pol Pot back in again. There is no way I would agree to the recognition of Pol Pot irrespective of what the five ASEAN nations do. A red herring is drawn about Timor. I do not hear honourable senators opposite crying about the Indonesian troops in Timor. I feel that this whole motion was really a red herring in the first place. To continue talking in the hypocritical way that honourable senators opposite are about stopping the little bit of humanitarian aid to the Vietnamese people and thinking that that, for some reason or other, will assist to get the Vietnamese troops out of Kampuchea again is hypocritical as Pol Pot would be put in the place of the Vietnamese. There is no doubt about that in my mind. I feel that this motion from the very beginning was nothing but a red herring. Honourable senators opposite have their facts mixed up from beginning to end. They obviously do not know the history of what took place in Kampuchea or they conveniently forgot what took place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion this afternoon in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate oppose any aid from Australia to Vietnam so long as Vietnamese military forces are occupying Kampuchea and Laos.

This motion was moved some time ago by Senator Teague, and the debate has been continued today. There are considerable areas of agreement on both sides of the chamber despite the last contribution. In particular, I accept what Senator Georges has said, that this is a vexed question. It is a question requiring careful judgment on an examination of all the circumstances. We, on this side of the House, contrary to the belief of Senator Georges, have sympathy for the Vietnamese people. I appreciate, and my colleagues appreciate, that they have been in a state of war almost continuously since 1949; in fact, historically long before then. So we have sympathy for the Vietnamese people. We also have great sympathy-I remind the Senate-for the people of Kampuchea who have obviously suffered considerably under Pol Pot. We never hear any honourable senator on this side attempt to legitimise the performance of Pol Pot. I suggest that honourable senators should look back through the speeches made by the then Foreign Minister, Mr Street. They will see a continual condemnation of the activities of Pol Pot. I think it is fair to say that in considerable aspects we are in agreement with what Senator Elstob has said. We accept that Australia's role in many places in the world should be to build bridges and bring about peaceful negotiation. That has been Australia's attitude to the Kampuchean crisis. We have looked for a peaceful diplomatic resolution of that problem. That was our objective in Government and it remains our objective in Opposition.

I want to contribute briefly to this debate by firstly looking at the principle of aid. I am speaking of development and humanitarian aid. I do not think there is any question that any of us are talking about military aid, but I would like to put my views on that subject as a matter of principle and then attempt to apply those views to the situation of aid to Vietnam in current circumstances and, from that, to reach certain conclusions. I anticipate that those conclusions will support the motion moved by Senator Teague.

My immediate reaction, as a matter of principle, is that, if there are people starving in Vietnam, we have a moral responsibily to help them. That is my attitude to humanitarian aid and I take that stand in relation to any country in the world. Similarly, I would also normally say that, if people are suffering from poverty, we should be willing to assist with development aid, notwithstanding the political complexion of the donee. That political complexion may not be what we regard as desirable. Nevertheless, we have an international responsibility to assist in those cases.

That attitude has been reasonably consistent with that of the previous Government. The reason for this attitude, firstly, is that I accept discontent will increase with misery. If we can relieve or reduce misery by contributing economic aid, we will contribute to reducing the discontent and therefore, will be acting for the betterment of the donee people. Secondly, I believe each nation prospers by the prosperity of others. Therefore, if we contribute to self -sustained economic growth, we lessen the dependence of such countries on others . That policy eventually leads to the introduction of trading markets. I remind the Senate that over 70 per cent of Third World trade is now with developed nations. So I believe economic aid is of benefit to Australia and the developed world from that point of view.

Thirdly, I support economic aid to underdeveloped countries because of the potential for closer, more meaningful relations with the West. I believe this can only assist Australia's security. That is particularly so in view of the deplorable record of the Soviet Union with respect to economic aid. I remind the Senate that its total contribution to economic aid is only 0.04 per cent of gross national product, which is not a record of which the Soviet Union should be proud. Of course, that is largely made up of military aid. That gives the West an opportunity to influence Third World countries by its attitude of being willing to contribute to the development of those countries.
That spirit was recognised by former Foreign Minister Peacock, in an address to the Australian-Asian Association on 13 September 1976, when he stated:

. . . we believe that it is important that the actions of others do not weaken the forces working towards moderation, co-operation and concentration on internal development, and do not limit their range of choices by making them highly dependent on the Communist great powers for the aid they need.
For that reason, as a matter of principle, I support the giving of economic aid to underdeveloped nations.

However, whilst I normally support humanitarian and development aid, I concede that there is always a danger that the aid will not achieve the designed objective-for example, in relation to humanitarian aid, it will not be used for the purpose for which it was intended but rather will be used for such purposes as feeding troops. Similar considerations apply to development aid. I will reflect upon my experiences, as have other honourable senators today. I particularly recall the situation in Somalia and Ethiopia, where approximately 30 per cent of GNP in each country is spent on the military forces. Both countries are now greatly supported by the Western industrialised world. It is beyond dispute that some aid goes directly to sustain the military forces. It might be said that the provision of aid also indirectly allows such a high percentage of GNP to continue to be provided for military purposes.

It is a difficult question. I concede the great reservation that, if we cut out or reduce economic and humanitarian aid to those countries, the population would not be any better off. Would there be sufficient pressure upon government to redirect a proportion of that massive expenditure which is currently spent on military causes? This is the great dilemma with regard to foreign aid, a dilemma to which there is no easy answer, which requires a careful evaluation of all the circumstances, and in the case of Vietnam, which is the subject of this debate, it is obviously a dilemma which requires evaluation of all the circumstances concerning Vietnam's involvement in the occupation of Kampuchea.

Now that I have explained my attitude towards aid, I move to look specifically at the subject of this motion. I remind the Senate that the motion does not state that the Senate opposes aid to Vietnam, but that it opposes aid so long as Vietnamese military forces are occupying Kampuchea and Laos. There has been some confusion in the debate today, particularly on the part of Senator McIntosh. I had the impression that the Opposition was being criticised for opposing aid to Vietnam. That is not true. Senator Teague, in moving the motion, indicated from authoritative sources that there are approximately 180,000 Vietnamese troops in Kampuchea at the moment and 45,000 Vietnamese troops in Laos. Those are the circumstances in which we are looking at the question of reintroducing aid.

I have never seen it disputed that foreign aid, particularly in the military form by the Soviet Union, enables Vietnam to maintain the huge occupying force in neighbouring countries. It is reasonable to assume that the Soviet Union is giving such major support for reasons which are to the advantage of the Soviet Union. Apparently, that reason is the development and building of a foothold in South East Asia, presumably both to strengthen its military position in relation to China and to be in a stronger military position in relation to the whole South East Asian and Pacific regions. The reinstatement of Australian aid must be considered in light of all of those circumstances.

I remind the Senate that, although aid first commenced to a Communist regime under the Whitlam Government, under the Fraser Government in December 1976 it was not only continued but also increased in size. That has been forgotten. The former Government is being condemned by the present Government in this debate for not being prepared to accept our humanitarian responsibilities to Vietnam. It is clearly being forgotten that, under Fraser, aid from Australia to Vietnam was increased. In December 1976, the Fraser Government announced that Australia would provide aid worth $6m over a three-year period primarily for livestock and a dairy product factory. So development aid was being offered. That policy was pursued by the Fraser Government for two years. It was only cancelled on 24 January 1979, upon Vietnam's invasion of Kampuchea. It was cancelled as part of a strong response by Australia and other Western nations to that invasion. Of course, the occupation of Kampuchea continues. Circumstances are roughly the same today as they were at the time of the invasion.

I accept statements from people such as Russell Rollason of the Australian Council for Overseas Aid who has emphasised that until 1979 Australian aid programs in Vietnam, such as the beef cattle development and the dairy products factory, were contributions towards overcoming malnutrition, especially among children. I accept that. I would very much like-I am sure all honourable senators on my side would-to see a situation in which Australia can reasonably resume giving aid to Vietnam for humanitarian reasons. I would say that most of us do not believe that a policy of isolating Vietnam is in Australia's best interests.
Debate interrupted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that proposed new paragraph (d) of clause 82 (1) be inserted.

—I will not keep the Committee for long because I am aware of the problems involved with printing and trying to get this legislation through. I just flag the issue that if we have a community affairs officer surely the Government must realise that in the mind of the public that is now the person to go to with complaints on a range of issues. It would seem logical to clothe that person with the responsibility of receiving the complaints in respect of program standards if, as I have pointed out, a program was otherwise offensive. I admit that of course anyone can contact the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, preferably in writing, with a logical explanation of the reasons that he considers the program was otherwise offensive . Anyone can do that. As has been evidenced by statements made in the Parliament , the ABC does not respond well or in a really considered fashion to those complaints. I just feel that this would be the appropriate person to whom, in the first instance, these complaints as to program standards should be addressed . I just hope the Government will take this matter into consideration and that, when it comes back to amend this legislation, it does so with a recognition of this proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no hostility to Senator Harradine's suggestion. I have indicated to him that we are not prepared to accept the amendment at this stage, but we are certainly prepared to examine it in the context of a general re-examination of these provisions at a later stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that Senator Harradine's amendment (2) be agreed to.

—I have moved my second amendment which seeks to delete clause 82 (2). This amendment clothes the community affairs officer with the right to refuse to investigate a complaint if it is his opinion that the complaint is frivolous, vexatious or not made in good faith and that the complainant does not have sufficient interest in the subject matter of the complaint. This matter has been given a canter over the field and I do not wish to debate it again. I raise the point that this sub-clause clothes the complaints officer with, in my view, too much of a bureaucratic power. If, as is sometimes the case, the complaints commissioner sets a large number of complaints which he may consider to be vexatious or nuisance-type complaints, the principal community affairs officer, under the proposition in my next amendment, need not notify each of the complainants if, having regard to the number of complainants, it would be burdensome so to do. Even a crackpot-I suppose that is a value judgment; who is to say that we are not crackpots-surely has a right to complain. I propose that we delete that sub-clause.
—Is there any objection to my putting amendments (2), (3) and (4) together?

—I indicate very briefly on behalf of the Opposition that we propose to oppose the amendment to sub-clause (2) which is presently before the Committee but to support the subsequent amendment to insert a new sub-clause. I would prefer that the amendments be taken separately. I do not know whether we will go to a division on this matter. I do not know the attitude of the Australian Democrats. I formally indicate on behalf of the Opposition that we do not support this amendment. We think it is a useful provision although, of course, in practice some of the difficulties and dangers Senator Harradine has mentioned may occur. I hope the Government will again be prepared to look at that provision in the light of actual operating experience. However, we can see some value in having the subsequent paragraph added to the Bill which simply ensures that complainants learn the result of their complaint unless there has been some undue burden placed on the officer concerned.
—In view of those remarks I intend to put amendment (2) separately and amendments (3) and (4) together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats very strongly support the thrust of what Senator Harradine has just said. We, too, are very apprehensive that this sub-clause gives an extraordinary amount of discretionary power to community affairs officers. In particular, we are concerned that under the provisions of clause 82 (2) (b) a community affairs officer has the discretion to determine whether a complainant has a sufficient interest in a subject. That seems to us to give enormous discretionary power to a community affairs officer. However, we have been guaranteed by the Government and by the Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Senator Button) who is also the Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications-this is on the record-that when the first reports of the community affairs officers hit Parliament which, I assume, will be in August 1984, the Government will be revising this section in the light of those reports . Because of that guarantee, at this stage we would go along with the Government and not vote for Senator Harradine's amendment to remove this sub-clause. But we do share his concern.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (2) negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that Senator Harradine's amendments (3) and (4 ) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My amendment (3) really should be supported by the Government because it provides the reporting mechanism whereby the community affairs officer notifies a complainant about what has happened to his complaint. That is fair enough. Someone complaining about an error of fact in a program, to become aware that the community affairs officer has decided that the complaint is justified and that the Managing Director has ensured that the Corporation makes a prompt apology or retraction, will have to watch television- ABC television, mind you-all day and all night. Presumably what I am proposing here will be done by the community affairs officers. All I am suggesting is that it be included in the legislation that the Principal Community Affairs Officer notify each complainant of his decision and the reasons for the decision in relation to the complaints. I know that the argument against that is that a whole lot of complaints will cost the ABC too much in postage stamps and would be very burdensome. That is why I have proposed new sub-clause (4B) which states :

SPEECH.PARA: Sub-clause (4A) does not require the Principal Community Affairs Officer to notify each of the complainants if he is of the opinion that, having regard to the number of complainants, it would be unduly burdensome to do so.
I think that is reasonable. I also think that is probably what will occur anyhow . I see no reason why the Government should not go along with that.

I will seek leave to withdraw amendment (4), but before doing so I wish to make the point that I knew that this matter was covered somewhere in the legislation. I have gone through it again and I believe it is probably covered by the definition of 'television program', which is 'images and associated sounds intended for reception by the general public', and the definition of ' broadcasting program'. So, I assume that my amendment (4) is not now required. If I am wrong, the Government could attend to that in the Budget session. Therefore, I seek leave to withdraw that amendment.
Leave granted; amendment withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Having examined the definition of 'television program', I believe Senator Harradine's view with regard to the withdrawn amendment to be correct. If we are not correct, we would certainly be prepared to look at the situation. Amendment (3) requires the Principal Community Affairs Officer to notify complainants of decisions and of the reasons for decisions. There can be no objection to that. I think Senator Harradine, with the second part of the amendment, gets into the difficulty that he accused us of getting into this morning. He said that if a community affairs officer had to deal with too many of these complaints he might have to make a decision that, because of the postage or time involved, he could not notify all complainants. That is another example of the elitism of which Senator Harradine accused us this morning. A community affairs officer would have to make a judgment to answer say, A, B and C but not to answer the rest because too many are involved. I am not criticising Senator Harradine for that. I recognise the quite genuine attempt to get round a practical problem. I am just saying that there are difficulties in writing provisions at relatively short notice and construing them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has no substantive problem with the intent of Senator Harradine' s provision that the community affairs officer should notify complainants. I only remind him-in a sense, he covered one of these points himself-that if the community affairs officer finds a complaint established, the rectification of that complaint is published on Australian Broadcasting Commission programs and, of course, there is a requirement to report to Parliament annually. I do not see either of these things as reasons for rejecting Senator Harradine's amendment. We reject it on the basis that the Government had relatively short notice of it.
