I think Senator Harradine will concede that. We are quite prepared to examine the spirit of it in the context of a review of these provisions at a later stage , but we cannot accept the amendment today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make it clear that the Opposition supports this amendment of Senator Harradine. We agree that he picks up the difficulty in proposed new sub-clause (4B) which he was complaining about with respect to the discretion given in the earlier sub-clause . But on balance we think this is a sensible provision. While noting the Government's reason for not accepting it, we believe that it would not add to the burden of administering the section and would be an additional safeguard for complainants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really must respond because the Government obviously has no objection to what is contained in this proposition other than that it did not receive the proposition until recently. Well, 'recently' was about midday yesterday. I really feel that that is sufficient time for the Government to consider it. At 5 o'clock today the Government had had 36 hours notice of the amendment. The amendment is unexceptionable. It is probably what will occur anyhow. It is not, as Senator Button said, an application of elitism; that is to say, that certain complainants will be told and other complainants will not be told. The point of elitism that I raised this morning dealt with equality of access to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in regard to complaints. We can ring the Chairman of the ABC and get through. Members of the ordinary rank and file can ring the Chairman of the ABC but will they get through? That was my point this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: The only point I make in proposed new sub-clause (4B) is with regard to, say, a substantial write-in campaign whereby the ABC gets hundreds of thousands of letters on the same issue. The Principal Community Affairs Officer has to report to Parliament. But if he is of the opinion that, having regard to the number of complainants, it would be unduly burdensome so to do, he is not required to make the notifications. Presumably this would be in the event of a complaint being unjustified. If it were justified, of course, the procedures that are laid down in clause 82 (5) would apply. I simply ask the Government: Is it or is it not a fact that this Committee is debating legislation which has already been printed and is ready to go to the House of Representatives without amendment? If that is the way we are to deal with legislation I think it is an insult to this chamber. If this sort of argument about the House of Representatives rising, shooting through and leaving the Senate is used next week, if we cannot move amendments to vital legislation next week on that excuse, that will be an insult to each and every member of this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the people who have put us here.

—And the people who have put us here; so far as I am concerned , let not the Government raise that argument next week. I presume that that is what it is doing here. It accepts the gravamen of my argument on this amendment but it is not prepared to allow it to go through, presumably because it is all cut and dried, because up to page 52 of the Bill is at the Government Printing Office about to be printed and when the Printer gets the message it will be printed.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be inserted (Senator Harradine's amendment) be inserted.

Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a statement on the economy and seek leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
ECONOMIC STATEMENT
Introduction

It is now just over a month since representatives of governments, employers, trade unions and other sections of the Australian community met in this place, as participants in the National Economic Summit Conference, to exchange views on the serious problems facing Australia and to discuss how to deal with those problems. Since then, the Government has given intensive consideration to many of the major issues discussed at the Summit and referred to in its communique. Following the general agreement reached then for the establishment of an Economic Planning Advisory Council, we have had further discussions with representatives of other governments, of the trade unions and of business, and have decided upon the detailed arrangements for the Council. Legislation to give effect to those arrangements will be introduced in the House in the current session.

The Economic Planning Advisory Council will therefore shortly be a reality and through it we shall continue the process of information sharing and consultation initiated at the Summit. Similarly, we are participating, along with employers, unions and other governments, in conferences before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which have been called in accordance with the request in the Summit communique to develop the option of a return to a centralised wage system. In other specialised forums we have furthered the process of consultation with a view to reaching agreed solutions to the problems confronting particular industries or regions. Such processes must lead in the end to policy decisions by each of the participants, including by governments.

As the Prime Minister said in his opening address to the Conference, this Government cannot escape and does not wish to escape its primary and fundamental responsibility for the economic and social policies of the nation. Since the Summit we have been pushing ahead with the necessary policy decisions to give effect to our basic objectives of promoting economic growth and creating additional employment.

Tonight I outline the decisions we have reached on substantive changes to expenditure and taxation programs and associated monetary policy issues. We have been determined to act with speed so that any uncertainty as to the broad nature of our intentions should be resolved as soon as possible and the processes of recovery set in train. Equally, however, we have been determined not to rush into decisions which require more thorough study and deliberation. We have no intention of indulging in the wholesale reversals of policy which have been all too frequent in this country in recent years and which have done much to generate uncertainty and shatter not only the confidence of business but also the aspirations of thousands of unemployed Australians.

The decisions which I shall shortly announce should be taken as indicative of the directions in which we will be moving in the months and years ahead and, in particular, in the Budget for 1983-84 to be brought down on 23 August. We have of course also been guided by the nature of the economic problems highlighted in the Summit discussions-most particularly, the parlous budgetary situation which we have inherited. This background requires further elaboration before I turn to our specific decisions.
Agreements from the Summit

As reflected in the communique, widespread agreement at several levels was reached among Summit participants. First, there was agreement on the basic facts of the economic crisis. Naturally, individual perceptions and emphases differed somewhat, but there was broad recognition: That unemployment is unacceptably high and is still rising, and that the burden of unemployment has fallen unequally upon the various groups in our society; that inflation must be brought under control if the economy is to recover and lasting jobs are to be created, a view since heightened by the release of the March quarter consumer price index figures; that profits are depressed to historically low levels and that recovery must come here, too, if economic prosperity is to be restored; and finally that, particularly when the economic cake has been shrinking, moderation in claims for a share of that cake is required, a recognition that underlies the need for burden sharing which has been central to our decisions now to be announced.

Secondly, there was substantial agreement about the factors which had contributed to our economic malaise and which must be addressed if that malaise is to be overcome. In particular there was widespread recognition of the role of : Unrealistic expectations, generated for political ends, which had resulted in large increases in real wage levels for some and unemployment for others; high interest rates, resulting from erratic and inconsistent application of monetary policies in a high inflation environment; and the pervasive but largely unavoidable consequences of the recession abroad and drought at home.

Finally, there was agreement on the general approach necessary to deal with our problems. Sustained economic growth must be restored and, contrary to the policies of the previous Government, inflation and unemployment should be tackled simultaneously. That is, of course, a very demanding approach. The interrelationships between inflation and unemployment were widely acknowledged in the Summit discussions. To combat inflation and unemployment simultaneously cannot merely involve allotting one policy to reduct inflation and another to tackle unemployment. On the contrary, in these as in other regards policies must be complementary and mutually supportive.
The Economic Context

As I have said, participants at the Summit were in general agreement in their assessment of the current economic situation. Because of that agreement and because such a wealth of information was made public at the Summit, it is not necessary for me to repeat all that now. I should, however, note in passing the more significant information which has become available since the Summit and briefly review the economic outlook as we presently see it. Recently released statistics indicate that: Price inflation, as measured by the consumer price index, remained high in the March quarter; wage increases moderated in the March quarter and real wages declined slightly-however, average weekly ordinary time earnings for full time adult workers were still 2 per cent higher, in real terms , than a year earlier; employment continued to fall in April and, after allowance for seasonal influences, unemployment continued to rise; and the balance of payments has strengthened with capital inflow remaining high.

That latter point-the strength of capital inflow-appears to be associated, at least in part, with some strengthening of optimism and confidence since the Summit. In particular: The somewhat better prospects for the international economy have received further confirmation, including at the meeting of senior Ministers from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries held in Paris last week; widespread rains have broken the worst drought in many areas; the flow of housing finance has continued at the higher level established in February; and interest rates have fallen.

As I noted in my address to the Summit Conference, we expect some improvement in economic activity in the course of 1983-84 with the main impetus coming from: The fiscal stimulus implicit in the Commonwealth Budget for 1982-83 and in prospect for 1983-84; the improvement in the international economy; a marked slowing in stock decumulation so that a greater proportion of increased demand will be met from additional production; the improved prospects for farm production and exports; the pick-up in dwelling construction already under way; and finally, but of fundamental importance, the improved prospects for ongoing moderation of income claims as the prices and incomes accord is implemented. Private sector spending is not expected to improve within that time frame and business fixed investment is expected to fall substantially further before it picks up.

If the expected pick-up in total activity is to be sustained beyond 1983-84, it will be a central task of policy to ensure that this imbalance is corrected; that is, that growth spreads through the private sector as well as the public sector. The expenditure and revenue decisions we have reached have had that consideration very much in mind. We are aware that the improvement in demand will take some time to lead to additional job creation. Accordingly we have given particular emphasis to the early introduction of direct job creation schemes. At the same time our decisions, overall, have been directed to the ongoing requirement of improving the general economic climate. Given that approach, and the implementation of our incomes policies, we would expect the pick-up in activity to be accompanied by a significant reduction in inflation and an improvement in profit levels.
Budget Policies

I turn now to the general objectives we have pursued and the general principles we have applied in reaching our present decisions. At the broadest level, as I have said, the objective has been to frame our budgetary policies to contribute both to reducing unemployment and to winding back inflation. In operational terms, that means looking to fiscal policy to stimulate employment directly but without placing intolerable burdens on the conduct of monetary policies or distorting the general economic environment needed to support the prices and incomes accord. Achieving the right balance is, of course, no easy task.

The Government is well aware that if the balance were not right-if the Budget were expanded too rapidly-there would be increased pressures on interest rates and on the balance of payments. Should that occur, any direct increases in employment flowing from the Budget would be offset-perhaps more than offset-by indirect falls in employment as private sector spending decisions were curtailed . That said, we have come to the judgment that a substantial increase in Budget programs and hence the Budget deficit from 1982-83 levels can occur in 1983-84 without incurring those risks. Fundamental to that judgment is our determination to see the prices and incomes accord implemented along the lines agreed at the Summit and to see that the accord is adequately supported by appropriate monetary policies. I shall have more to say on that later.

We believe that inflationary expectations are already on the wane. It is critical to the success of our expansionary fiscal policies that they remain so. We have had to judge how large the 1983-84 Budget impact should be to meet the requirement of stimulating employment without detracting from our efforts to reduce inflation. And we have to do that in the context of a prospective deficit for next year approaching $10 billion on the basis of the ongoing programs of the previous Government. We have said categorically-and I maintain-that such an outcome is simply not on. It would entail too many risks for the policy of sustained growth that we have in mind, risks connected with interest rates and the balance of payments, and indeed with the safe conduct of the prices and incomes accord. In order to provide for productive job creation activities, while minimising those risks, we have therefore been obliged to offset the additional expenditures involved by rather greater reductions in the previous Government's programs.

In approaching that task we have been heavily influenced by the guidance given by the Summit. In particular, we have focussed upon the central concept of equality of sacrifice and, where savings have had to be found, we have sought them in areas where those affected can most readily afford to shoulder the burden. In taxation, our long-standing policy has been to restore equity. We are committed to providing the Commissioner of Taxation with the legislation necessary to achieve that end. In the Budget sittings we will introduce further legislation and will continue to support the Commissioner in this and all other possible ways in ensuring that the tax burden is once again correctly spread across the community. Without this action we cannot expect the community to share with us the view that we all have an obligation to pay our fair share of taxes. Without this action the opportunities for taxpayers to opt out of the tax paying system will continue to grow as they began and were sustained under the previous Government. It is our overwhelming conviction that such a burden sharing approach is in the interests of the Australian community at large and particularly those most affected by the economic recession.
Policy Decisions

In this light the Government has reviewed many of the programs of the previous Government and is proposing a number of new programs. We have placed emphasis on creating new jobs, on increasing activity in the housing industry, on directing assistance to those in need and on removing unwarranted concessions. Many programs we have inherited are ill-suited to meet the current economic problems which Australia faces. They are also poorly designed to meet the needs of low income earners.

We found that a substantial proportion of the costs of tax concessions announced in and immediately prior to the 1982-83 Budget by the former Government-amounting to around $3,000m-first come to account next financial year . The Liberal Government which preceded us went beyond the limits of fiscal responsibility in increasing commitments to outlays and tax expenditures and reducing taxation through 1982 in a desperate attempt to retain office. But even more reprehensibly, it concealed the extent of the fiscal imbalances which it was creating from the Australian people, and arranged for the bills for its extravagance to be presented a year later, in 1983-84. When we have raised these points before, Opposition members have said that they would have changed their policies had they been re-elected. Perhaps they would have; the Australian people remember the fistful of dollars before the 1977 election which was taken back after the election. I have no doubt that the Opposition will find fault with some of the measures that we are announcing tonight. But they cannot have it all ways. If they say that they would taken steps to reduce the 1983-84 Budget deficit by as much as we will do in this statement, or more, then they accept our measures or propose alternatives. What would they have done? What would they have done for job creation and housing? What tax expenditures would they have amended? I look forward to hearing their alternatives.

I outline below the major initiatives of the Government from this initial review. Details of all affected programs are summarised in a paper I now seek leave to have tabled. Further information is to be provided to Parliament by relevant Ministers.
Retirement Incomes

Retirement incomes are heavily supported from the Budget, both directly through the provision of age and Service pensions and indirectly through generous tax concessions for occupational superannuation. On the outlays side, some of the assistance is directed to high income earners because of the income test-free component for pensions of persons aged 70 and over. On the revenue side, the $2 billion or so of assistance for occupational superannuation goes mostly to people who are neither needy nor poor and largely fails to achieve one of its principal objectives-the promotion of more effective self-provision in retirement. This is because benefits are principally being taken in the form of lump sums rather than pensions. The present tax provisions also facilitate tax avoidance arrangements under which an employee's pay is deferred so as to be taken in a lump sum termination payment at the end of his or her employment in a particular job.

Against this background, the Government has undertaken a comprehensive review of existing policies relating to retirement incomes and has decided to take three significant measures to rationalise the present system. These measures are designed to ensure that outlays on pensions are more effectively directed to those who need them, that tax concessions for occupational superannuation achieve their purpose of encouraging genuine provision for retirement incomes, and that retirement benefits provided in different forms are treated on a fairer basis than in the past.

First, the Government has reviewed the taxation treatment of certain lump sum payments which are presently exempt from tax entirely or are subject to tax on only 5 per cent of the amounts received. In general, and subject to certain exceptions detailed in a paper I now table, lump sum payments received after tonight for services after tonight will be subject to taxation-in most cases at the standard rate of tax of 30 per cent-unless converted into a pension or annuity or rolled over into another superannuation fund within a short time. In order to encourage retirees to use lump sum benefits to secure an income in retirement, such payments will be exempt from tax entirely if converted into a continuing retirement income in the form of a pension or annuity. That part of a lump sum which comprises a person's own contribution which have not attracted a tax rebate or deduction will also be exempt from tax. I emphasise that the proposed fuller taxation of lump sum payments does not apply to payments in respect of services up to the present time. This means that lump sum payments in the years immediately ahead to people who have been contributing to a superannuation fund for some time will continue to be largely exempt from taxation. It also means, of course, that employees need not consider retiring before they would otherwise have done so in order to ensure that the lump sum benefits they have already earned are treated according to the present tax rules . Lump sum amounts in respect of services up to today, whenever in the future they are made, will enjoy taxation treatment no less favourable than they would have received if paid today. The changed taxation treatment of lump sum payments is estimated to yield only $15m in additional revenue in 1983-84, but thereafter gains to revenue will increase by approximately $50m a year to a peak of about $ 420m.

Our second initiative in the area of retirement provision is that we have decided to take action to encourage people to convert assets, including lump sum retirement benefits, into regular incomes. To this end, we propose to amend the Life Insurance Act and the Income Tax Assessment Act along the general lines recommended by the National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry under Professor Hancock and the Taxation Review Committee, the Asprey Committee. This will make it possible for life offices and superannuation funds to sell annuities on more attractive terms than at present. We will also review present arrangements under which the return of capital component of an annuity is taken into account in the age pension income test. The changes we propose to the treatment of annuities, together with the proposed arrangements for exempting lump sum payments from taxation, if used to buy pensions or annuities, will assist retired people to obtain secure incomes during their retirement.

The Government expects that these reforms will help to ensure that tax concessions for superannuation achieve their intended purpose, and reduce present incentives for people who have the capacity to provide their own retirement incomes to arrange their affairs so as to become eligible for benefits intended for the needy. Some technical aspects of the new arrangements in relation to the taxation of lump sum benefits, such as the precise method of determining the portion of lump sum entitlements relating to service before the date of announcement, and the action we propose to take to facilitate the sale of annuities, will be decided after consultation with interested parties, including the life offices and superannuation funds. The consultations will also canvass the possible introduction of new types of securities, including indexed bonds, which could assist the institutions concerned to meet the needs of retired people in ways that are consistent with the Government's objectives.

The third major measure we have decided to take in relation to retirement incomes is to introduce an income test on the component of age and service pensions for persons aged 70 years and over which is presently paid free of any income test. Only persons with substantial private incomes will be affected. Single pensioners with non pension incomes up to $200 a week, and married pensioner couples with non pension incomes up to $333 a week, will continue to receive the same pension as at present. Above these amounts, the current income- test-free component will be reduced by $1 for every extra $2 of non pension income received. Entitlement to part pension will therefore continue for single persons aged 70 years or over with non pension income up to about $303 per week and for married couples with non pension income up to about $505 per week. The proposed new arrangements will come into effect from 1 November 1983 and are estimated to reduce Budget outlays by $167m in 1983-84. For decades successive governments have grappled with the problem of providing decent support for the aged. That problem has been almost totally bedevilled by the way in which the available resources has been sprayed around indiscriminately. The measures I have announced tonight provide a firm basis for the development of a secure system of retirement incomes that aged people deserve.
Repatriation Pensions

In addition, we propose some changes in the method of disbursement of repatriation pension payments. These are currently paid by cheque fortnightly in advance, or by direct credit to a nominated bank, building society or credit union account twelve weekly in arrears. The Government has decided that from 23 June 1983 all direct credits of repatriation pensions will be made fortnightly in advance. Letters outlining the conversion and explaining the arrangements will be sent to veterans.
Health

The Government's election health policy statement made it clear that the rebate for basic health insurance premiums would be abolished to help finance the Medicare arrangements. It will be abolished in respect of contributions for basic health insurance coverage after 30 June 1983. Premiums paid in 1982-83 to provide coverage up to 30 June 1983 will attract a rebate in assessments for the 1982-83 income year. The resultant savings in taxation revenue are estimated at $95m in 1983-84 and $550m in 1984-85.

At present, the Commonwealth contributes to the Hospital Benefits Reinsurance Trust Fund to assist hospital insurance organisations to help meet the cost of the insured chronically ill. The Government's election health policy statement made it clear that on the introduction of Medicare the Commonwealth would reduce its contribution to the Fund. In view of the impending introduction of Medicare, and the budgetary situation, the Government is to reduce by $80m to $20m the intended contribution to the Hospital Benefits Reinsurance Trust Fund in 1983-84 .

Under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme there are a number of multi-branded pharmaceutical products which bear different rates of subsidy. The Government has decided that for such generally equivalent pharmaceutical products, the price differential between the highest and lowest price brands should be reduced as soon as possible to no more than 5c. Savings in 1983-84 are estimated at $6m.
Education

An income test is to be applied to the living allowance payable to full time adult migrant education program students. This will bring treatment of such payments into line with payments to part time students of the program and other equivalent allowances. Savings in 1983-84 and in subsequent years are estimated at around $3m.
Industry-Transport

The maximum cost differential payable by consumers for the freighting of certain petroleum products, at present 1c a litre, will in future be indexed in line with increases in the consumer price index. As an initial step, the differential will be increased to 1.1c per litre on 1 June 1983. This measure will save about $10m in 1983-84.

In lieu of an increase in air navigation charges during 1983-84, the rate of excise on AVGAS and AVTUR will be increased by 2c a litre from 1 July 1983. This will ameliorate the sharp deterioration in the rate of recovery of costs incurred by the Government in the provision of aviation services. This increase will yield $15m in 1983-84. Proposed expenditure in 1983-84 on the redevelopment of the Brisbane Airport has been reviewed and estimates have been reduced for 1983-84 by $20m to an estimated $50m. The target date for completion, 1987, has not been affected by this revision. The Government has decided to suspend and defer certain projects under the aerodrome local ownership plan and to institute a thorough review of the costs and benefits of the plan. Savings in 1983-84 are estimated to be $8m.

We shall provide $5m in 1983-84 to complete initial design and route identification works on the Alice Springs to Darwin railway. Commonwealth assistance to the Northern Territory is very generous. In 1982-83, total per capita payments to the Northern Territory will be about $5,600-about five times the average level of per capita payments to the six States. In the light of this , and the significance of the rail project to the Northern Territory, we believe the Northern Territory Government should share with us the cost of constructing the railway. We intend to proceed on the basis that the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory contribute 60 per cent and 40 per cent respectively to construction costs. Part of the Commonwealth's contribution would be funded by transferring about $60m currently allocated to upgrading the Stuart Highway in the Northern Territory. Should the Northern Territory not accept this approach, the Commonwealth would be prepared to provide, in place of the railway, a high standard road link from Alice Springs to Darwin by 1987 and additional rail facilities for Alice Springs to provide an efficient transport alternative. The Commonwealth is proceeding this way in light of the prevailing budgetary situation, and the fact that it is plainly uneconomic to proceed simultaneously with both the construction of the Alice Springs-Darwin railway and the major upgrading of the parallel road link.
Communications

The Government has taken an in principle decision to sell up to 49 per cent of its equity in Aussat Pty Ltd to allow private sector participation in the ownership of the national domestic satellite communications system. The sale will be subject to an appropriate spread of shareholding and to the development of satisfactory arrangements being in place to protect the public interest, which may include regulation of satellite services to ensure co-ordination with terrestrial services. The Government is to increase the interest rate payable on that part of the interest bearing capital of Telecom Australia which is still subject to a 10 per cent per annum rate. The increase will provide $100m in 1983 -84. Telecom will determine-with the consent of the Minister for Communications -how to fund this additional payment and the need for an expanded capital program in 1983-84. As an illustration, in a full year the additional interest charge could be met by a one cent increase in the cost of local calls, a commensurate increase in short and medium distance subscriber trunk dialling charges and a $10 increase in annual telephone rental fees. As noted in the paper prepared for the Summit on price surveillance by the Government:

Public utility prices need, of course, to be high enough to cover operating costs, to provide an adequate return on capital, and to produce sufficient internal funds to finance new investment without undue reliance on loan markets: But the community would not expect prices to be raised to accommodate unauthorised wage demands or as an expedient to raise revenue for other Government purposes.
Moreover, when introducing the paper I said that the Government was:
Not seeking to encourage uneconomic pricing arrangements: Public utilities, like private corporations, must earn their keep.
Other Industry Measures

The Government has decided to terminate the special depreciation arrangements for storage facilities for petroleum fuel and the taxation concessions available in respect of conversions or replacements of oil-fired and liquefied petroleum gas-fired plant. These incentives were introduced to provide a short term boost to investment in these areas following the outbreak of the Iran-Iraq war in 1979 . That purpose has been achieved and the concessions will now be terminated.

Since the 1977-78 income year the primary producer averaging provisions have had the effect that tax is calculated at the rate on average income only in years when current income exceeds average income. Ordinary rates are applied in other years. Those arrangements-sometimes described as automatic in-out averaging-attracted criticism for several reasons. The most obvious objection is that they went beyond the objective of removing tax effects of fluctuations in incomes, and gave taxpayers with access to averaging a clear tax advantage over others. As well it became advantageous for those with access to averaging to have their taxable incomes fluctuate and disadvantageous to do anything to stabilise them. That made it impossible for the income equalisation deposit scheme to operate as intended; the in-out averaging threw the system out of gear . Commencing with the 1983-84 income year the rate on average income will be applied every year. The present arrangement limiting the amount of non-primary production income which is subject to averaging will remain. It is estimated that this measure will yield about $15m in 1983-84 and $20m in subsequent years.

There are some unsatisfactory features of the income equalisation deposit scheme other than those caused by the present averaging arrangements. The Government is developing a new IED scheme to provide an incentive for farmers to set aside in good years money for use in poor years. Approval of the Loan Council will be sought for its introduction, with its first application to deposits after 31 August 1983. Some features of the scheme will be outlined in a separate statement which I now table. The measure is expected to cost less than $1m in 1983-84; the budgetary effect in later years will depend on the response to the new scheme.

Under the depreciation measures announced by the former Government on 19 July 1982, depreciation over either 5 years or 3 years was to be allowed under the general depreciation provisions. As part of that package, the period of depreciation of certain primary production plant, including improvements for the storage of hay, grain or fodder, was reduced from 5 to 3 years. The Government this week introduced legislation to honour the previous Government's announcement last year that these provisions would apply from 19 July 1982. However, the Government considers that the reduction to 3 years goes beyond what is reasonable. It is clearly anomalous when compared to the deductions for capital expenditure allowed to other industries. Accordingly, the deduction period for those plant items is to revert to 5 years, with effect for plant acquired under a contract entered into after today or commenced to be constructed by the taxpayer after today.

The Government is mindful of the cash flow problems of many farmers this calendar year in the aftermath of the drought. The extension of the period of depreciation for primary production plant affected by this measure will not have a large effect until the 1984-85 financial year, mainly the first half of 1985. Revenue from this measure is estimated to be $9m in 1983-84, rising to $44m in 1984-85, $89m in 1985-86 and $128m in 1986-87. Following a comprehensive review of the previous Government's water programs, we have decided not to proceed with the supplementary program of the previous Government's proposed Bicentennial Water Resources Program. However, in its preparation of the 1983-84 Budget, the Government will be considering a continuation of the previous Government's National Water Resources Program which has been in operation since 1978-79. We have also decided to allocate funds under our employment generation initiative for the establishment of a Country Towns' Water Supply Improvement Program, and we will be discussing guidelines for this important program with the States in the near future.

The Government is seeking Loan Council approval to allow the Australian Wheat Board to borrow overseas to help finance its advance payments to growers. This will allow the Board to reduce hedging costs on overseas sales and to take advantage of any lower overseas interest rates. Subject to Loan Council approval , the Board will be able to borrow overseas up to an annual limit of not less than 50 per cent of its prospective net borrowing requirements. Approval will also be sought if borrowings beyond that level are judged to be appropriate in any year in the light of the prospective monetary situation, the prospective borrowing requirement and borrowing costs. Thus, there is no further need for the interest subsidy which has previously been provided to the Australian Wheat Board's borrowing. Accordingly no subsidy will be paid after 30 June 1983. Savings are estimated to be $19.8m in 1983-84 and about $30m in subsequent years .
Housing

Following discussions at the Summit, the Government has moved quickly and positively to ensure that housing will play a major role in economic recovery. We have been encouraged in this task by the strong co-operation from State governments, the housing industry and the financial institutions. Our plan is responsible. Assistance will be directed only to those in need. We will avoid the risk of overheating in the industry. After very careful consideration the Government has decided to seek to achieve house commencements at an annual rate of 130,000 to 135,000 in the second half of 1983-84.

The housing industry, including the building unions, have clearly indicated to us that this rate should be achievable without significant resource constraints and wage or other inflationary pressures. This will be sought by measures designed to lift both public and private dwelling activity. We will retain the option for the States to nominate part of their Loan Council funds for use in public housing under concessional terms and conditions. So long as we are confident that this does not lead to any diminution of effort by the States in this area of acute need, direct Commonwealth funding for public housing will be increased from $333m in 1982-83 to $500m in 1983-84, an increase of 50 per cent.

We will implement our election promise and introduce the First Home Ownership Assistance Scheme from 1 October 1983. This will provide, on an income tested basis, assistance of up to $7,000 for a family with two or more children, $6,500 for a family with one child and $5,000 for other eligible first home buyers. This subsidy will enable lower income home buyers to borrow more, thus reducing the deposit gap, or to reduce the repayment burden, or both. The new scheme will be subject to the same income test as that applying under the existing Home Deposit Assistance Scheme. The maximum grants will be available to home purchasers with a family income of up to 135 per cent of average weekly earnings with assistance tapering to zero at 155 per cent of average weekly earnings. The test applies to taxable income in the year before purchase. For those purchasing in 1983-84 the limits applying to taxable income in 1982-83 are $24,300 for a full grant tapering to zero at $27,900.

In deciding upon this new scheme, the Government has reviewed the operation of the existing schemes of assistance for home buyers and concluded that they are neither efficient nor effective in targeting assistance to those in most need and in providing a stimulus to the housing industry. In addition, because of the multiplicity of arrangements and their complexity of operation, the existing measures have proved so confusing to home buyers that, in many instances, benefits are not being taken up. The Government has decided therefore,with one important qualification, to terminate or phase out the operation of existing schemes.

The existing Home Deposit Assistance Scheme will be terminated from the date of commencement of the new First Home Ownership Assistance Scheme. Eligible first home buyers who purchase between today and the introduction of the new First Home Ownership Assistance Scheme will be able to apply for assistance under the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme. Total outlays on the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme, until its termination, and the new First Home Ownership Assistance Scheme will be $120m in 1983-84, increasing to $165m in 1984-85.

Consistent with our policy of directing Government assistance to those most in need, we will be terminating from 30 June 1983 the housing interest rebate introduced last August by the Fraser Government. This was a highly inequitable scheme, the great bulk of assistance going to high income earners able to take out large loans. The losers were the prospective home buyers on a modest income who received little assistance if they were able to buy a home and none at all if they could not. They will gain from tonight's measures, which will have the effect of putting home ownership within the reach of many more Australians.

In order to meet our social commitments and obligations, we will continue the special home loan interest tax rebate introduced in March 1982 for low income first home buyers who enter the scheme on or before 30 September 1983. The scheme will continue on an income tested basis with the income limits set at the same level as the new First Home Ownership Assistance Scheme. This will ensure that the lower income first home buyers, who have entered home ownership at a time of high interest rates, will continue to receive assistance to the end of their fifth year of first home ownership. No new entrants to that scheme will be accepted after introduction of the new First Home Ownership Assistance Scheme.

The full or partial abolition of the previous government's schemes will save $ 130m in 1983-84 and $420m in 1984-85. In addition to the steps taken to stimulate demand the Government is concerned to ensure that there is an adequate supply of housing funds at reasonable interest rates. We have received assurances from the banks and building societies that they will be able to increase their lending significantly in 1983-84 and against the background of our target rate of commencements, we will be consulting further with financial institutions regarding the availability of housing finance.
Other Tax Expenditures and Concessions

Under an anti-avoidance measure introduced by the former Government, unmarried minors currently pay tax rates of 46 per cent or higher on unearned income above $1,040 per annum. The original announcement indicated that the threshold would be $416, but it was later set at $1,040. The $1,040 threshold has come to be exploited in many tax minimisation schemes, and a reduction in it is necessary to control this. The threshold will be reduced to $416 from the beginning of the 1983-84 income year; the new shading-in range will be from $417 to $1,372. The measure will yield nothing in 1983-84 but $70m in the first full year.

A concessional rebate at the standard tax rate is available to taxpayers on the excess of expenditure over $1,590 on certain eligible items such as superannuation contributions, life insurance premiums, net medical expenses, education expenses and private rates. The rebate costs over $100 per annum but only about 10 per cent of taxpayers derive any benefit from it. It has been decided to increase the threshold amount of eligible expenditure for rebate purposes to $2,000 with effect from the 1983-84 income year. This is expected to result in a gain to revenue of $11m in 1983-84 and $70m in 1984-85.

It has been decided to abolish, as from 1 July, 1983, the rebate available on up to $1,000 of dividend income of individual taxpayers which was introduced in the last Budget. While some features in the taxation treatment of dividends, resulting from the interaction of the personal income and company income tax systems, have been criticised in recent studies, such as the Asprey and Campbell reports, the Government does not believe that the dividend rebate introduced by the previous Government was an appropriate or equitable response. In some circumstances the rebate would aggravate rather than reduce inequities. Indeed, it has much in common with a measure which the Asprey report described as an ' unacceptable alternative to the present system'. Abolition of the rebate is expected to increase revenue by $75m in 1983-84 and $105m in 1984-85.

Friendly societies do not currently bear tax on investment income from their life insurance and disability and accident insurance business. This has placed friendly societies at a distinct advantage over life insurance companies and has been a growing cause for concern. With the assistance of tax exemption their business has grown rapidly in recent years, and has involved policies of a kind which are of a concern from tax avoidance viewpoint. The Government has decided that the exemption for friendly societies on life, disability and accident insurance business will be terminated in respect of 1983-84 and later income years. Measures will be introduced to impose tax at a level comparable to that on the non-superannuation business of life insurance companies. Further details will be announced at a later date. This measure will not affect revenue in 1983- 84, but will add to it in 1984-85 and later years, and preserve revenue which would otherwise be forgone.

Generally, interest payable to non-residents from Australian sources is taxable under withholding arrangements at the rate of 10 per cent of the gross amount. There are some exceptions to this rule, two of which were criticised in the Campbell report as having discriminatory and distorting effects. Those two are the 'Australian Entity' exemption and the exemption for interest on borrowing by the Australian Industry Development Corporation.

The Government has decided that interest arising on moneys borrowed under contractual obligations entered into after tonight by 'Australian entities' as defined in the present legislation and by the Australian Industry Development Corporation will be subject to interest withholding tax. Interest on existing loans will continue to be exempt.

Exemption will continue to apply to interest on widely held overseas loans of a 'bearer bond' nature, borrowings by the Commonwealth and State governments, and borrowings by Commonwealth and State authorities where the Treasurer is satisfied that the authorities are not in direct competition with private sector enterprises. It is estimated that this measure will yield $12m in 1983-84 and $ 26m in 1984-85. Under section 77 of the Income Tax Assessment Act losses from exempt activities such as gold mining may be deducted against the taxpayer's income from other sources. From the commencement of the 1983-84 income year those losses will not be deductible. The Government is concerned at the potential that this provision has for tax avoidance uses, of which there are already indications. This measure does not change the current exemption of gold mining income from taxation.
Labour and Employment

The Government is to introduce legislation in the current session of Parliament to establish for a period of three years a Community Employment Program. In 1983 -84 $300m will be provided for this program. It has also been decided to introduce a Private Sector Assistance Program to replace the Special Youth Employment Training Program and to increase funding for other manpower and training schemes. Overall, some $733m will be allocated in 1983-84 for these activities, an increase of $383m or about 110 per cent over 1982-83. The $300m provided for the Community Employment Program, together with $100m for continuation of the wages pause program in 1983-84, will be allocated to projects which have the capacity to provide new jobs, particularly for those most disadvantaged in the labour market.

The objective will be to generate a level of activity in 1983-84 consistent with supporting in a full year 70,000 full time jobs for an average duration of six months. It is intended that the projects supported will lead to improved local community facilities and services, including improved roads and country water supplies. All levels of government and community organisations will participate in the Program, and projects will be selected through joint Commonwealth-State consideration. Special arrangements will apply to projects in the Australian Capital Territory and projects to be conducted by Commonwealth departments and authorities. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) will be making a detailed statement on the job creation initiatives by way of a second reading speech on the introduction of the relevant legislation.
Overview of Fiscal Measures

The new expenditure initiatives I have just announced will add an estimated $ 557m to outlays in 1983-84. The savings I have just announced on the expenditure and tax expenditure programs of the previous Government are estimated to total $ 985m in 1983-84. These decisions take into account the fact that we have a longer term structural Budget problem arising from the policies of the previous Government. We shall have to deal-and we shall-with that problem and, in this connection, I direct the attention of honourable members to the longer term savings involved in many of the measures announced tonight. In total the figures indicate that, on the basis of present estimates, gross savings on the policies of the previous Government will increase to an estimated $2,036m in 1984-85 and to $2,190m in the following year. Those are significant savings and represent an important initial contribution to the task of implementing the Government's priorities within the context of responsible fiscal policies. I stress again that we view the implementation of our policies, and the review of those of the previous Government, as a continuing process in which the decisions announced tonight should be seen as the initial steps. That process will be furthered in many ways, including in discussion with State governments in the Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting at the end of June. In that context, we will be looking to increase the State authorities' domestic or overseas borrowing programs for 1983-84 to ensure that, in conjunction with other measures, there will be scope for real growth in those authorities' capital expenditures next year.
Concluding Remarks

Mr Speaker, I wish to underline the importance which our Government places upon the success of the prices and incomes accord and the monetary policies necessary to support it. By reducing the Budget deficit for 1983-84 below that implied by the policies of the previous Government we will be reducing the financing task and hence the burden upon monetary policy. But that financing task, and that burden, will still be considerable-and will be coming on top of a monetary situation which our predecessors had for some time allowed to drift and which, as a consequence, is already most unsatisfactory.

To take only the current financial year, the previous Government set itself a target for growth in the money supply, M3, of 9-11 per cent for 1982-83, but by March this year that target was already virtually out of reach. In the 12 months to March, M3 increased by 12.4 per cent and the average increase for the year to date was already at the top of the previous Government's target range. Yet the monetary expansion effects of the last Budget are heavily concentrated in the current half year. That is to say, with the real push in monetary expansion from the Budget only just recently coming through, the monetary target had already been allowed to drift out of reach. Monetary growth as rapid as the current level of 12 per cent or so is not consistent with this Government's objectives and prompt action is necessary to bring it down. Accordingly, and in keeping with the previously foreshadowed timetable, the Treasury is announcing this evening the details of a bond tender considerably larger than had previously been thought likely to be necessary. The tender will be for an amount of $1,500m , which is $400m larger than any previous tender. I trust that this will indicate to all concerned our determination to pursue appropriate monetary policies-not merely, as was the case with the previous Government, by rhetoric, but by action.

We are determined, as I have said, to achieve a monetary environment in which our prices and incomes accord will succeed and non-inflationary growth can be sustained. I would like to dwell for a moment on that latter point-the requirements for success of the prices and incomes accord. In particular, I want to deal with the criticisms which have been levelled at the Government from some quarters because it did not, in the course of the Summit, give more support to the type of wage outcomes contained in scenario C rather than those in scenario A.

To refresh our memories, I note that Scenario A assumed a national wage case in the second half of this calendar year leading to a general wage increase of about 3 per cent, to be followed by a return to indexation of wages in the first half of 1984; scenario C, on the other hand, assumed that the wages pause would be continued to the end of 1983, with only partial indexation to follow thereafter.

Accepting all the qualifications which must be placed on such exercises- qualifications which I went out of my way to stress in my own address to the Summit Conference-it is true that scenario C indicated both lower inflation and lower unemployment than did scenario A. The Government does not question that conclusion. We have promoted the need for wage restraint and that approach found acceptance by all participants in the Summit. But it is necessary to look not just at immediate requirements but also at the institution of a prices and incomes policy which can be sustainable over the longer term.

Many of Australia's economic problems in recent years were created by the deliberate tactics of the previous Government around the time of the 1980 election in generating unrealistic expectations regarding the magnitude of the wage increases which industry could afford. It would be equally dishonest and equally disastrous-because it simply would not be sustainable-if we went to the other extreme and sought to deny any wage increases at all this year. That would indeed be, to quote Samuel Johnson, a triumph of hope over experience. It is true that the degree of understanding of these issues has been enhanced by the Summit and subsequent discussions. It is equally true that there is still a long way to go and much more to be done to foster that understanding. It is the Government's view, therefore, that in this as in other matters, there must be a sense of proportion, a sense of balance. The Government, for its part, has pursued that balance-in its approach to the budgetary decisions I have announced tonight and, as I have just indicated, in its approach to the prices and incomes accord. Unless the same balanced approach is pursued by all, however, the consensus reached by the Summit will not endure. In concluding, therefore, may I refer again to the notion of equality of sacrifice which is implicit in the prices and incomes accord and which, as I have already noted, has been a guiding principle in the budgetary decisions I have now announced. I cannot stress too strongly the fundamental importance of that principle in the current economic circumstances.

Some of the changes we have made to the previous Government's programs were overdue and would have been desirable in any circumstances. Some, however, will result in the removal of benefits which might perhaps have been justified in better times. It is the Government's belief that the Australian ethic of a fair go provides the will to share the burden. This was the message that the Government received at the Summit. There is no practical alternative to a fairer sharing of restraint if we are to return to a healthier economy in which living standards can rise and jobs can become available to all Australians.

The Government believes that the measures announced tonight provide for a reallocation of incomes and opportunities which is both fair and conducive to economic recovery. With the consistent application of the principles underlying tonight's measures to our further Budget deliberations and monetary policy decisions, we believe that Australia is now well positioned for national reconciliation, reconstruction and recovery. I commend the measures to honourable members.

SUPPORTING STATEMENT BY TREASURER, THE HON. P. J. KEATING ON NEW TAX ARRANGEMENTS RELATING TO RETIREMENT LUMP SUMS

The Government proposes, with effect after today, to change the income tax rules that apply to those lump sum retirement and kindred payments which are currently assessable as to only 5 per cent of the amount paid. In this category are payments from superannuation funds on retirement through age or invalidity or on earlier cessation of an employment, 'golden handshakes' and other severance payments, contractual termination payments, payments for unused sick leave and amounts, other than bona fide redundancy payments, paid in compensation for loss of office or employment. Certain other lump sums which have their origin in untaxed remuneration or other income but under existing law are not taxed at all , will also be brought within the new arrangements.
The following measures are proposed:
(a) new tax arrangements shall apply to certain lump sum superannuation and other entitlements received after today in respect of services after today;
(b) the lump sums so affected shall be:

(i) those which fall within the provisions of the existing law under which 5 per cent of retirement or termination amounts is included in assessable income, except that no change will be made to the tax arrangements relating to bona fide redundancy payments as set out in sub-paragraph (c) below; and
(ii) certain kindred payments which are not taxed at all under existing law such as-
(A) amounts received in full or partial commutation of a pension;

(B) lump sums received by the executor or dependants of a deceased person if those payments represent unused annual leave or long service leave, or amounts from superannuation funds that would be within the new arrangements if they had been received by that person while living; and
(C) distributions from a superannuation fund during an employee's service that are made in accordance with the fund's rules;
(c) the Commissioner of Taxation will be authorised to determine whether a payment is a bona fide redundancy payment on the following bases:

(i) a principal element in determining whether a lump sum is a bona fide redundancy payment will be that the recipient's employment has been prematurely brought to an end as part of a reduction in the work-force of the employer or the group of which the employer forms part, and that there is no arrangement for the re-employment of the person;
(ii) payments between closely associated persons, such as a lump sum paid by a private company to a shareholder of the company would not qualify; and
(iii) a lump sum will qualify as a bona fide redundancy payment only to the extent that it exceeds the amount which the person would have received had he resigned or retired from the employment;

(d) subject to anti-avoidance rules, there will be no change in the taxation treatment of capital sums received in consideration of an agreement not to compete against a former employer or by way of compensation for loss of income through personal injury;
(e) that amount of lump sum superannuation and other entitlements which is in respect of services after the date of announcement will generally be assessable in full except that:

(i) no tax shall be payable on such an amount to the extent that it represents the return of a person's own superannuation contributions made after the date of announcement, where those contributions have not attracted a tax rebate or deduction; and

(ii) amounts will generally be taxed at no more than 30 per cent, except that the tax rate will be 46 per cent of that part of the fully assessable amount which is between $125,000 and $225,000 and 60 per cent of that part of the fully assessable amount which exceeds $225,000;
(f) a lump sum which is converted into a pension or annuity, or which is ' rolled over' into another superannuation fund within a short time, will be exempt from tax.

Else-Mitchell, says in his foreword to this report, for at least six years there has been a debate in Australia on the relative cost of delivering legal aid through private lawyers or by salaried lawyers employed by legal aid agencies. This debate has assumed a new urgency because the cost of legal aid is escalating in a manner which now seems to be almost out of control. Let me illustrate. Since 1979-80 Commonwealth payments for private lawyers have increased in real terms by 80.2 per cent whereas the number of cases handled by private lawyers during that period has increased by only 27.1 per cent. Expressed in money terms, total direct expenditure by the Commonwealth on legal aid has risen from $21.3m in 1979-80 to an estimated $51.44m in 1982-83, a cumulative increase of 141.5 per cent, and payments to private lawyers have risen from $14.679m to an estimated $35.181m, a cumulative increase of 139 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is obviously essential that legal aid be delivered in the most efficient and economical manner possible, and one way-although by no means the only way-it has been suggested this could be achieved is by delivering a greater proportion of aid through salaried lawyers. The matter was first seriously raised in 1974 in the report of Professor Ronald Sackville on Law and Poverty in Australia. It was later raised by the then Attorney-General, Mr Ellicott, in an address to the Western Australian Law Summer School on 18-19 March 1977 following a study in the Australian Legal Aid Office and the New South Wales Public Solicitor's Office. Considerable impetus was given to the debate by the study in 1980 by officers of the South Australian Legal Services Commission which concluded that the cost of delivering legal aid by salaried lawyers rather than through referrals to private practitioners was up to twice as cheap in civil cases and three times as cheap in criminal cases.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tate raised the question of a study into the comparative cost of providing legal aid services by salaried legal officers as opposed to private practitioners at the Senate Estimates Committee hearing on 13 October 1978. He and other honourable senators have raised the matter at each six-monthly Senate Estimates hearing since then. Following these expressions of concern the then Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission determined in March 1979 to undertake such a study. A feasibility study was undertaken and the study itself commenced in March 1981. Although it was estimated originally that the study would be completed in August 1981, the final report was not presented to the council until late 1982. In his foreword to the report, Mr Justice Else-Mitchell comments adversely on the delays. The report has now been published by the Commonwealth Legal Aid Council and is available for distribution. It does not, however, appear that this report will constitute the last word on the subject, notwithstanding all the time and effort that have gone into its production. I invite honourable senators to have particular regard in this respect to the comments made by Mr Justice Else-Mitchell in his foreword where he indicates that in its present form the report will not assist in determining whether a particular matter should be allocated to a private lawyer or to a salaried lawyer. I am concerned that this study does not appear to have settled the debate as it was originally designed to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you were going to incorporate that?

—I am incorporating the appendix to it. I have only two or three pages to read, so hold on to your horses. It seems clear that a methodology exists which will allow comparisons to be made and the report does contain formulae which, if applied correctly, would provide the answers sought. But unfortunately it fails to apply those formulae in such a way as to arrive at conclusions that can be generally accepted. The basic conclusion reached by Professor Meredith is that there are no significant differences in the costs of delivering legal aid as between private and salaried lawyers. This conclusion appears, however, to be rendered quite unsafe by a number of considerations including inconsistencies in the application of data in comparable calculations, doubts about whether the sample of private lawyers chosen was properly representative, inclusion of non-comparable costs (for example the cost of administering referred matters within the Commissions) in some comparisons, and sundry arithmetical errors. I have prepared a detailed commentary, which is appendix A on the main conclusions in the report and seek leave to incorporate this and a further appendix in Hansard at the conclusion of this statement. Among the interesting conclusions to emerge from this analysis is that, whereas to have case work done by in-house salaried lawyers costs $31.24 per hour, the cost of salaried lawyers engaged in administering the supervising cases assigned to private lawyers is $54.83 per hour.

SPEECH.PARA: The primary objective of the present Government's legal aid policy, faced as we are with the necessity to pare expenditure to the bone, is simply to make the existing legal aid dollar go further. While I recognise, of course, that the private profession has played and will continue to play a very important role in the delivery of legal aid services it seems that the time has come to review delivery methods, with a view to placing significantly greater emphasis on the role of the salaried service so long as the evidence points to the greater cost effectiveness of this approach. The Government's aim in funding legal aid must be to promote equal access to the law in an economically efficient and effective way, rather than to provide guaranteed levels of income to the private profession: However, in a time of significant unemployment among qualified practitioners any moves to develop the salaried service should not simply be seen as reducing opportunities for the private legal profession, so much as creating new opportunities for the profession as a whole in the salaried service . The review of legal aid to which I have referred will not be restricted to this aspect only. Legal aid funding is not a bottomless pit. It is necessary to examine all facets of practice and expenditure in an endeavour to find ways in which legal aid can be made more cost effective. Increases in real terms of the magnitude of 80 per cent in three years cannot be allowed to continue.

In this context, the establishment-presently under consideration-of a new national legal aid commission continuously to co-ordinate and monitor legal aid services is of great importance. This Commission will have the essential function of monitoring the availability of legal aid State by State, ensuring the best use of available finances and promoting uniformity in eligibility criteria for Australians seeking legal aid. The Commission would be assisted by information from the national legal aid statistics collection which will commence in about April 1984 after installation of a computerized office system in all legal aid commissions and the Australian Legal Aid Office. This joint Commonwealth-State venture is currently under way. I table this report in full awareness of its deficiencies and confusions. I am disappointed that it has not put an end to the long-lasting debate. Definitive conclusions must await the implementation of the national legal aid computer system, the collection of comprehensive data and its proper analysis, and it seems unlikely that this can occur before mid-1984. I trust that there will be constructive discussion on the issues I have raised here today. There is much which can be done in this regard, and I am sure that there will be a good measure of disinterested and self- critical analysis by lawyers themselves as we together seek the solution which best promotes the public interest. As I indicated in the course of the statement , there are attachments to it which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Appendix A
COMMENT ON REPORT'S CONCLUSIONS
Summaries of the 8 specific conclusions drawn by the report and set out in Chapter 1.4 (page 7) and Chapter 4 (Page 57) are set out below, together with comments on each.

First Conclusion: Much of the Australian literature fails to evaluate the total costs associated with alternative legal aid delivery systems and therefore includes invalid comparisons between the alternative systems.

Although this claim is repeated several times, none of the literature which studies these cost comparisons is examined in the report. Four sets of findings are referred to (pp. 28-29), all to the effect that salaried work is cheaper than referrals to the private profession. There is no attempt to analyse or evaluate these findings or the methods adopted to achieve them, but merely a generalised assertion that they fail to take into account the total cost of legal aid agencies necessary to support the work of salaried lawyers.

The four sets of findings referred to are derived respectively from the 1976 and 1977 Annual Reports of the N.S.W. Commissioner for Legal Aid Services, the 1978 paper prepared by the N.S.W. Public Solicitor's Office on duty lawyers' services and the 1980 study by the Research and Education Section of the Legal Services Commission of South Australia. In fact each set of findings does take into account costs other than the direct salary and salary-related costs of lawyers. Moreover, all the other relevant studies cited by Professor Meredith in his bibliography do purport to include all direct and indirect costs associated with legal aid delivery.

Second Conclusion: Cost differences as between salaried and private lawyers can be expected given differences in personnel efficiency, organisational structure, fee scale bases and the approach taken by professionals.

While this conclusion may be unexceptionable, it does nothing to advance the state of knowledge as to the cost of delivery through salaried or private lawyers, and contradicts some of the basic assumptions upon which the study was undertaken (pp. 3-5). Levels of efficiency, quality of work, structure of legal aid bodies and the manner of service delivery were supposedly all assumed constant for the purpose of conducting this cost comparison. Throughout the entire report, however, these factors are put forward as reasons for varying results, which confuses the issue considerably.

Third, Fourth and Fifth Conclusions: Total cost per person, total cost per professional and cost per lawyer hour are similar for legal aid agencies and private practices i.e. differences in the costs of delivering legal aid are not significant.

These conclusions clearly must be read in the context of the method of calculation adopted. It does appear that dividing the total operating cost of a Legal Aid Commission (not including the actual amounts paid to private lawyers) by the number of people employed by that Commission produces a figure for cost per lawyer similar to that obtained by dividing the total operating cost of a private law office by the number of people employed in that office. It does not, however, necessarily follow that the costs of delivering legal aid by these two methods are therefore similar.
There are several problems inherent in the method used by the consultant to obtain these figures, and further problems in the specific material relied upon. In particular:

(i) There must be significant doubt as to whether the sample of private solicitors' offices used is in fact representative of solicitors' offices in N.S .W. Table 3 (p. 20) shows offices ranging in size from 11 to 130 lawyers, yet information supplied by the N.S.W. Law Society shows that over half of all firms in N.S.W. consist of sole practitioners. Furthermore, there is no indication as to the mode of selecting the 16 legal practices comprising the sample used for Tables 1 and 3.

(ii) There is no indication of the sources for the figures on total operating costs of legal aid commisions (Table 2), although the figures would appear to derive from the annual reports of the respective commissions. Moreover, there are unexplained differences in the figures used in Tables 4 and 5 (''cost per professional'' for South Australia in 1980-81 is shown in Table 4 as $83,416 and in Table 5 as $72,037), and arithmetical errors in Tabe 1 (at items 3 and 16) and Table 3 (at item 3), all of which must affect the validity of comparisons made therein.

(iii) No explanation is given of how the figures for ''cost per effective legal aid lawyer hour'' in Table 8 are arrived at. The only other figures in the report which would seem relevant to such a calculation are those contained in Table 4 for total operating cost per professional. When, however, those figures are applied to this calculation, they produce strikingly different results from those set out in Table 8.

(iv) The consultant was specifically requested to restrict his study of referrals to private lawyers to the actual cost to the legal aid commissions: i. e. what amounts were paid by way of costs to private lawyers, rather than what it cost the lawyers to undertake the task. The report repeatedly addresses the latter which, although relevant and useful information, is of much less immediate concern to the funder of legal aid than the former.

(v) The cost per salaried lawyer for Legal Aid Commissions as set out in the report (Tables 4 and 8) does not reflect the actual cost of delivering legal aid case work by salaried lawyers. In calculating this cost, the report has included in the base figure for the relevant costs of a Commission some items which would not constitute part of the overheads of a private law firm and others which bear no relation to the delivery of legal aid by the Commission. These items include advertising, public educational material and activities, and the costs of administering assignments to private lawyers. Such items should not have any place in a comparative calculation of the cost per lawyer hour; if they are included, they should at the very least be separately identified.

(vi) The figure used for the amount of chargeable time spent by lawyers in an average year varies throughout the report. For example, at page 21 1300 hours per annum is used to calculate cost per professional hour for both private and salaried lawyers; at pages 37 and 38 1063 and 1472 hours are used in the alternative to calculate salaried lawyer costs in legal aid commissions; and at pages 48 and 49 (Table 10) 1650 hours per annum is used in relation to N.S.W. Legal Services Commission salaried lawyers. Table 7 (page 35) shows yet another figure of 1635 hours per annum. There is no adequate explanation for the variations between these figures nor for how the figures themselves were arrived at.

(vii) Pages 25 and 26 compare the differential cost of a salaried lawyer (the total cost of appointment of an additional salaried lawyer) with the private lawyer mark-up rate (the salary mark-up applied to the lawyer's salary to determine his charge-out rate per hour of client work). The ''rule of thumb'' formulae used here-salary + 90% for salaried lawyers and 2.5 times salary for private lawyers-are not adequately explained, but are used to support a finding that the differential cost and mark-up rate ''may be similar''.

In any case, this conclusion is of no value to the cost comparison in question. Although these formulae may be applied in a global sense, the differential cost or mark-up rate of a lawyer will vary widely as between individual positions, since that cost or rate will differ according to the nature of the job. For example, duty lawyers do not need large support staff and therefore the differential cost involved in appointing an additional duty lawyer will be considerably less than that of appointing a lawyer who will require significant support staff.

(viii) The use in Table 10 of 1650 hours as the annual effective time worked by ''in-house'' lawyers assumes an efficiency in excess of 100% if the figure in Table 7 of 1635 lawyer hours per annum is accepted as the base. This compares with an apparent efficiency of 79.5% for private lawyers who are assumed (page 21) to allocate 1300 hours of the total of 1635 per annum to client legal services. Thus the hourly costs calculated for ''in-house'' lawyers are too low.

Sixth Conclusion: From the data supplied by the New South Wales Legal Services Commission, actual cost per salaried lawyer hour varied from $29.24 to $52.67 depending upon the specific activities of the lawyer and costs of agency departments.

The staff of the New South Wales Legal Services Commission undertook the difficult and time-consuming task of collecting the data sought. This was the only empirical study carried out during the project but, unfortunately, the data obtained does not appear to have been properly used.

It should be said at the outset that time recording systems were not implemented in the New South Wales Commission during this study, nor was any attempt made to sample cases and record accurate hours for handling these cases. Rather an estimate was made of the proportion of time spent by each staff member in the various defined activities, namely, general administration, general legal services, pre-assignment activities and post-assignment activities.

The data obtained from this study forms the basis of Table 10. The conclusion reached on the basis of Table 10 is that 'the total costs per lawyer hour varied from $29.24 for post-assignment in-house activities to $52.67 for post- assignment referral activities'.

An analysis of Table 10 prepared for the Legal Services Commission of New South Wales by its research section shows, however, that the data is not utilised correctly. The relevant extract from that analysis is, with the Commission's approval, attached as Appendix B to this Statement.

A revised Table 10 has been prepared by my Department in the light of that analysis which corrects the identified errors in the original, and in particular uses a figure of 1,300 hours per annum for the effective salaried lawyer time. The figure of 1,300 is that used by Professor Meredith for private lawyers (p. 21).
