As can be seen, the revised Table 10 shows that the hourly cost of salaried lawyers engaged in ''in-house'' case work is $31.24 while the cost of salaried lawyers engaged in administering and supervising cases assigned to private lawyers is $54.83 per hour.

This is a significant result. Nevertheless, to enable the desired cost comparison to be made, it is necessary to add the actual cost of private referrals i.e. fees and disbursements paid by the Commission, to the cost to the Commission of administering and supervising such referrals.

Table 11 (Page 52) provides some information in this regard but it is wholly unsatisfactory as a basis for comparison. The table refers to only 2 cases, of 100 and 90 hours duration respectively. The source of the data in relation to these cases is not disclosed-it was not obtained from the Legal Services Commission of New South Wales-and the cases cited would appear not to be typical . For example it is known from other studies that over half of all family law matters take less than 5 hours of lawyer time to complete, yet the family law case in Table 11 is recorded as having taken ninety hours to complete. Moreover, the amount of time spent in supervision by Commission lawyers seems to be excessive in both cases. It is difficult to understand how Professor Meredith could seek to derive general conclusions from the evidence of two isolated cases , the basis for the selection of which is not even indicated.

Failing a thorough analysis of the accounts received by the Commission from private lawyers, some guidance for the purposes of comparison can be derived from the hourly rates which were being paid to the private profession under NSW legal aid costs scales during the relevant period (November 1981 to April 1982). Those hourly rates were as follows:
Family Law Act-$47
Duty Lawyer in Courts of Petty Sessions-$35
Conferences (Junior Counsel)-$48
District Court matters-$55

These hourly costs, which average out at $46.25, are significantly different from the $31.24 hourly cost of salaried laywers doing in-house case work. In addition, the cost to the Commission of referring and supervising at a rate of $ 54.83 per hour each matter referred to a private lawyer must be taken into account. On the basis of the data collected for Professor Meredith, the research unit of the NSW Legal Services Commission estimates that the average salaried lawyer time spent per matter on this referral and supervisory function is 2.7 hours, so that an average figure of $148.04 for administrative expenses of the Commission must be added to each account received from private lawyers.
In summary the comparative costs to the Legal Aid Commission are as follows:
cost of salaried lawyers doing in-house case work-$31.24 per hour.
average cost of matters assigned to private lawyers (in four areas for which hourly rate figures are available)-$46.25 per hour.

cost of salaried laywers administering and supervising work assigned to private lawyers-$54.83 per hour, and at an average 2.7 hours per account, $148.04 to be added to each private lawyer account for administration.

Seventh and Eighth Conclusions: Many assumptions were necessary to enable valid comparisons to be made between the two delivery systems, due to the absence of time-cost date from legal aid agencies; no universal conclusion can be reached that one system always cost less to the legal aid fund than another; and each aid case must be examined individually to determine whether cost would be minimised by handling it in-house or by referring it to a private lawyer.

The terms of reference for the study included a requirement that time-cost data be collected from legal aid commissions. It is unfortunate that, due in some measure to the manner in which Professor Meredith conducted the early part of the inquiry, he was not able to persuade legal aid commissions to embark upon an extensive data collection exercise and thus the collection was ultimately restricted to the NSW Legal Services Commission. It is also unfortunate that he did not conduct a study of accounts received by that Commission or seek any information relating to accounts paid. He was therefore not able to provide any formula or method which could be used by legal aid staff to analyse private lawyer accounts so as, in his words, ''to decide whether the cost to the funder of a legal aid matter would be minimised by handling the matter in-house or referring the matter to a private lawyer''.
Appendix B
Extract from Analysis of Meredith Report by Y. Reuben, Research Officer, Legal Services Commission of New South Wales, March 1983
''Modifying Methodology given available data

As noted previously time-recording systems were not implemented in New South Wales nor was any attempt made to sample cases and record accurate hours for handling these cases. Modifications were made to the methodology which negated the necessity to perform these tasks (pp. 44-46).

All the modifications outlined, except for number 7 (p. 45) appear reasonable, if an assessment of costs per lawyer hour is being calculated for defined areas of work e.g. time devoted to supervision of referral work or time spent on actual casework. Modification number 6 states: ''assuming salary allocations relate to hours worked, an approximation of professional lawyer time could be made based on salary allocation. A direct cost per lawyer hour can therefore be calculated'' (p. 45). Given this assumption, direct cost per lawyer hour could be calculated for all five areas of work covered, as salaries were apportioned for each individual employee according to the amount of time devoted to all 5 areas.

To calculate the total cost per lawyer hour, overhead costs must be allocated across all staff and work areas. However, only overhead costs should be allocated and not salaries related to General Administration as is advised in modification number 7. Administrative support costs for the 4 legally related work areas have already been taken into account and are presented as ''Salaries: administrative staff''. The salary figures found under General Administration are totally unrelated to legal aid work. They arise from the fact that staff are employed in a government department which is subject to a range of requirements applying throughout the public service, e.g. guaranteeing equal opportunity in employment, providing staff development programmes and complying with public service personnel requirements. Like activities would not be performed by private firms in the main and costs attributed to general administration should be kept quite distinct from the other 4 work areas which directly represent the provision of legal aid. Administrative support costs related to legal aid activities are accounted for and it is these costs that are relevant to the cost comparison and not the costs attributable to the general administration of a large public service organisation. These costs are only relevant if the total cost to funder is being examined. Then the total cost of the legal aid agency would be compared to the total cost of private firms and total cost of general administration would have to be taken into account. As this was not part of the researcher's brief any costs related to general administration should be identified but kept quite distinct from the costs related to the provision of legal aid.
This error has a marked effect on the resulting total costs per lawyer hour increasing them unnecessarily as shall be seen when Table 10 (p. 49) is examined .

The approach outlined in modification number 10 (p. 46) seems quite valid if a substantial number of cases are examined, and might in fact produce guidelines for legal aid managers deciding on the assignment of particular cases to in- house staff or private firms. Unfortunately this was not done by the researcher as shall be seen when Table 11 (p. 52) is examined.
Illustration of Cost Comparisons for Legal Aid Agencies

A summary of the data provided by the New South Wales Legal Services Commission is outlined on pages 46-50. Examples of legal aid cases and time spent by private practitioners and in-house staff were never requested from the New South Wales Legal Services Commission and it is unknown where the data contained in pages 51-53 has come from.

Looking however at the data that was supplied by the Commission, it should be pointed out that post-assignment activities and consequently salaries for all individuals were divided into: civil, criminal indictable, criminal petty sessions and visiting justice/mental health committal work for in-house staff; and civil, criminal, children and prisoners for referral staff. This was done in an effort to provide enough detail to enable costs per lawyer hour to be calculated for particular areas of case-work, e.g. cost per lawyer hour for civil in-house work as compared with criminal indictable matters.

It is evident from Tables 9 and 10 (pp. 48 and 49) that these sub-divisions have been ignored and only aggregate figures for in-house and referral work have been utilised. It is unclear as to why this was done and is in fact very unfortunate since little comparative use can be made of cost per lawyer hour for in-house work when fees paid to private practitioners vary so much depending on the particular area of work involved. For example for civil matters, solicitors are paid 80% of scale while in the criminal areas daily lump sum payments are made. Also, the cost of referring work to the private profession varies according to the type of case.

The analysis of the data supplied is presented in Table 10 (p. 49). The error concerning allocation of 'general administration' salaries in addition to general overheads has been noted in discussion of modification number 7. The error is evident in Column 1 of Table 10. The salary figures of $90,269 and $292 ,101 should remain distinct and only the figures related to overheads of $37,855 and $285,177 (totalling $323,032) should be allocated across the work areas.

A proportion of overhead costs must therefore be allocated to all 5 work areas and not just the 4 legally related activities as was done by the researcher. Once the correct allocation has been carried out costs related to each of the 5 work areas are clearly defined, each with a component for salaries and overheads , with general administration costs distinct from the areas related to the provision of legal aid. Direct and total cost per lawyer hour can then be calculated according to the formula outlined.

It can therefore be seen when the correct figures are substituted in Table 10 that the Total Costs per lawyer hour are substantially less than the amounts appearing on page 49 of the report. There are however two points which must still be raised that would once again have an effect on Total cost per lawyer hour.

The first deals with the omission of $105,680 worth of expenses related to salaries, covering workers' compensation and payroll tax. This figure was supplied to the researcher but does not appear anywhere in the report. This amount should be added to overhead costs thus increasing this component to $405, 680. This would raise the total cost per lawyer hour slightly. For example for pre-assignment activities, the cost becomes $26.34 and for in-house work, $24.61 .

The second point concerns the researcher's use of 1650 lawyer hours per year to calculate direct and total costs per lawyer hour. Previously 1300 hours was used , at a later point various efficiency rates were examined ranging from 1063 hours (65% effective) to 1472 (90% effective) and yet here 1650 hours are used. This would represent over 100% efficiency according to the effective hour scale used by the researcher. This inconsistency is inexcusable and leads to substantial confusion as to what effective lawyer hours per year should in fact be. A reasonable number of hours might be 1300 per year (80% on the efficiency scale) rather than 1650. This would increase direct and total costs per lawyer hour accordingly. For example, direct cost per lawyer hour for pre-assignment activities would equal $27.36 and $26.33 for in-house work. Total costs per lawyer hour using correct allocation of overheads (including salary related expenses) results in $33.43 for pre-assignment activities and $31.24 for in- house work. The matter of effective lawyer hours must be clarified before any comparative use can be made of a cost per lawyer hour.

Once these issues have been clarified it would be useful to conduct an analysis of the data supplied to the research in its orginal form i.e. with divisions of in-house and referral work into legal areas. This would result in more meaningful cost per lawyer hour dependant on legal area.''

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few preliminary remarks in relation to this statement and the report on 'Legal Aid Cost Comparison-Salaried and Private Lawyers'. I will then seek leave to continue my remarks at a later date when this matter is brought on for proper and full debate. The report that Senator Gareth Evans has tabled and the statement that he has made on it are an important matter for discussion in the Senate, in the community and amongst the legal profession. They deal with the very difficult and important question as to what is the most effective way of delivering legal aid and, in particular, the way in which the most can be made of the limited funds that are available for legal aid. As the statement indicates, there was a great increase in the funds made available for legal aid in recent years by the previous Government during the period when I was Attorney-General. Demands for legal aid were growing very greatly during that period. Unfortunately, the increased funds available, though well in excess of the cost of living during that period, were not really reflected in a similar increase in the number of cases that could be handled. So, that is certainly a matter which exercised my mind very considerably. I notice that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans ) is concerned with the same problem.

SPEECH.PARA: One major debate that has gone on-indeed I might even say raged-not only just the last few years but for many years, since the establishment of the Australian Legal Aid Office, has been on the question whether legal aid can be delivered more efficiently by salaried officers or by reference of the matters to the private legal profession. When I say 'more efficiently', I use that term in its broadest sense. Of course, matters may be able to be handled more cheaply by one method or another, but that is not to say that, in the broad analysis of cost benefit and so on to the client, one or other method can be clearly shown to be the more efficient.

I think it is fair to say that Senator Evans and other honourable senators who have been particularly interested in this matter have a somewhat preconceived notion that the employment of salaried lawyers would be the better way of delivering legal aid. Some years ago, as the statement records, this question was referred to Professor Meredith for determination. Everybody hoped that he would determine it once and for all. Despite the length of time that he has been engaged upon it and the consideration that has been given to this matter, in the first place by the former Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission and referred back to Professor Meredith, the final result as Senator Evans said is inconclusive. That may not be a criticism of Professor Meredith. Of course I have not had the time to study his report or to have any advice in relation to it. However, the difficulties that he has experienced, the time that he has taken to report and now the inconclusiveness of it may well reflect the great difficulties that there are in making any definitive judgments about whether salaried lawyers or lawyers in private practice are able to deliver legal aid more efficiently.

This question cannot be decided only by statistical analysis. Larger questions are at stake. I am pleased that Senator Evans, in his statement, recognises the fact that the private legal profession must always have a major role to play in the delivery of legal aid. It is clear that over many years the private profession has, without any real payment to speak of, provided legal aid to people who could not afford it. In recent years, because of the increase in public funds for legal aid, members of the private profession have been recompensed to some extent for the work that they do. Probably the amounts that have been paid for the work, although seemingly large, are not anything like the recompense that lawyers can obtain from their ordinary private paying clients. A very considerable public contribution continues to be made, not necessarily by all members of the legal profession by any means but by a significant number of lawyers in private practice.

I would be disturbed if, in the long term, there were a policy which phased out the contribution that the private profession were making to legal aid by a steady increase in the number of salaried lawyers. I do not know whether the Attorney-General's statement-this report-or the Government's policy portends that, but I am concerned that it may do so. I am familiar with the arguments by many people, particularly from the Government side of the Parliament which indicate that they favour the delivery of legal aid by salaried lawyers rather than by the private profession. I am pleased that the Attorney-General has indicated that there will be a continuing role for the private profession. How big a role that will be is, I think, the crux of this whole discussion. I look forward to considering this report in detail and to debating further this important question in this chamber when we return in the Budget Session. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

When an honourable senator has a motion to move in this place his right is equal to the right of anyone else, including a Minister. I suggest that what happened this afternoon ought not to happen again. It is not satisfactory for Ministers to be making their own arrangements privately, sometimes without the benefit of the Whips. I know from experience that that is often the case. Ministers should not come to those private arrangements.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Annual Reports: Government Response

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the Government's response to a report on annual reports by the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I seek leave to make a statement and to move that the Senate take note of that statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 November 1980 the Senate resolved that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs should consider and, if necessary, report on all annual reports of government departments and authorities, including statutory corporations, laid on the table of the Senate. On 23 September 1982 the Senate Standing Committee tabled in the Senate its report entitled 'Report on Annual Reports Referred to the Committee'. The report dealt with annual reports prepared by the High Court of Australia, the Attorney- General's Department and a large number of Commonwealth authorities covering either the 1979 and 1980 calendar years or the 1979-80 and 1980-81 financial years depending upon the basis adopted by the particular reporting body.

SPEECH.PARA: The report contained only three recommendations. One recommendation, paragraph 30 of the report, related to the reports of the Attorney-General's Department and read as follows:

Since the Annual Report of the Attorney-General's Department is the only place where the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General is systematically reported on, this part of each future annual report should be considerably expanded. Indeed, consideration should be given to the presentation of a separate report to be dealt with separately by the Parliament and by this Committee.

That recommendation followed consideration of the treatment in the annual report of the Attorney-General's Department of the activities of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. The Senate Committee noted that as at 30 June 1980 there were 40 items on the Standing Committee's agenda, only eight of which were mentioned in the departmental report; none of them in detail.

The approach adopted by the Department in relation to the reporting of Standing Committee of Attorneys-General matters was to deal with only those matters that had been announced already by Ministers-Commonwealth, State or Territory. This approach had regard to the fact that discussions in the Standing Committee had always been conducted on a basis of confidentiality.

The Standing Committee itself recognised the need for some publicity to be given to matters that had been considered. Originally, it was the practice for this to be done by means of an agreed Press statement. However, in February 1980 it was agreed that individual Ministers could issue a statement, if they wished, on the basis that it was for the Minister making a statement to avoid making disclosures which would be outside the spirit of confidentiality accorded to Standing Committee discussions.

At the Standing Committee meeting on 26 March 1983 I informed my colleagues that I intended that there be a considerably expanded report to the Parliament of Standing Committee activities but that such report would be consistent with the existing procedures of the Standing Committee regarding confidentiality. The next annual report of the Attorney-General's Department will be prepared on this basis.

Paragraph 28 of the report now being considered, dealt with the departmental response to criticisms of delays in the Legislative Drafting Division in relation to Australian Capital Territory law reform projects. The Senate Committee suggested increased staff resources for that Division and education of instructing departments. As to the former, there was a small reorganisation of the Division and a strong and successful recruitment campaign. Since the completion of recruitment, the Division's turnover of work has ensured that no backlog of work developed.

As to the suggestion of educating instructing departments, it should be noted that the Division has always been ready to help departments with difficulties encountered in the preparation of drafting instructions and has provided such assistance on many occasions. Further, the Division has assisted in the running of courses at the Canberra College of Advanced Education for persons involved in work related to legislation, including the giving of instructions.
The second recommendation, paragraph 52 of the report, read as follows:

Because of the peculiar nature of the Ombudsman's function and the consequence that he may, on occasions, be embarrassed by the operation of Finance Direction 23/5, its application to his office should be reconsidered.

Finance direction 23/5 has been withdrawn and its provision replaced by directions 13/7 and 13/8. Direction 13/8 applies to the certification that charges for legal expenses are fair and reasonable where the engagement of the legal practioner was undertaken by other than the Crown Solicitor's Office. The direction provides in those circumstances that the endorsement is to be made by the Crown Solicitor, or a Deputy Crown Solicitor or an officer appointed by the Crown Solicitor.

While recognising that there are some few cases where resort to the Crown Solicitor for endorsement of the charges would raise problems of confidentiality for the Commonwealth Ombudsman the Government is unable to agree to an exemption from the direction for him. The Government is, however, prepared to minimise any such problems of confidentiality and in this regard the Crown Solicitor has indicated that he would be prepared to appoint the Registrar of the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory to endorse such claims for legal costs as fair and reasonable. Where, however, the endorsement of such costs by the Crown Solicitor would not raise possible problems of confidentiality the Ombudsman will still be required to submit such accounts to the Crown Solicitor for endorsement.
The final recommendation, paragraph 77 of the report, dealt with the staffing of the Law Reform Commission. That recommendation was as follows:

The Government should give urgent consideration to the staffing situation in the Law Reform Commission with a view to providing the Commission with sufficient staff to properly discharge its important task of law reform.

Since becoming Attorney-General, I have had a number of discussions with the Chairman of the Law Reform Commission regarding present and prospective law reform projects and the resources necessary to undertake them. I have agreed to certain staffing increases and my Department is taking the necessary action in that regard. The Government is committed to public accountability by Departments and authorities. The amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 currently before the Parliament ensure that annual reports are available for parliamentary scrutiny soon after the close of the reporting year and thus that the information provided is up to date.

The report of the Senate Committee I am responding to was critical of the contents of many annual reports because of the brevity of the information contained in them. The Government will, as a matter of priority, review the accountability requirements to ensure adequate and meaningful reporting is achieved. The Government regards the monitoring of reports by this Senate Committee and others as vital if the full benefits of reporting are to be achieved. With the large number of reports tabled and the many conflicting demands on parliamentarians, there is insufficient time available to all of them to examine reports thoroughly and raise matters of concern. Careful scrutiny by the Senate Committee ensures that proper attention is paid both to the recommendations in reports and to the strength and adequacy of the reasoning upon which the recommendations are based. Finally, I wish to commend the Senate Committee on its report which is both informative and appropriately critical. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.
Debate (on motion by Senator Durack) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation to correct an address recorded in Hansard. On 18 May 1983, as recorded at page 599 of Senate Hansard, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: To be fair, the Premier of the day put forward the nomination when legislation such as this was not on the statute books and when he was prepared to build a dam, namely the Gordon above Olga, within the South West Tasmania nominated area .

The latter mentioned adjectival clause is not correct. My attention has been kindly drawn to that fact by the then Premier, Mr Doug Lowe. Because I am concerned that what I say here adheres rigorously to the facts of the situation, I willingly take this opportunity to correct my statement made at that late hour of the night.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak briefly at the second reading stage of the Appropriation Bill (No. 5). There are expenditures in this Appropriation Bill and the other Bills we are debating cognately relating to both the Department of Defence and the Attorney-General's Department. Although there may not be any large expenditures involved which are of any great significance, the fact is that the opportunity has been taken during the Estimates committee debates to question officers of the Department of Defence regarding procedures that were followed within that Department. The Royal Australian Air Force received a request from the Attorney-General's Department to provide assistance in taking aerial photographs of South West Tasmania in which the Gordon below Franklin dam is to be constructed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate will be very familiar with this whole matter and with many of the issues that have been raised. I think a number of the issues are still in some doubt. Certainly, there is clearly a lingering concern on the part of many honourable senators and many people in the community, particularly in Tasmania, about this whole somewhat bizarre episode. On 22 April this year, on a matter of public importance raised by me, the Senate gave close consideration to this matter. I do not want to re-open that particular debate, but I want to deal with some questions that have arisen since then and, in particular, the matters which arose from the Senate Estimates Committee E hearings of evidence from officers of the Department of Defence. These matters are of very considerable concern. I will say something about that a little later.

I also want to refer to the role of the Attorney-General and the Attorney- General's Department in this matter and to the lack of oversight of procedures which undoubtedly occurred and the breaches of procedures in the Department of Defence which have undoubtedly occurred. I am concerned that these matters should be brought to the attention of the Senate because they present serious problems for the future. Questions can still be raised by the Parliament about the proper use of defence assets and the proper expenditure of appropriations by this Parliament in regard to the particular episodes that occurred on 7 April and 8 April this year. On 7 April the Mirage flight took place and on 8 April the flight and photography by the F111 took place. As I said, I do not think I need to recount the facts because they are well known to honourable senators.

The first matter that is of considerable interest is the answers that were obtained during the proceedings of the Estimates Committee. Defence officers were asked how this whole matter came about, what set instructions under the Defence Act applied and why they were not applied. Some very interesting questions were asked and answers given in the Estimates Committee dealing with the Department of Resources and Energy. Senator Sir John Carrick asked a number of questions of the Division of National Mapping as to the availability of resources for photography of this kind. The first question which should be asked is: Why on earth did the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), the Department of Defence and officials of those two departments so readily come to the conclusion that the photography should be undertaken by defence assets rather than by other readily available resources-either resources of the Government or resources in the private sector?

This question is of general importance and also particular importance. One set of the provisions of defence instructions makes it quite clear that any authority requesting the assistance of defence forces for civil purposes must assure the officers of the Defence Force who are dealing with the request that no other resources are properly available in the community to undertake a particular job. That is a very important principle with regard to the use of defence forces for civil purposes. We are talking about non-force situations. We are not talking about defence forces aid being given to quell violence in the community. That is a separate question. Nothing I say today relates to that situation. I refer to the use of defence forces for assistance to the civil community. The other set of instructions deals with aid to the civil power. There is not much doubt that the second set of instructions, namely, 'Defence Force Aid to the Civil Power', were appropriate. But whichever set of instructions applied, a threshold question must be determined as to whether it is appropriate in the circumstances for the defence forces to be used at all in this way.

The matter seems to have first arisen in discussions that occurred between the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and members of his legal team who were concerned with the proceedings against Tasmania for an injunction to restrain the work on the Gordon below Franklin dam. The question must then have arisen about defence forces being used. A very interesting minute dated 11 April 1983 has been tabled in the Senate from Mr Glare, a deputy secretary of the Attorney- General's Department. I suggest that that minute to the Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department gives a very clear outline of what happened. I fully accept the terms of the report made by Mr Glare. It is very instructive and provides the basis for much of the concern that we have because of the way in which this matter was carried out. It appears that after the discussion had been held between the Attorney-General and his legal team the need arose to obtain evidence, presumably in a covert way, so as not, as Mr Glare said, to alarm the Tasmanians. It was decided that Mr Glare should be asked to telephone a personal contact that he had in the RAAF. So the matter started on the basis of an old boy network. Senator Evans has said that the photographic survey by the RAAF seemed a good idea at the time. It apparently seemed a good idea at the time that it should be done in that way. But it was really quite an improper way of going about such an important subject, because of the fundamental point that defence assets should not be used, except in exceptional cases, when other means might be readily available to do the job. It may be that in the end the use of defence assets for this purpose may have been justified. I do not know. It is not my purpose today to pursue that argument. I am concerned that no proper consideration was ever given to this fundamental question.

Mr Glare discussed the matter with RAAF officers. He stated, in effect, that he telephoned a contact to inquire whether it would be feasible to obtain evidence, and it appeared it was feasible. He also made it clear that after discussions with operational people it was decided that the job would require a single pass by an F111 flying at 30,000 feet over the area. As I said, it is quote clear from answers that were given to Senator Sir John Carrick during an Estimates committee hearing dealing with the Department of Resources and Energy that the Division of National Mapping had aircraft available which were capable of undertaking high precision aerial photography. The Division of National Mapping also stated that organisations in the private sector were capable of providing the same service. The Division provided a list containing the names of nine organisations which, in its opinion, were capable of carrying out this work. Aerial photography required for national mapping purposes would seem to be of a sufficiently high standard to provide evidence in legal proceedings, even in a High Court case of such importance.

One of the first matters of real concern is that the availability of such sources was not explored. It also has emerged during the course of this debate that the Australian Federal Police had chartered an aircraft to take photographs . I do not know whether the photographs taken were adequate. Certainly, aerial photography could be carried out by those means. It is probably reasonable to assume the private resources of the nine organisations to which the Division of National Mapping referred would have been perfectly adequate for the purpose. Perhaps the Division of National Mapping could have been engaged to carry out the work. That is another matter which could be debated. The worrying thing is the rapidity with which the old boy network was put into place. A decision was taken that the best way of taking the photographs was to use an F111 to make one pass over the area and take the photographs.

We all now know that Mr Glare told the Attorney-General that the consent of the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) would have to be obtained. It is rather strange that the Attorney-General inquired of a non-legal officer of the Attorney-General's Department whether it would be necessary to obtain the Minister's consent. Mr Glare said he thought it was necessary. Apparently, the only reason why the Attorney-General spoke to the Minister for Defence was on the advice given to him by one of his few non-legal officers. Of course, Mr Glare's advice to the Attorney-General was quite correct. The Attorney-General then spoke to the Minister for Defence, who agreed with the Attorney-General that the flight could be undertaken. It was apparently put to him that it would be consistent with RAAF operational activities.

Of course, the Minister for Defence asked that the matter be confirmed in writing. He did not get anything from the Attorney-General for two or three days after the conversation took place. By the time the Minister for Defence received the letter from the Attorney-General, the flights had taken place. At that stage , obviously there was nothing further that the Minister for Defence could do actually to put in train the agreement that he had made with the Attorney- General. Of course, that is exactly what happened. Mr Scholes did nothing. He may have agreed with the Attorney-General in principle that these flights should take place but he never did anything to authorise the flights. He gave no directions or instructions whatsoever in relation to the matter. The answer of the Minister for Defence to a question asked by Mr Groom in another place on 3 May is very instructive. The Minister for Defence said:

The flights were not authorised by me personally. The negotiations took place on the basis of department to department requirements after the task was agreed between the Attorney-General and me. The flights in this instance were authorised in the same way as flights and activities of this nature are authorised for the purpose of aid to the civil community.

We know that, in fact, these flights were not authorised in accordance with the ordinary procedures for aid to the civil community. The Attorney-General has admitted that there were breaches of the rules. He says that, somehow or other, that does not matter, which is also a very strange view for an Attorney-General to take.

In fact, all that happened was that Mr Glare telephoned Group Captain Waterfield in the Royal Australian Air Force operations section and asked him whether these particular photographic exercises could be carried out. Mr Glare told Group Captain Waterfield that the Minister for Defence had agreed to them. Group Captain Waterfield, in answer to questions he was asked in Estimates Committee E, said that he did not know Mr Glare. He did not even recognise his voice. Yet, on receipt of a telephone call from somebody Group Captain Waterfield did not know and on the say so of that person that the Minister for Defence had authorised the exercises, Group Captain Waterfield set in train this whole operation. He referred the matter to other officers under him who were more directly responsible.

These operations were carried out simply on the basis of that telephone call, with there being no checking with the Minister or any senior officers in the Department of Defence, with no checking being done as to what authority Mr Glare had to say that the Minister had agreed to the exercises and with no formal request having been received from the Attorney-General or the Attorney-General's Department. Really, this does reveal a most extraordinary and disturbing set of circumstances both in the way the Attorney-General's Department and the Attorney -General approached the matter and in the way in which, in fact, fairly senior officers in the RAAF section of the Department of Defence approached this matter . It was a most cavalier approach to a very important problem.

This is a very serious matter indeed and very close controls should be applied. Indeed, under the instructions issued under the Defence Act very considerable controls are placed on the obtaining of Defence Force assets and services for civilian purposes. That is a most important assurance. Indeed, in our democratic society, the use of military forces for other than purely military purposes is a very sensitive matter. As I pointed out in the debate that we had on 22 April, for 100 years or more the House of Commons passed annually an army Act to give emphasis to this very sensitive issue. Therefore, the cavalier way in which this whole matter was approached is, I believe, greatly disturbing.

I believe that it is the responsibility of the Minister for Defence to make an early statement on this whole matter and to make it quite clear which set of instructions he believes applied. As the Attorney-General says and as was confirmed in the Estimates Committee there has been quite some debate about the question of which set of instructions applied. Surely that point at least must be clarified immediately. As I have said, I have a belief about which set of instructions applied. But I think it is imperative that the Minister for Defence makes this clear and ensures that proper procedures are followed so that he can assure the Parliament that procedures have been laid down to avoid this cavalier approach to the use of defence assets occurring again.

I quote for the Senate what the Chief of the Defence Force Staff had to say about this matter in the minute that has been tabled in the Senate. This minute was from Sir Neville McNamara to the Chief of the Air Staff. The minute states:

. . . I now wish to advise you more formally of my concern regarding a number of aspects of the generation and handling of this task; in particular I am extremely concerned that the matter appears to have been handled as a routine task within your directorate of Operations and authorization given without yours or my knowledge. At the very least this action demonstrates a lack of awareness of the political sensitivities and even deeper consequences of the use of Defence Force assets in an issue such as the Franklin River Dam.

As I have said, I think that matter is of great concern to the Parliament. I think the Minister for Defence should, at a very early date indeed, make a statement about the whole matter and clear it up. He should give assurances to the Parliament that this sort of action will not be allowed to happen again in the Department of Defence.

The other matter to which I refer is the role of the Attorney-General and his approach to this matter. He does not seem to have given much thought to this very basic question, to the lawfulness of it or to what were the proper and, indeed, lawful procedures to give effect to his request. He seems to be very ready to brush it off as something for which he did not have any responsibility. He seems ready to brush off the matter because he had a conversation with the Minister for Defence who agreed that that was the beginning and the end of his own responsibility. But the Attorney-General is the chief law officer, the chief legal adviser to the Government. I would have thought that he should and would have been alert to the sensitivities of this matter. When all is said and done, a non-political officer, the Chief of the Defence Force Staff, was very alert to the political sensitivities of this matter. But the Attorney-General does not seem to have been alert to that element. He does not seem to have been alert either to the legal problems that could have arisen and to the legal procedures that should have been observed.

The Department of Defence instructions are, in fact, issued under the statutory authority of the Defence Act. There must be some sanctions for breaches of these instructions. One cannot have instructions with statutory force and obligations arising under a statute which are just entirely ignored. Yet the proper way of going about this matter was ignored not only by officers of the Department of Defence but also by the officers of the Attorney-General's Department who were involved in this matter. I would have thought that, at the very least, these questions should have been in the forefront of the minds of officers of the Attorney-General's Department, if not in the forefront of the mind of the Attorney-General himself. This should be a matter of very considerable concern to the Senate. When we appropriate money for these departments, as we are doing here, we are entitled to an assurance that they will take a very much more responsible approach to questions of such importance, should a matter such as this arise again in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to enter this debate, but a few things ought to be said in defence of Group Captain Waterfield. Were it not known how to characterise and give weight to the utterances of the Opposition in this matter, the continued allegations against that young officer by the shadow Attorney would be potentially damaging to his career. That is the only reason I enter this debate. Group Captain Waterfield was brought before the Senate Estimates committee at the request of the Opposition and, as I understand it, at considerable difficulty to himself. It was not expected that he would be required to appear. But he did appear, perhaps an hour after the commencement of proceedings, when the request was made. He remained extremely calm, polite and co-operative in the face of the most hostile, not to say somewhat abrupt, questioning that I have seen a witness before an Estimates committee subjected to. It became so hostile at one stage that the Committee Chairman and the Committee rebuked one honourable senator. After Group Captain Waterfield had given an answer to the best of his ability, Senator MacGibbon asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Were these flights within the normal and customary ambit of training operations of the Royal Australian Air Force-yes or no?
It was like a magistrates court. The Hansard record continues:
Group Capt. Waterfield-Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you.
—Are you happy with that?
—No. The witness has got to live with that answer.
—I suggest that is an intimidatory remark and it should be struck from the record. Senator MacGibbon ought to be asked to apologise.

SPEECH.PARA: CHAIRMAN-I ask for that remark to be withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw it.
—I ask Senator MacGibbon to apologise to the witness. It is quite intolerable behaviour.
—I apologise.

SPEECH.PARA: I give him credit for doing so at the request of the Committee. My point is that this young officer, in the face of hostile questioning, conducted himself with a demeanour that was a credit to him. I think that small tribute should be paid.

As to the substantive matters, Senator Durack put once again that Group Captain Waterfield acted in a cavalier manner in dispatching an aircraft as though it could have been done on the basis of a telephone call from any unidentified person claiming to be X, Y or Z from any phone box somewhere in Australia. In fact, as emerged from the evidence, Group Captain Waterfield responded, as he felt required to do, having been informed that the Minister had approved a task. He did not then dispatch an aircraft. As the evidence reveals, he determined that the matter should be passed to the appropriate tasking officer from Operational Command. He told the Operational Command tasking officer to contact the Attorney-General's Department to see about the details. In other words, there was a series of subsequent contacts between the tasking officer and the Department to determine the precise nature of the task to be undertaken. I think that sequence ought to be reconfirmed to the Senate.

I turn to the letter from the Chief of Defence Force Staff. Senator MacGibbon, having put that letter from the CDFS, including the phrase, 'In particular I am extremely concerned that the matter appeared to have been handled as a routine task within your directorate', went on:
The inference from that is very clear, that the CDFS did not regard this as a training flight. What is your comment on that?

After some toing and froing it was determined by the Committee that it was appropriate that Group Captain Waterfield not be put in the position of having to draw an inference from the written remarks of the Chief of Defence Force Staff. That is my contribution. I simply felt that in defence of Group Captain Waterfield a little fuller revealing of the course of the evidence would be of advantage to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to speak for very long. I apologise for not hearing all the speakers from the Opposition. I want to make a couple of brief comments. As I listened to Senator Durack's casuistry, I thought what a pity he was not as diligent in cleaning out the bottom drawers of the Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth as he is in chasing phantoms around the Senate for the nth time. His criticism of what he purports to regard as official negligence sits very badly when it comes from someone who presided, inert as a stuffed bullfrog, over the Attorney-General's Department while tax evaders stole billions of dollars from honest taxpayers, protected from the long arm of the law by the bottom drawer of the Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to comment on one item in Senator MacGibbon's speech, which was the other one I heard. I refer to the question of the airlines. Again I thought it was somewhat incongruous for a Queensland senator to be criticising Trans Australia Airlines for operating unprofitably-I interpolate that I am by no means an uncritical admirer of TAA-when to a significant degree the losses recorded by TAA are a direct function of its being forced to maintain unprofitable services in western Queensland with unsuitable aircraft, services which it is forced to maintain by what can be described only as blackmail by the State Government of Queensland. As regards his criticism of the two airlines agreement, I do not recall precisely who voted for that agreement when it was before the Parliament. But my recollection is that Senator MacGibbon was one of those then Government senators who voted for the two airlines agreement which he now has the audacity to criticise. If that is wrong, I will willingly retract and apologise, but my recollection is--

TALK.START.PARA: —You will get the opportunity when you finish.

—If the honourable senator did not vote for it, I apologise. My recollection is that certainly the party of which he is member pushed that agreement through the Parliament knowing that, if it did not do so before the end of June 1981, it would not have the numbers to do so afterwards. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a few questions partly on behalf of Senator Martin, who is unable to be here, and partly on my own behalf, concerning the National Film Archive. They are of some urgency. I understand that Senator Ryan was given warning that these questions were to be asked. I think it is important that they be put on the public record. They concern the problem of the copying of nitrate film being undertaken by the National Film Archive. In the hearings of the Estimates committees last year-and again this year, I believe-it was pointed out that if the present holdings of nitrate film are not copied for preservation by the year 2000 it will be too late to preserve these films because they will have deteriorated irretrievably. First, have extra funds and staff been allocated, as the Estimates Committee recommended, for the copying program? I understand from the Director of the National Film Archive that $600,000 is required each year for the copying program to be achieved by the due date; that is, to the year 2000. What is the sum allocated to this program in the current financial year? What was the additional sum, if any, allocated in the Budget since last year? What is the number of full time qualified staff in the National Film Archive? Are these numbers sufficient to carry out the program? Have any additional full time staff been allocated to the National Film Archive since last year's Budget? The National Film Archive estimated that it needs to copy 700 cans of film this year to reach the year 2000 target. Will it have sufficient funds to copy this number in this financial year? If not, how many cans of film will it be able to copy?

SPEECH.PARA: I am also concerned about reports that services of the film makers and the film industry in general have been severely restricted because of a lack of funds for the National Film Archive. Is there a prospect of further funds and staff being made available to the National Film Archive to rectify this problem? Mr Temporary Chairman, if these questions seem too detailed I emphasise that the matter is urgent and that Senator Ryan was given notice of the intention to raise these questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been given a note which I think deals with the questions that Senator Hamer has asked. I did not have time to write down all the questions so if the answers are not satisfactory Senator Hamer should feel free to come back to me. The National Library Council has recorded its concern at the inadequacy of the resources available for film archive activities and for certain other Library activities. The Library has recognised the need to copy the deteriorating nitrate cellulose based film in its collection by the year 2000. Accordingly over recent years it has been allocating increasing resources of staff and funds for this purpose. Last financial year $150,000 was provided and this financial year $248,000 was provided. I acknowledge that that falls well short of the longer term target identified by Senator Hamer. The sum originally allocated for 1982-83 has not been supplemented.

SPEECH.PARA: There are 10 full time staff, including some with long experience in the National Film Archive's activities. Since the Budget last year 16 part time positions have also been allocated to this work. No formal qualifications are required in film archives work generally. It is estimated that 250 cans of film will be copied this year of which 100 will be preservation copies. Fewer than 150 cans of film were copied in 1981-82. Access restrictions to the material in the National Film Archive were introduced because the staff could no longer service the rapidly rising demand. The lack of funds and equipment has limited the number of viewing copies than can be made and has curtailed access to the Archive's resources.

I understand that in its 1983-84 estimate proposals the Australian National Library is seeking additional staff and funds for the Film Archive. The stage one extensions to the National Library building which are now being constructed include provision for a special storage facility for the preservation of master copies of Australian film. In closing, I should add that that bid will have to be considered in conjunction with all the other bids that will come from various departments and from other sources in the Budget context.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in this debate on the expenditures considered by Senate Estimates Committee E. I propose to put some balance into what has already been debated this afternoon because there was nothing at all in what the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Durack, said that in any way reflected on the professional ability of Group Captain Waterfield. Group Captain Waterfield came before us, at the suggestion of members of the Committee .
—He was treated disgracefully.
—Indeed, Senator Sibraa was the Chairman and allowed the questioning to go on in the fashion that it did.
—He was treated disgracefully.

—He was not treated disgracefully, otherwise Senator Sibraa would have brought the questioning to an end. But at no stage did he attempt to bring it to an end. He considered it to be quite reasonable questioning. Indeed, I believe that it is to Group Captain Waterfield's credit that he was able to answer the questions in such an open fashion with the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), the responsible Minister in the Senate, sitting at the end of the table. To say that there was perhaps a little pressure brought to bear on Group Captain Waterfield by his Minister is putting it mildly. I asked Group Captain Waterfield what time he was telephoned by Mr Glare. According to the documents we had tabled, Group Captain Waterfield said that it was one o'clock. Later, because that answer did not fit in with what Mr Glare or the Attorney-General had said regarding the permission that was sought by the Minister for Defence ( Mr Scholes), Group Captain Waterfield was then asked whether he was sure it was one o'clock. He said: 'Well, I do not really know what the time was. I thought it was around one o'clock'. He was prepared to say he did not know. Maybe it was 3 o'clock, as Mr Glare had said. I asked Group Captain Waterfield why he thought it was one o'clock. I think his simple answer reflected the truth. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I stated the time initially as being around one o'clock was that at that stage I thought I had received the call at about the tail end of our normal lunch period.

That is an easy way in which to recollect the time. He believed he received the call around about the tail end of his normal lunch period. That suggests to me that it is around one o'clock, not 3 o'clock in the afternoon which would be well after the tail end of the lunch period. The suggestion that it might have been 3 o'clock was, I believe, because of pressure put upon him that it should fit in with the Minister's suggestion that he sought permission at a much later time. I believe this underlines very clearly that the Attorney-General had not even sought permission from the Minister for Defence when Group Captain Waterfield was telephoned and told that the Minister had given his approval. Group Captain Waterfield's recollection was that he received the call at one o' clock.

Senator Gareth Evans said that he asked the Minister for Defence at the beginning of a Cabinet meeting. The Minister for Defence said that his recollection was after the Cabinet meeting. Mr Glare said that he thought it was about 3 o'clock in the afternoon. There is a great deal of doubt about whether, when this streaker's defence started, the Minister for Defence had even been approached for permission to have these spy flights over Tasmania. Indeed, there was a meeting between Mr Glare and the Attorney-General. The Attorney-General, according to the tabled documents, asked Mr Glare whether there was any need to approach the Minister for Defence. Mr Glare said yes. He believed there was a need. He said he would telephone. A short time later Mr Glare was telephoned and told that permission had been given. That was some time after the morning meeting. There was an indication that the telephone call had taken place. The Attorney-General never made that telephone call. He said he saw Mr Scholes at the beginning of a Cabinet meeting.

I believe that is a ridiculous way in which to go about seeking permission from the Minister for Defence. Any Minister would know that he has to get written approval before anything can take place. That written approval was never given. I believe there is very serious doubt that any verbal permission was given until well after the debacle was set in motion, even though Group Captain Waterfield had been told that the Minister had given permission. I felt very sorry for Group Captain Waterfield, sitting there with the Minister applying what I believe was pressure. If any disgraceful behaviour took place at that Estimates Committee meeting it would have been by the Attorney-General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak because of some of the remarks made by Senator Walters. I am getting sick and tired of this nonsense that is being talked about spy flights over Tasmania. I think the matter ought to be put in its proper perspective. As far as I recall-I did not take part in the questioning at the time-the matter concerns a normal sort of flight that the Royal Australian Air Force undertakes all the time, as was revealed in the Estimates Committee hearing. Not one additional cent was spent. Not one additional minute was spent in flying. It was a flight by the Royal Australian Air Force over Australia. To call it a spy flight is the greatest lot of nonsense that I have ever heard. I ask Senator Walters whether she regards Tasmanians as Australians.
—Order! Senator Sibraa, I am afraid you cannot address questions to Senator Walters.

—I shall read some extracts from the Estimates Committee Hansard report. I have not had a lot of time to find them. At one stage I reminded the shadow Attorney-General that Group Captain Waterfield was not on trial and that he should not put questions to him in the way in which he did. I refer to two instances in which a relatively junior officer in the Air Force was treated in what I regard as a disgraceful manner. I refer to the transcript of Estimates Committee E, which states:

—I put it to you, Mr Chairman, that it is inappropriate and quite outside the normal parameters of the operation of the Defence Force anywhere for a junior officer to be required to comment on the inference of a senior officer's letter.

SPEECH.PARA: CHAIRMAN-That was the point that I was about to take. I am appreciative of the fact that Group Captain Waterfield has come along here to answer questions. He did not have to come. I think that is a question which if he does not want to answer, he should not answer.
Group Captain Waterfield-I would prefer not to answer that question.
I have another example. Senator Durack directed this question to Group Captain Waterfield:

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you regard the flights, as you have told us, as special flights for those purposes?

SPEECH.PARA: Group Capt. Waterfield-They were specially tasked.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take up Senator Durack's point and remind the witness that this is a privileged meeting.
—What is that supposed to mean?

SPEECH.PARA: CHAIRMAN-I do not think any member of this Committee can attempt to put that sort of proposition to any of the witnesses here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you allow me the courtesy of asking my question please? My question is: Were these flights within the normal and customary ambit of training operations of the Royal Australian Air Force-yes or no?

SPEECH.PARA: Group Capt. Waterfield-Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you.
—Are you happy with that?
—No. The witness has got to live with that answer.
—I suggest that is an intimidatory remark and it should be struck from the record. Senator MacGibbon ought to be asked to apologise.

SPEECH.PARA: CHAIRMAN-I ask for that remark to be withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw it.
—I ask Senator MacGibbon to apologise to the witness. It is quite intolerable behaviour.
—I apologise.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that those two instances-and I referred to a third-do not show the sort of treatment a junior officer from the Air Force should receive in front of a Senate Estimates committee. That is the reason I asked for an apology. I would not have raised this issue at all if Senator Walters had not commented on this instance in the first place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call any other speakers on this matter I should point out to the Committee that this matter was aired during the second reading debate. I allowed Senator Walters to make some remarks and a rejoinder by Senator Sibraa. But I insist that any subsequent speakers on this matter relate their remarks to a particular aspect of the Estimates, rather than having a general debate.

—The Estimates Committee was faced with a most obdurate and impassive level of obstruction from the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans), the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, who was there at the time representing the Department. He did everything in his power to restrict the appearance of witnesses who were very relevant to the business before the Chair. It must be understood what was going on. It is quite wrong for the Chairman to put a different interpretation on the events to those that occurred at the time. The Chairman was there. If he does not like the way the meeting was conducted, that is his fault. He was in command, although I think that in reality Senator Gareth Evans was in command. The point is that Senator Evans was blatantly intimidating serving officers of the Royal Australian Air Force and trying to make them conform to a position he had adopted. At no stage did Senator Durack or myself do anything to harm or hazard the career of an officer of the Crown. We asked questions with great care. What we were after was the truth of what occurred. If honourable senators read the transcript of the Committee proceedings they will find that is borne out. Senator Evans clearly tried to intimidate and obstruct that Committee. That is the truth of the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly and relate my remarks to the Estimates. Senator Sibraa has just said that not one extra cent was spent on the flights; that they were normal flights. I quote one question and an answer. They read:
—Would it be in any way appropriate to describe that as a re- routed training flight?

SPEECH.PARA: Group Capt. Waterfield-This is the Mirage flight you are referring to?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Mirage flight.

SPEECH.PARA: Group Capt. Waterfield-No. That Mirage flight was specifically tasked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is perhaps a bit of information I should supply here. The matter has been raised earlier on a number of occasions as to why a Royal Australian Air Force plane was used. At the Estimates Committee Senator Sir John Carrick, I think it was, asked whether the Division of National Mapping had planes available and whether they were suitably equipped. I have been advised that on 6, 7 and 8 April the aircraft, which is fitted with suitable photographic equipment and belongs to the Division of National Mapping, was located at Melbourne on standby for aerial photography in the Mildura area, but that the weather at Mildura was unsuitable at the time. Weather conditions permitting, National Mapping could have carried out aerial photography over the Franklin Dam site but it is unlikely that the Attorney- General's Department was aware of National Mapping's air photography capabilities as there had been no precedent.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Remarks of Minister for Foreign Affairs-Tabling of Papers by Attorney-General

PROCTEXT.PARA: Remarks of Minister for Foreign Affairs-Tabling of Papers by Attorney-General
Motion (by Senator Walsh) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw attention to a story which appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser resulting from a recent interview that Peter Smark of the Melbourne Age had with the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Bill Hayden. In the course of the interview, Mr Hayden was reported to have said:

SPEECH.PARA: It was obvious that we were going to win.
This is in connection with the election-

I had never doubted it. I still believe that the election could have been won by our party led by anyone except a cripple. Of course there are some people in politics who have been crippled by their mates.

I understand that the remark was widely reported in a number of newspapers around Australia and that the matter was given some prominence by the electronic media. Mr Hayden's reference to 'cripples' has caused concern, anguish and distress within the disabled community. I draw this matter to the attention of the Senate because it has occurred particularly in my own State.

Over the past decade, governments, non-government organisations and the disabled community have been attempting to ensure that disabled people are accepted, without discrimination, into the wider community. I believe that efforts in this area have been generally successful. We have gone a long way towards removing from the minds of the general community the stigma or otherwise that was long associated with disabled people. In these endeavours exercises such as the International Year of Disabled Persons have been important in making us more aware of the disabled and assisting them to come out. This good work can and will be set back by a return to old prejudices. Terms like that unfortunately uttered by Mr Hayden feed those prejudices and should not be spoken or heard. It should be remembered that the community's expectations of the disabled are governed by labels and attitudes. In turn, the disabled individual's self-concept is moulded by the status accorded him and the expectations of him. Statements like Mr Hayden's have the effect of limiting these expectations and reducing their status. As a former Minister for Social Security, and a respected Minister, Mr Hayden should have known perhaps how disparaging such remark was.

This week I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) requesting that he obtain from Mr Hayden a withdrawal of his remark and an apology to the members of the community, particularly the disabled. I hope that that action will be quickly forthcoming. In conclusion, I should not have to point out to Mr Hayden the number of disabled people who have records of significant achievements in many areas of the community. Disabled people should not have to prove themselves, but if they must, I think that their achievements speak for themselves. I refer very briefly to a small poem by Gerard Manley Hopkins:
Each mortal thing does one thing and the same:
Deals at that being indoors each one dwells;
Selves-goes itself: myself it speaks and spells;
Crying What I do is me: for that I came.
If all Australians were to try harder to fulfil their own potential, as Hopkins urges, ours would be a better community. In reaching this goal there is much we can learn from the disabled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this adjournment debate on a most unusual matter. I ask the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, who is the Minister in charge of the Senate, whether he can accommodate my request. This is at least the fourth time when I have sought the papers that the Attorney -General, Senator Gareth Evans, promised he would table when I first asked for them on 11 May. I repeated my request at the appropriate Estimates committee hearing. I was told by the officer concerned that it would take two days to do so. That was a fortnight ago. I brought up the matter again this morning and I was assured by the Attorney-General that the papers would be tabled before the Senate adjourned today. I have just made inquiries and they have still not been tabled.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans has said on two occasions that he was sorry, he forgot. I take that statement at face value. I am quite sure that he is so snowed with paper in his Department that the matter has not crossed his mind. But surely to heavens there is someone in his Department whose responsibility it is to see that papers which are requested are tabled. I do not know whether it is arrogance on the part of the Department; but, if the Attorney-General does not have sufficient control over his Department to get the papers tabled, he should have. I ask again, with the greatest respect: Is it possible to have the papers tabled before we rise this evening?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reply briefly to the two matters that have been raised tonight. I refer first to the speech by Senator Messner. I read the remarks attributed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, in the Adelaide Advertiser and I spoke to Mr Hayden about them. Of course, as Senator Messner said, the remarks were unfortunate. Mr Hayden, of course, regrets making them. But I am sure that Senator Messner, like any other politician in this place, has been unfortunate enough to make remarks like that in similar situations to those in which these were made. I assume that Senator Messner is genuine in his concern for the disabled people in the community by bringing this matter up tonight and that he is not just trying ot make political points and to embarrass Mr Hayden. It would be wrong of me to suggest that Senator Messner would do anything like that, although some would suggest that he might.

SPEECH.PARA: In case that is what he was about, perhaps I should compare the speaker tonight with the person when he chose to refer to in this way in the Parliament tonight rather than to do so privately. Mr Hayden was a very respected Minister for Social Security. The Handicapped Persons Assistance Program in this country was developed and introduced by the same Bill Hayden who, as I say, was a distinguished Minister and always showed great concern for the disabled in the community. If one reads the speeches which Mr Hayden has made over the years, one will know that one of the people he has admired in the past and whom he quotes in speeches inside and outside the Parliament is President Roosevelt who inspired the world in his efforts from a wheelchair as President of the United States.

I compare that with the actions of the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs who, when he held that portfolio, proceeded to sell off to a large extent the repatriation artificial limb facility. What has happened is that the costs of artificial limbs and appliances for the disabled in this community have increased to the extent that the present Minister has had to reverse the decision. I make those points. I think it is easy for any of us to speak in a pompous way as did the ex-Minister for Veterans' Affairs today and try to denigrate a man who has contributed far more to politics than he has or is likely to do in this community. Mr Hayden regrets the words that he used. He admits that he regrets the words that he used and he does not need speeches from Senator Messner to get him to do that.

I will seek advice from the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, on what has happened to the papers which I believe he described in Question Time as being lost somewhere in the bowels of the Department. As the honourable senator said, he is busy and is snowed under with paper as the rest of us are. However, I am sure that, when he is reminded of the fact that he did say that they would be tabled today and they have not been, his impatience will be demonstrated to the officers who were responsible. I am sure that, now both of us are working on the matter, the honourable senator will get in the next few days the papers that she desires.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.11 p.m. until 1.45 p.m. on Tuesday, 31 May 1983.
