ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Statutory Authorities: Loans to Board Members

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which of the following Government authorities extend below-market interest loans to members of their executive, boards, or staff: (a) Aussat Pty Ltd; (b) the Australian Broadcasting Commission; (c) the Australian Manufacturing Council ; (d) the Project Australia Committee; (e) the Australia-Japan Foundation; and ( f) the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization.
(2) Have any loans at below-market rates been extended to the Western Australian businessman, Mr Denis Byrne Horgan.
(3) Is Mr Horgan associated with all the authorities mentioned in the first part of this question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) None of the bodies named in the question falls within the portfolio of the Treasurer. Accordingly, the honourable senator should redirect his questions to the Ministers responsible for the company, authority or body concerned; the Minister for Communications in respect of 1 (a) and 1 (b); the Minister for Industry and Commerce in respect of 1 (c) and 1 (d); the Minister for Foreign Affairs in respect of 1 (e) and the Minister for Science and Technology in respect of 1 (f).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the normal manner in which Australian Ambassadors or High Commissioners are paid their salaries.

(2) Are one or more Australian Ambassadors or High Commissioners been paid their salaries as a gross figure, without any tax being deducted, or in any manner different from the normal manner in which persons on the Government payroll receive their salaries; if so, who are the persons involved and what is the manner of payment involved.
(3) What are the special circumstances involved in each case in which deductions have been varied pursuant to section 221D (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australian Ambassadors and High Commissioners receive their salaries fortnightly through the Department of Finance salaries system which takes account of allowance entitlements and deductions for income tax instalments, superannuation instalments, Hospital and Medical Benefits Fund contributions, etc.

Tax instalments are deducted in accordance with schedules prescribed in the Income Tax Regulations unless the Taxation Office directs otherwise. The Taxation Commissioner points out that, although the prescribed schedules are satisfactory for the majority of salary and wage earners, the law recognises that cases may arise where it would be inappropriate to make deductions at normal rates. Accordingly, section 221D of the Income Tax Assessment Act authorises the Commissioner to vary the amounts of tax instalments to be deducted to meet special circumstances of any case or class of cases. Where such a variation is approved, the employer concerned is notified in writing.
(2), (3) and (4) The Commissioner of Taxation advises that the secrecy provisions of the income tax law prevent the disclosing of details of the affairs of particular taxpayers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Treasurer consider introducing legislation to compel foreign corporations participating, or intending to participate, in resource projects in Australia, to process the raw materials domestically, where possible, to increase employent opportunities for Australian workers and to provide a boost to the Australian economy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The attractiveness of Australia as a location for resource processing depends on many factors, including relative profitability, availability of appropriate technology and proximity to final markets as well as the availability and cost of transport. It these factors do not favour processing in Australia, making processing a condition of foreign investment policy approval for proposed resource extraction would be likely to significantly reduce the attractiveness of resources extraction projects themselves and, thereby, to place in jeopardy the economic benefits that can accrue to Australia from foreign investment in such projects. The Government considers that processing will be undertaken when commercial circumstances favour processing in Australia rather than elsewhere and that compulsion is therefore an inappropriate means of encouraging foreign investors to undertake processing in Australia of Australian raw materials.
